Weather teams also do not appreciate Sticky Web.

Team Options

Shuckle should be run on Sticky Web-based offensive teams. Such teams generally include decently fast setup sweepers, such as Carracosta and Omastar, that can take advantage of the Sticky Web to more easily sweep with less fear of being outsped. Faster setup sweepers such as Oricorio-E, Dodrio, and Simisear and other faster Pokemon such as Floatzel similarly appreciate being able to more reliably outspeed foes, specifically Choice Scarf users like Primeape. Finally, slower wallbreakers such as Stoutland and Victreebel benefit from Sticky Web, as they can supply immediate power without having to fear being easily revenge killed. Primeape and Pawniard both run Defiant, which allows them to switch in against and take advantage of Defog users like Skuntank and Silvally-Fairy. They also often pressure the opponent into being more hesitant to use Defog altogether. Ghost-types like Oricorio-G and Jellicent can block the other form of entry hazard removal in Rapid Spin and can help against Defiant Primeape. Although they take a decent amount from Stealth Rock, Flying-types like Swanna and Oricorio-G are immune to Sticky Web, making them large threats to these teams. Therefore, Pokemon that can check them such as Cryogonal can come in handy.

Ursaring.overview: Monstrous Attack, access to Swords Dance, and a powerful ability in Guts make Ursaring a force to be reckoned with as a physical wallbreaker. This, combined with its fairly low Speed, makes it a near mandatory member for Trick Room teams as a wallbreaker. Its bulk is good enough so that it isn't too threatened by priority outside of Mach Punch. However, Ursaring's Speed and mediocre bulk mean that, outside of Trick Room, it's very vulnerable to faster attackers. It also faces competition from other physical Normal-types such as Kangaskhan and Stoutland, which fit on more common playstyles, while Ursaring is usually dedicated to only Trick Room. While it does have a large number of coverage moves, Ursaring finds itself very predictable because it generally chooses the same moves for any set.
Ursaring.comments:
Other Options

Despite facing stiff competition from faster Normal-types like Stoutland and Kangaskhan, faster Guts variants with maximum Speed investment are nevertheless very effective at wallbreaking, and can utilize Protect to safely activate Guts against common leads like Eelektross and Primeape, making Ursaring a decent anti-lead. Quick Feet can be used with a Toxic Orb instead of a Flame Orb, but, even with the boost, Ursaring is outsped by Pokemon like Lycanroc and is easily revenge killed because of its bulk. This set is much weaker than other sets because of Ursaring's Jolly nature and loss of a Guts boost. Earthquake can be used as a coverage option over Close Combat to eliminate the Defense and Special Defense drops while still hitting most of the same Pokemon, but it lacks a lot of power in comparison to Close Combat. Play Rough is an option to hit Sableye and Spiritomb for super effective damage, but it is generally worse than Crunch because Crunch can hit a wider range of Ghost-types. Seed Bomb more immediately threatens Colbur Berry variants of Jellicent but is otherwise inferior to Crunch. A Bulk Up set with Rest and Sleep Talk is an alternative way to set up, and, while it doesn't provide as much offensive pressure as Swords Dance, the Defense boosts help its matchup against Foul Play users and other physical attackers. However, this is usually outclassed by Type: Null.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon: Fighting-types threaten Ursaring greatly with their super effective STAB attacks. Hitmonchan and Primeape easily outspeed and can KO Ursaring without Trick Room, although Hitmonchan needs a little chip damage to ensure it can OHKO Ursaring. Gurdurr can tank a Facade and 2HKO Ursaring, and a Mach Punch from Hitmonchan and Gurdurr can pick off a weakened Ursaring. However, all of these Pokemon lose to Ursaring if it already has set up a Swords Dance and is under Trick Room.

Physical Walls: Pokemon like Regirock and Mudsdale require Ursaring to set up a Swords Dance in order to OHKO them and can use the opportunity to set up Stealth Rock or get chip damage with Stone Edge or Earthquake. Regirock also has the option to run Sturdy, making Ursaring's job of KOing it even harder.

Ghost-type Pokemon: While not impenetrable, Ghost-types like Jellicent and Oricorio-G are capable of pivoting around Ursaring’s attacks and can stall Trick Room turns. Black Glasses Spiritomb is able to take one hit from an unboosted Ursaring while 2HKOing it, and Aguav Berry variants can handle it in a similar manner.

Fake Out and Protect: This is more of a way to check the Trick Room playstyle that Ursaring often finds itself on, but stalling Trick Room turns helps minimize the damage Ursaring can do. Protect users like Regirock allow the player to scout what move Ursaring is going for, forcing the opponent to make a prediction on whether it will switch out or not, and Kangaskhan's Fake Out can do a sizable amount of damage to Ursaring.

Faster Pokemon: Outside of Trick Room, Ursaring is extremely slow, leaving it easily revenge killed by anything faster with a strong STAB move or Fighting-type coverage.

sets.name: Trick Room Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Moves

Facade is Ursaring's go-to STAB move unless there is a foe resistant or immune to Normal-type moves. With 140 Base Power, STAB, and a boost from Guts when Ursaring is burned, Facade can break through almost anything in the tier. Crunch is used to hit Ghost-types like Oricorio-G and Jellicent super effectively while also hitting Sableye and Spiritomb neutrally to prevent Ursaring from being completely walled by them. Close Combat hits Rock- and Steel-types that resist Facade like Regirock, Carracosta, and Aggron.

Set Details

A Brave nature is used to make Ursaring's low Speed more effective under Trick Room. Guts boosts Ursaring's Attack even higher when affected by status and helps it beat common physical walls in the tier like Tangela. A Flame Orb is used to ensure that Ursaring can have Guts activated and to prevent it from being affected by Toxic poison and paralysis, which are much more detrimental.

Usage Tips

Ursaring under Trick Room is a dedicated physical wallbreaker, as there aren't many good checks to it that can take its Facade after a boost. Even with a sky-high Attack stat, Ursaring can fail to harm defensive Ghost-types that run Foul Play like Spiritomb, so it should try to play around those. Ursaring should try to use Swords Dance when coming in on a weak foe like Clefairy, though it should be wary of the rare Knock Off. Because Ursaring is a very prediction-reliant Pokemon and Trick Room is a hyper offensive playstyle, Ursaring should take advantage of the limited turns as much as possible. As its main role is to be a wallbreaker, it should allow a late-game cleaner like Drampa to finish off the other parts of a team.

Team Options

Trick Room setters like Carbink are mandatory partners for Ursaring. Carbink sets up Stealth Rock, has Magic Coat to prevent opposing entry hazards from being set up, and uses Explosion to bring in Ursaring for free. As a hard-hitting wallbreaker, Ursaring appreciates the help of U-turn support to get in on something it can take advantage of or threaten. Wishiwashi is notable, as it can lure in special walls like Audino and Eelektross for Ursaring to take advantage of. Special wallbreakers like Drampa help Ursaring deal with physically defensive Pokemon, namely Regirock and Tangela, and have an easier time cleaning after Ursaring breaks a team. Pokemon with moves like Memento, Explosion, and Healing Wish such as Carbink, Audino, and Musharna all help Ursaring get in for free and many Pokemon have access to one of these moves along with Trick Room. Musharna also acts as a Fighting-type check that helps cover Ursaring's weakness to Mach Punch. Ursaring and Crabominable form a great physically offensive core with Trick Room, with Ursaring absorbing status and being fairly reliable at breaking through Psychic-types like Musharna and Crabominable in return taking care of Normal-resistant and -immune Pokemon like Regirock and Jellicent.

Magcargo.overview: Magcargo has access to a decent utility movepool and has good physical bulk. However, it has a bad HP stat, is weak to all entry hazards, and is prone to being Taunted by the likes of Jellicent and Aggron due to its low Speed. Furthermore, its typing hinders it, as its 4x weakness to Water- and Ground-type attacks make it easy for Jellicent and Mudsdale to take care of Magcargo, and its other weaknesses to Fighting- and Rock-types attacks leave it vulnerable to Pokemon like Gurdurr and Aggron. It is outclassed by Stealth Rock users like Mudsdale, Regirock, and Clefairy because of their better typing, resistance or immunity to Stealth Rock, and better abilities like Stamina and Magic Guard.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Magcargo's goal is to set Stealth Rock, spread status to Pokemon, and stall them out with Recover, as having reliable recovery is one niche it does have as well as Flame Body to help scare out physical attackers. However, it has a hard time doing this because of its low Speed and its 4x weaknesses to Water- and Ground-types. Stealth Rock users like Mudsdale, Clefairy, and Regirock outclass this Pokemon because of their typing, better bulk, and better abilities like Stamina and Magic Guard.

Corsola.overview: Corsola's stats make it extremely passive, slow, and a momentum sink, and its defensive typing is also quite bad, since there are a lot of top threats such as Victreebel and Gurdurr that have a type advantage against it. It is outclassed by multiple Stealth Rock users, most notably Omastar, which shares a similar typing to Corsola, as well as Regirock and Clefairy, which have better stats and are more threatening. The only redeeming quality that Corsola has is possessing two types of recovery in Recover and Regenerator.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: This set attempts to set up Stealth Rock and, if possible, status the opposing Pokemon it can check, such as Flying-types like Oricorio-G and Swanna, or switch out to take advantage of Regenerator. Unfortunately, Corsola doesn't really accomplish anything besides setting Stealth Rock and fainting. Omastar, Clefairy, and Regirock fulfill this role with a lot more success because of their better stats and, with the exception of Omastar, typing. Regirock is especially noteworthy because it fills the same role, checks very similar Pokemon, and generally has more to offer in a team slot.

Octillery.overview: Octillery might appear to possess some potential with its good Special Attack and vast movepool, but its lackluster Speed and bulk gives it a more difficult time to switch in safely. Octillery faces overwhelming competition from Ludicolo and Choice Specs Jellicent as Water-type wallbreakers due to them having far more opportunities to switch in by virtue of their secondary typings. Octillery can only use its poor Speed to its advantage in the niche archetype of Trick Room, but it still faces competition from special attackers like Beheeyem, which bears a better offensive presence through Nasty Plot and higher Special Attack.

sets.name: Trick Room
sets.description: This set attempts to utilize Octillery as a wallbreaker on Trick Room with a Life Orb to allow Octillery to fire off its good coverage. However, there is very little reason to use Octillery over Beheeyem, which has a higher Special Attack stat as well as Nasty Plot, meaning it doesn't have to predict as often to wallbreak.

Delibird.overview: Delibird is an atrocious Pokemon, being outclassed by virtually every other lead in the game due to its abysmal Speed and defenses, meaning it will rarely ever be able to set up more than one layer of Spikes. Even though it's able to run Rapid Spin in an attempt to win the hazard game, Qwilfish is more effective at keeping entry hazards off the field due to its superior Speed, Intimidate and access to Taunt while Roselia can utilize Eviolite and has access to reliable recovery options; both have more defensive utility overall, making them far more reliable options.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description: In theory, Spikes and Rapid Spin let Delibird function as a suicide lead, keeping on top of opposing Stealth Rock users such as Torterra and Clefairy by removing their entry hazards. However, Delibird is quite susceptible to Taunt users like Qwilfish and Alolan Persian, while Jellicent spinblocks effectively versus Delibird due to its resistance to Ice-type moves, great special bulk, and access to Recover.

Stantler.overview: There's no reason to use Stantler over other Normal-types, particularly Dodrio and Stoutland. Intimidate is nice, and it does have some decent coverage and priority options, but its lack of bulk, Speed or even decent power means it fails to carve a niche for itself in PU.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: This set attempts to deal as much damage as possible and revenge kill weakened Pokemon with Sucker Punch, with Intimidate helping against physical attackers. Unfortunately, Stantler's lack of bulk, Speed or Swords Dance means it's completely outclassed by Stoutland, Dodrio, and Kangaskhan as an offensive Normal-type. Stantler is also fairly weak, as most of the damage it does comes from hitting foes super effectively with its coverage, with the exception of its decently powerful STAB Double-Edge. Finally, Stantler is worn down quite easily with the combination of Life Orb and Double-Edge recoil.

Smeargle.overview: Smeargle is a satisfactory lead Pokemon in the tier due to its access to almost all moves, including useful support moves such as Spore, Sticky Web, and Stealth Rock. The combination of Spore and Nuzzle makes Smeargle very difficult to check without either something being crippled or entry hazards being set. Smeargle's Speed tier is also decent, allowing it to outpace common Stealth Rock setters such as Aurorus and Golurk, although it still is slower than a large part of the metagame, including two other Sticky Web setters, Masquerain and Leavanny. Smeargle's pitiful offensive and defensive stats prevent it from performing any roles outside of a suicide lead. This, in turn, makes it only usable on hyper offensive playstyles, as it is not bulky enough for any other roles and is almost useless once its Focus Sash has been broken. Due to its reliance on status moves, Smeargle is very susceptible to Taunt from Pokemon like Floatzel and Skuntank and is completely shut down by them unless carrying Magic Coat. It also faces competition from Leavanny and Masquerain, which are faster and have actual offensive pressure. However, Smeargle has a much better support movepool, including access to Spore and Stealth Rock. Competition from Shuckle is also detrimental, as, even though Smeargle does have access to Spore and Magic Coat, Shuckle has fantastic defenses alongside Sturdy, meaning it can function on more defensive teams while also not fearing Taunt as much, thanks to Mental Herb.
Smeargle.comments:
Other Options

Explosion, Memento, and Parting Shot are options in the last moveslot, although Nuzzle is generally more beneficial for Smeargle's team and Taunt can prevent opposing entry hazards, among other things. Explosion has the benefit of preventing entry hazard removal by foes like Hitmonchan and Adamant Skuntank, while Memento and Parting Shot weaken the foe and bring in a teammate relatively unscathed. Smeargle can run an offensive set with Belly Drum, although it requires an entire team dedicated to support it and is weak even at +6. Z-Geomancy and Geomancy + Power Herb are options for offensive sets that look good on paper but share similar difficulties with the aforementioned set. Destiny Bond gives Smeargle the opportunity to take down the opponent if they KO it, but Smeargle often prefers the utility its other moves offer. Spikes and Toxic Spikes give Smeargle another way of stacking hazards, but the loss of Taunt, Nuzzle, or Magic Coat makes Smeargle less effective as a suicide lead.

Checks and Counters

Taunt: Taunt is the most intimidating thing for Smeargle to face, as Pokemon like Lycanroc and Skuntank completely stop Smeargle in its tracks, unless it has access to Magic Coat and predicts correctly. They do have to be wary of Nuzzle crippling them, however.

Faster Pokemon: Although Smeargle is often able to get off at least one entry hazard, faster Pokemon such as Cryogonal and Kabutops can put an immense amount of pressure on it with Rapid Spin. Both Choice Scarf Abomasnow and Aurorus only let Smeargle set one entry hazard thanks to hail damage + Blizzard KOing it. Fake Out Kangaskhan is also able to stop Smeargle from setting up.

Flying-types and Levitate Users: Although not a direct threat to Smeargle, Flying-types and Levitate users like Swanna and Rotom-F ignore the Speed drop caused by Sticky Web and are also capable of removing Sticky Web from the field with Defog.

sets.name: Sticky Web Lead
sets.description:
Moves

Sticky Web is Smeargle's main utility, allowing its slower teammates to outpace usually faster grounded Pokemon. Stealth Rock can help break foes' Focus Sash and Sturdy as well as break them down for teammates to have an easier time cleaning. Spore allows Smeargle to put foes to sleep, ensuring that it can use one, if not both, of its entry hazards. Spore can also allow teammates to switch in freely and even set up. Nuzzle prevents Smeargle from being completely immobilized by Taunt and can paralyze both Pokemon immune to Spore, such as Sap Sipper Drampa and Grass-types, and faster foes like Floatzel. Taunt is another utility move that can prevent slower Pokemon, like Clefairy and Ferroseed, from using status moves, especially shutting down opposing entry hazard setters, although it forces Smeargle to Struggle if Taunted, since it would have no attacking moves. Magic Coat is an alternative fourth move that allows Smeargle to bounce back Taunt from users like Skuntank, which would otherwise completely shut it down bar fearing the paralysis from Nuzzle.

Set Details

The given HP investment helps Smeargle's overall bulk, although it's almost worthless due to its abysmal defensive stats, still being 2HKOed by almost every Pokemon in the tier. Focus Sash allows Smeargle to take any single hit and ensures it will be able to use one of its utility moves before fainting. Own Tempo is the best ability that Smeargle can run, since it prevents potential confusion, although it is not very useful in most situations.

Usage Tips

Due to its lackluster offensive and defensive presence, Smeargle is used solely as a suicide lead, getting up entry hazards to support its teammates. Smeargle should almost always prioritize Sticky Web over Stealth Rock, as the former supports the hyper offensive teams that it's usually found on better. This is especially true against Choice Scarf users like Abomasnow and Aurorus, which outspeed Smeargle and knock it out with a combination of Blizzard and hail damage. In order to do this, Smeargle should use Spore on opposing Pokemon to get up as many hazards as it can and cripple the target. Alternatively, Nuzzle should be used against threatening Pokemon that are immune to Spore or can be revenge killed by a partner if slowed. Nuzzle can also be useful later in the game versus setup sweepers like Floatzel and Lycanroc, if Smeargle's Focus Sash is kept intact from earlier, preventing them from sweeping. Taunt users like Sableye and Skuntank should be looked out for, as they completely shut down and make Smeargle useless during the early game. This prompts either another lead to be used or a mind game to be played with Magic Coat against said Pokemon. Based on certain matchups, Sticky Web has no real use if the opposing team is slower than yours already, such as playing against Trick Room or stall teams, meaning that Stealth Rock or Taunt should be used instead.

Team Options

Since Smeargle can only function as a suicide lead effectively, it is designed to support offensive teams. Slower, strong attackers like Jellicent, Abomasnow, and Stoutland all appreciate the Speed drop Sticky Web inflicts on grounded foes, allowing them to outspeed and deal with usually standard checks like Skuntank, Simisear, and Kangaskhan that would otherwise outspeed and either severely weaken or KO them. Defiant and Contrary users such as Primeape and Lurantis are almost essential on Sticky Web teams, as the ability to punish Defog with a +2 boost in Attack or a +1 boost in Evasion makes the opponent extremely cautious of trying to remove entry hazards, especially in the case of Choice Scarf Primeape, which can capitalize on its high Speed stat along with its Attack boost to dismantle other offensive teams with ease. The U-turn utility that Primeape offers is also invaluable, as hyper offensive teams rarely want to directly switch into a foe's attacks due to their frail structure, and it allows these types of teams to keep momentum. Spinblockers such as Oricorio-G and Jellicent prevent Rapid Spin users, such as Hitmonchan and Kabutops, from removing your hazards and pressure them with either powerful attacks or status. Both also support Sticky Web teams differently, with Oricorio-G being able to benefit from the Speed drop to sweep more easily with Calm Mind and Supersonic Skystrike, and with Jellicent taking advantage of the speed drop to bypass Pursuit users such as Skuntank and Stoutland while abusing the likes of Choice Scarf Primeape locked into Close Combat. Oricorio-G and Jellicent are also able to grab momentum no matter whether the opponent predicts incorrectly and goes for Rapid Spin or attacks and KOes them, as this allows another teammate to come in while hazards are left intact. Oricorio-G can also be used for its fantastic matchup against Trick Room teams, being capable of using Substitute and setting up on the most common lead setter, Carbink. Setup sweepers like Carracosta and Alolan Raichu are able to use the Speed reduction to get free setup turns and sweep without as much fear of being revenge killed by Choice Scarf users like Primeape. Torterra is able to focus on setting up Swords Dance over Agility in some matchups, as it doesn't have to worry too much about its middling Speed and being revenge killed by foes such as Choice Specs Aurorus, while Alolan Raichu can get free boosts against more balance-oriented teams. Spore support from Smeargle can also give the aforementioned setup sweepers free turns.

Combusken.overview: Access to the fantastic ability Speed Boost gives Combusken a solid niche in PU, allowing it to reliably clean opposing teams late-game and, in combination with Swords Dance, break through Pokemon such as Carbink that serve as common checks to other offensive Fire-types like Simisear and Turtonator. Its Speed boosts also allow it to punish teams reliant on traditional revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Primeape and Alolan Sandslash to deal with other Fire-types like Simisear for sacrificing Pokemon to bring their revenge killer in safely. Combusken can run both physical and special sets that can break through each other's checks such as Gurdurr for the former and Lanturn for the latter. A near-unresisted STAB combination also makes it a reliable late-game cleaner, provided its main counter in Jellicent is removed. However, Combusken faces fierce competition as an offensive Fire-type from Simisear, as the latter's greater base Speed and Special Attack allow it to more immediately threaten opposing teams, and, importantly, its access to Grass Knot allows it to reliably break through one of Combusken's hardest counters in Jellicent. Furthermore, Combusken is held back by its low Speed, which leaves it outsped by common Choice Scarf users such as Primeape and Dodrio even after two Speed boosts. This fact coupled with Combusken's poor bulk also forces it to often use Protect first against faster Pokemon that can cripple or OHKO it such as Alolan Sandslash and Aurorus, potentially offering free switches to checks such as Lanturn and Eelektross. It also limits Combusken's ability to switch into resisted attacks or aggressively double switch in, which leaves it with limited setup opportunities compared to bulkier setup sweepers such as Gurdurr and Carracosta that offer some defensive utility and leaves it more vulnerable to being revenge killed by priority users such as Hitmonchan, Lycanroc, and Gurdurr.
Combusken.comments:
Other Options

Flamethrower can be run over Fire Blast for a more accurate Fire-type STAB attack to more reliably clean late-game and poison stall foes more easily thanks to its higher PP. The lower damage output can cause Combusken to struggle to claim KOs, however, such as the 2HKO on Silvally-Fairy after Stealth Rock. Hidden Power Ice is an option instead of Hidden Power Electric that allows Combusken to hit Altaria super effectively; however, this provides little coverage compared to Hidden Power Electric otherwise, not to mention specially defensive Altaria is not 2HKOed unless Stealth Rock is up. Furthermore, Altaria is a lot less common than Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Jellicent. Thunder Punch is an option on Swords Dance variants that allows Combusken to threaten Jellicent and Qwilfish without them being significantly weakened or removed first, but this prevents Combusken from running Protect, which will make it harder to accrue safe Speed boosts.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Certain Water-type Pokemon such as Jellicent and Qwilfish resist Combusken's STAB combination. Defensive Jellicent sets in particular are capable of walling all Combusken sets unless Toxic Spikes are present. Qwilfish can greatly threaten Swords Dance Combusken sets, but it must watch out for Hidden Power Electric from special attacking sets, which can 2HKO it. Gastrodon can also wall special Combusken sets and can check Swords Dance sets not running Fightinium Z. Assault Vest Lanturn can also be problematic for special sets, as Focus Blast is only a 4HKO, while Lanturn can OHKO Combusken in return with Scald.

Faster Pokemon: Despite its ability, Combusken's low Speed enables Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Dodrio and Primeape to outspeed and revenge kill it even after two Speed boosts. Priority users such as Carracosta, Floatzel, and Hitmonchan are also capable of revenge killing Combusken, though Hitmonchan needs some chip damage from entry hazards or Combusken setting Substitutes.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Specially defensive Pokemon such as Clefairy, Carbink, and Altaria are capable of walling Combusken's special attacking set, even with Toxic Spikes present provided Carbink has Rest, with the former two also using it as setup fodder.

sets.name: Specially Offensive
sets.description:
Moves

Hidden Power Electric allows Combusken to OHKO Swanna and 2HKO Qwilfish, which both resist its STAB moves. Substitute can be run instead to allow Combusken to punish switches and protect itself from Pokemon such as Dodrio and Carracosta that would otherwise revenge kill it, gain extra Speed boosts, and stall poisoned Pokemon. Protect allows Combusken to get a free Speed boost and scout Choice item Pokemon such as Primeape, Dodrio, and Aurorus.

Set Details

Firium Z lets Combusken OHKO Oricorio-E with Inferno Overdrive after Stealth Rock damage; furthermore, Inferno Overdrive has a high chance to OHKO Skuntank and Alolan Raichu and hits targets such as Mudsdale and Musharna that would otherwise force Combusken out for as much damage as possible, KOing both after Fire Blast and Stealth Rock. Fightinium Z is an alternative that allows Combusken to OHKO Regirock and Drampa with All-Out Pummeling, do greater damage to Pokemon such as Lanturn, and bypass Focus Blast's poor accuracy once. Leftovers is an option that allows Combusken to set up more Substitutes while staying out of range of priority users such as Gurdurr and Lycanroc more easily; however, this should only be run on sets featuring Substitute, as three attacks sets benefit more from the extra damage Z-Crystals offer. Life Orb is an option on teams not using Toxic Spikes if another Pokemon is holding a Z-Crystal, helping to make up for Combusken's average damage output, such as offering it a high chance to OHKO Regirock with Focus Blast. The chip damage makes Combusken have a harder time staying out of range of priority attacks such as Lycanroc's Accelerock, however.

Usage Tips

Combusken should avoid taking too much chip damage from entry hazards and status where possible and should mainly be brought in via safe switches and aggressive double switches so it can stay out of range of priority attacks such as Gurdurr's Mach Punch and Lycanroc's Accelerock to reliably clean late-game. Combusken can also be used early- to mid-game to immediately pressure teams and take advantage of switches to counters such as Jellicent with appropriate double switches. If running Substitute, Combusken can use it to punish switches it forces against Pokemon such as Ferroseed, Cryogonal, Tangela, Alolan Sandslash, and Victreebel, although it must be careful when doing this against the latter two, as they can outspeed and either cripple or KO Combusken if they predict it to use Substitute. Against more offensive teams, Substitute can help ease prediction and make Combusken harder to revenge kill while helping it outspeed Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Dodrio and Primeape that it needs multiple Speed boosts for. Combusken should, however, be wary of setting up too many Substitutes when counters such as Carbink and Altaria are present, especially when running a Z-Crystal instead of Leftovers, so it has enough HP to take priority attacks or keep setting up Substitutes later in the match. If a teammate is running Toxic Spikes, Combusken can very effectively poison stall with Substitute + Protect, as Speed Boost allows it to nearly always set up Substitutes first. In particular, this allows Combusken to pressure Jellicent a lot more, forcing it to take poison damage while attempting to force Combusken out with Taunt.

Team Options

Combusken fits on bulky offense and balance teams that desire a late-game cleaner and on Toxic Spikes teams where it can also function as a poison staller. Pivots such as Lanturn, Eelektross, and Silvally-Fairy can help bring Combusken in on Pokemon that it can force out such as Victreebel, Cryogonal, and Regirock, offering it free opportunities to gain Speed boosts, set Substitutes, or break the enemy team. Lanturn and Eelektross in particular can help pressure Jellicent, and Lanturn can also help to spread poison onto Pokemon that annoy Combusken such as Jellicent, Eelektross, and opposing Lanturn and clear Combusken of status with Heal Bell. Pokemon that can help deal with Jellicent in particular are incredibly useful, especially when you're not running it alongside Toxic Spikes. Victreebel can consistently switch into and pressure defensive Jellicent while switching into and helping break other Pokemon such as Gurdurr and Mudsdale that can force Combusken out when at high HP, as well as help break through Carbink and Clefairy, which can otherwise wall Combusken. Pokemon such as Choice Band Stoutland and Absol are capable of Pursuit trapping Jellicent and can help pressure the special walls that Combusken dislikes, such as Lanturn, Eelektross, and Musharna. Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Aurorus, Taunt Oricorio-E, Golurk, and Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy can also help to break through specially defensive Pokemon such as Altaria, Carbink, and Clefairy that can consistently wall Combusken, as well as break holes in the enemy team for Combusken to reliably clean late-game.

Toxic Spikes support from Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Roselia can help Combusken break through opposing teams via stalling through the combination of Substitute + Protect, allowing it to more easily beat Pokemon such as Assault Vest Lanturn that would otherwise give it a lot of trouble. Roselia is able to consistently pressure Jellicent alongside setting Toxic Spikes, which is helpful in matchups against grounded Poison-types such as Victreebel or against entry hazard removers that Roselia loses to such as Cryogonal, while Qwilfish is able to provide a switch-in to priority users such as Hitmonchan and Gurdurr that could revenge kill Combusken, as well as to Choice Scarf Dodrio, which can outspeed Combusken after multiple Speed boosts. Spinblockers such as Jellicent and Sableye are excellent partners, especially on Toxic Spikes teams, to help deal with Rapid Spin users such as Alolan Sandslash, although they have to be wary of Toxic. Sableye can also offer Knock Off support to aid Combusken in poison stalling foes, while both Pokemon can help check Fighting-types such as Hitmonchan and Primeape and offer Taunt support to pressure entry hazard setters and removers.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Sky Uppercut is Combusken's strongest Fighting-type STAB option versus lighter Pokemon such as Lanturn and Carbink. Low Kick is an alternative that can do more damage versus heavier Pokemon such as Regirock while still retaining the ability to break through Lanturn and Carbink alongside Fightinium Z.

Set Details

Firium Z allows Combusken to OHKO Mudsdale and Choice Specs Jellicent with +2 Inferno Overdrive after Stealth Rock damage, deal heavy damage to Gurdurr, and avoid recoil once against high-HP targets such as Musharna to stay out of range of priority attacks. Alternatively, Fightinium Z allows Combusken to OHKO Fire-type checks such as Lanturn and Carbink, the latter after Stealth Rock, with +2 All-Out Pummeling; however, it does less damage versus targets such as Gurdurr and Mudsdale than Inferno Overdrive. Eviolite is an alternative option if another Pokemon is using a Z-Crystal, allowing Combusken to more easily take priority moves such as Gurdurr or Hitmonchan's Mach Punch, take an Earthquake from offensive Alolan Sandslash to risk setting up against it more freely without being KOed on a misprediction, and set up against Victreebel more easily. The lower damage output is very noticeable, however, allowing bulky Pokemon such as Mudsdale to force it out much more easily.

Usage Tips

Due to Combusken's low bulk and tendency to get worn down by entry hazards and Flare Blitz recoil, it should prioritize being brought in safely so it has enough HP to set up when necessary and stay out of range of priority moves from Pokemon such as Gurdurr. Because of this, Combusken should also wait to set up until answers such as defensive Jellicent have been crippled or removed, as it will be unlikely to get multiple setup opportunities; however, if Combusken is unlikely to be able to reliably set up or revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Dodrio are present, it can be used to immediately pressure the opposing team when forcing switches. Combusken should prioritize attempting to set up against Pokemon that cannot threaten it if possible, such as Cryogonal, Audino, and Choice Band Absol locked into Pursuit. However, it can also attempt to set up on Pokemon it can force to switch out, such as Victreebel and Alolan Sandslash, though they are faster and can cripple or KO Combusken if they end up staying in. Combusken can also make use of the fact that its two sets have different checks and counters, allowing it to potentially set up a Swords Dance on a switch-in to its special set, such as Carbink or Lanturn.

Team Options

Pivots such as Eelektross, Rotom-F, Lanturn, and Primeape are able to provide Combusken with safe switches into Pokemon such as Audino, Cryogonal, and Victreebel to get free setup opportunities. In particular, Eelektross can help pressure Jellicent and Mudsdale, while Rotom-F can also offer Defog support and help pressure Jellicent, Carracosta, and Qwilfish. Silvally-Fairy is another option that can run a Swords Dance set to pressure physically defensive Pokemon such as Gurdurr and Mudsdale or provide Defog support. Regirock and Torterra are good choices for Stealth Rock setters to pair with Combusken, as the former provides a good switch-in to Choice Scarf Dodrio, which can outspeed and revenge kill Combusken easily, while the latter can help pressure Mudsdale and Jellicent. In return, Torterra greatly appreciates Combusken switching into and pressuring Cryogonal. Victreebel is a particularly good partner for Swords Dance Combusken, as it is able to switch into and pressure several Combusken checks such as Mudsdale, Jellicent, Lanturn, and Gurdurr. In return, Combusken can help pressure Cryogonal. Musharna can provide wallbreaking support with Future Sight to pressure switch-ins to Combusken such as Gurdurr and Jellicent. It can also allow Combusken a second opportunity to sweep and provide it with a free switch in to set up with Swords Dance thanks to Healing Wish. In return, Combusken can help pressure Dark-types such as Skuntank and Alolan Persian. Pursuit trappers such as Choice Band Absol, Skuntank, and Stoutland can remove one of Combusken's best answers in Jellicent. Absol and Stoutland can also wear down opposing teams for Combusken to clean more easily late-game, especially their shared switch-ins with Combusken such as Gurdurr and Mudsdale.

Mightyena.overview: Subpar stats across the board leave Mightyena completely outclassed by Absol and Alolan Raticate, which sport far higher Attack stats and better Speed tiers. The aforementioned Pokemon also have access to Swords Dance and possess a more useful Dark-type STAB move in Knock Off. Mightyena's niche lies in attempting to revenge kill opposing Pokemon to get Attack boosts from Moxie, but it does not do its job properly because it ends up being too weak to kill anything and it lacks the defenses to stay in for long periods of time.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: This set attempts to hit as hard as possible in order to revenge kill weakened Pokemon to achieve Moxie boosts, utilizing its STAB priority and coverage to attempt to beat checks. Unfortunately, Mightyena is outsped by a lot of offensive Pokemon and relies too much on Sucker Punch as an attacking move, being unable to use its good coverage. Alolan Raticate, for example, is a much better Pokemon to use because it has Swords Dance, Hustle, Normal-type STAB moves, and a better Speed tier. It also can use a Z-Move so it doesn't need to beat opposing Pokemon to become an immediate threat. It is advised to use Alolan Raticate and Absol as offensive Dark-type Pokemon over Mightyena.

Beautifly.overview: Beautifly is an especially atrocious Pokemon. It may have access to Quiver Dance, but its horrendous bulk, subpar Speed, bad defensive and offensive typing, 4x Stealth Rock weakness, and lack of useful abilities or definable niche make it impossible to justify using over Bellossom thanks to its better stats overall and its ability to set up using Strength Sap.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: Beautifly can attempt to sweep with Quiver Dance. However, its subpar stats, shallow movepool, bad defensive typing, and lack of any definable niche over other Quiver Dance sweepers make it an abysmal option in general.

Dustox.overview: With its two 4x resistances to Grass and Fighting, an immunity to Toxic, and access to both Quiver Dance and Iron Defense, Dustox can slowly turn into a setup sweeper. However, its typing brings forth several notable weaknesses, most notably to Fire, Flying, and Rock, that allow Dustox to be overcome by threats such as Simisear, Dodrio, and Aggron. Dustox also faces fierce competition from Bellossom as a bulky Quiver Dance sweeper, as Bellossom has better offensive stats as well as Strength Sap to restore its health while lowering the target's Attack.

sets.name: Quiver Dance + Iron Defense
sets.description: Dustox can use its combination of Quiver Dance + Iron Defense + Roost to set up on Pokemon such as non-Stone Edge Hitmonchan. Once Dustox has obtained enough boosts, it can theoretically become a bulky sweeper; however, odds are Dustox will not be given such a chance to set up all the way due to its mediocre defensive stats, proving how much better Bellossom is as a bulky Quiver Dance sweeper despite Dustox's niches such as Shield Dust and its immunity to Toxic.

Ludicolo.overview: Ludicolo is a fearsome sweeper in the PU metagame by virtue of its access to Swift Swim, which allows it to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame under rain. Furthermore, a decent Special Attack stat in tandem with a good STAB combination and nearly unresisted coverage allows it to adequately pressure offensive and defensive teams alike, and a fairly decent defensive typing and good special bulk allow it to tank some hits and find easy opportunities to set up on Pokemon like Floatzel and Lanturn. Unfortunately, Ludicolo is hindered by its poor Defense and Speed stats, as they can complicate setup and leave it susceptible to common threats in Skuntank, Primeape, and Scyther. It also suffers from the prevalence of Pokemon that can tank a hit in the rain and cripple or KO it in return, including Roselia and Assault Vest Hitmonchan. Lastly, Ludicolo's physical frailty can leave it prone to getting revenge killed by strong priority users, including Absol, Alolan Raticate, and especially Kangaskhan, which can stall out rain turns with Fake Out.
Ludicolo.comments:
Other Options

Surf is an option for consistent and reliable damage over the less accurate Hydro Pump, though the loss in power is quite notable. Scald sacrifices power for better accuracy than Hydro Pump and a chance to burn that Surf doesn't have. However, given that Ludicolo looks to power through most foes, this often isn't a good option. Ludicolo can use Z-Crystals like Grassium Z and Icium Z to lure in and remove specific threats, but this cuts into the power its other attacks would have with a Life Orb, which is notably more valuable. Waterium Z is also a nice option due to its insane power in the rain, though it often isn't preferred for similar reasons. A Substitute + Leech Seed set can be used due to Ludicolo's decent defensive typing, though its poor physical bulk makes this hard to pull off.

Checks and Counters

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Various specially bulky Pokemon are capable of tanking Ludicolo's attacks easily due to its only decent Special Attack. Examples include Roselia and Type: Null.

Bulky Attackers: Due to Ludicolo's poor bulk overall, it is heavily pressured by strong offensive Pokemon that it fails to KO, including Assault Vest Hitmonchan.

Strong Priority: Strong priority attacks from Spiritomb and Skuntank can heavily dent Ludicolo and even revenge kill it after it's been whittled down some. Kangaskhan's priority attacks are particularly troublesome, as with Fake Out, it can damage Ludicolo while burning rain turns.

Abomasnow and Aurorus: By virtue of Snow Warning, Abomasnow and Aurorus can disrupt Ludicolo's rain. Abomasnow can tank any hit while pressuring Ludicolo with powerful STAB attacks, while Choice Scarf Aurorus can outspeed and OHKO Ludicolo with Freeze-Dry.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Moves

Rain Dance is mandatory for doubling Ludicolo's Speed and beginning a sweep, and it also supports some of Ludicolo's other teammates on dedicated rain teams. Hydro Pump is a powerful STAB attack that hits obscenely hard in the rain, OHKOing or 2HKOing the majority of neutral targets. Giga Drain allows Ludicolo to recover its health and is also useful for hitting Water-types such as Gastrodon and Lanturn. Energy Ball is an option over Giga Drain for its greater power, notably damaging the likes of Primeape and Swanna more reliably. Ice Beam hits the Grass- and Dragon-types that otherwise wall Ludicolo, including Lurantis, Victreebel, and Drampa. Focus Blast is an option over Rain Dance in order to hit Pokemon like Type: Null and Cradily harder, but it is unreliable and makes Ludicolo reliant on teammates to set up rain.

Set Details

Full investment in both Special Attack and Speed maximizes Ludicolo's offensive presence. 29 IVs are invested in HP to minimize damage taken from Life Orb. A Modest nature is used to maximize Ludicolo's damage output, but Timid is also an option to outspeed faster Choice Scarf users such as Manectric and Scyther. Life Orb puts even more power behind Ludicolo's attacks, allowing it to secure KOs such as the 2HKO on Lanturn with Giga Drain.

Usage Tips

Ludicolo should look to set up against Pokemon that can't adequately damage it, like Lanturn and Choice-locked Floatzel, or against Pokemon that it forces out, like Regirock and Gastrodon. It is also important to note that when not on a full rain team Ludicolo should be preserved for the late-game and rarely used early on, as it has an easier time sweeping once checks and counters are weakened. It can, however, be used as a late-game breaker if need be. If Ludicolo is up against a slower foe that is within range of a KO and isn't likely to switch out, it should usually just use an attack to revenge kill the opposing Pokemon so as not to take any damage. Lastly, Ludicolo should look for the opposing team to be generally weakened to begin its sweep, as while its good coverage lets it cover most of the metagame on its own, its middling power can compromise its sweeping chances.

Team Options

On dedicated rain teams, rain setters like Liepard and Volbeat are important teammates for Ludicolo. Both of them also have access to U-turn, which allows them to safely bring Ludicolo into play. Other pivots, such as Alolan Raichu and Primeape, can also safely bring Ludicolo into battle. Slow pivots like Lanturn and Probopass are particularly useful for minimizing its chances of taking damage. Other Swift Swim users, such as Kabutops and Poliwrath, can fit onto rain teams with Ludicolo and appreciate its ability to break past their common checks, like Gastrodon. Entry hazard support from the likes of Golurk and Mudsdale can aid Ludicolo in punishing its switches and breaking past foes more easily in general. Powerful physical attackers like Stoutland, Gurdurr, and Zangoose adequately pressure the specially defensive Pokemon that Ludicolo struggles to break past, like Assault Vest Hitmonchan and Type: Null, while in return it can pressure the physically defensive Pokemon they're troubled with themselves, like Regirock.

Shiftry.overview: Shiftry is an offensive force to be reckoned with as a result of its solid offensive typing, decent mixed attacking stats, and strong STAB options such as Knock Off, Leaf Storm, Seed Bomb, and Sucker Punch. Because of its mixed coverage, Shiftry manages to stand apart from other Dark- and Grass-types in the tier and is a massive threat to teams that are overly reliant on Pokemon such as Gurdurr, Mudsdale, and Regirock to check physical attackers. Shiftry becomes even more threatening under sun because of its ability Chlorophyll doubling its Speed, which allows it to also threaten opposing sun teams. It can also function well as an offensive user of Defog because its typing gives it the ability to threaten common entry hazard setters such as Mudsdale, Golurk and Regirock, allowing it to clear the field of entry hazards on the turn that they switch out. However, its great offensive typing curses it with weaknesses to common attack typings such as Fire, Flying, Poison, and Ice, and its poor bulk doesn't make matters much better. Although its Speed is far from terrible, Shiftry is outsped by common offensive Pokemon such as Primeape and Silvally-Fairy, and its main method of mitigating this in Sucker Punch isn't very reliable due to how it can be taken advantage of. Finally, as a purely physical wallbreaker, Shiftry faces competition from other Dark-types in the tier such as Absol and Alolan Raticate, both of which, while slower, are stronger.
Shiftry.comments:
Other Options

A purely specially offensive or specially biased mixed set is an option, and Shiftry even has access to Nasty Plot to boost the power of those moves. Solar Beam can be used over Leaf Storm on the mixed set if Shiftry is on a sun team so that Shiftry has a more spammable Grass-type STAB attack that doesn't drop its Special Attack; however, it's fairly useless outside of sun, and it's less strong than Leaf Storm. Pickpocket can be used on the Choice Scarf set to steal the opposing Pokemon's item if Shiftry loses its Choice Scarf, which can be useful for crippling defensive Pokemon in the event that Shiftry takes a Knock Off. A Lum Berry can be used on the Swords Dance sets to let Shiftry ignore a status condition once and have a slightly easier time setting up as a result. It's noticeably weaker without the boost from Black Glasses or a Life Orb, though. Synthesis gives Shiftry a form of reliable recovery, taking advantage of the switches it can force, but it usually prefers having a move to hit Alolan Sandslash or remove entry hazards as the final move on the mixed set, and it struggles to find room for Synthesis on any other set. Furthermore, Shiftry really doesn't need recovery, as its main priority should be breaking as much as it can. Grassium Z can be used on the Swords Dance set to turn Seed Bomb into Bloom Doom, which can be nice for luring Pokemon like Skuntank and taking them out after a Swords Dance boost. Normalium Z can be used on non-Choice Scarf sets with Explosion to still hit hard and not lose Shiftry in the process. It should be noted that Breakneck Blitz is slightly less strong than Explosion, and this takes away from the surprise factor that Explosion has. Flyinium Z can be used with Hurricane to lure and KO Gurdurr and Hitmonchan, and Shiftry can do this easier with Nasty Plot.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Muk and Skuntank can all deal heavy damage to Shiftry with their respective Poison-type STAB moves and don't mind Knock Off much, and Skuntank even resists both of Shiftry's STAB types. They do have to watch out for Explosion, however, boosted in power or not.

Fighting-types: Combusken, Gurdurr, Hitmonchan, and Primeape all resist Sucker Punch and force Shiftry out due to either outspeeding it or having Mach Punch; however, none of them except for Combusken and Hitmonchan want to be brought in on Leaf Storm, Gurdurr hates losing its Eviolite to Knock Off, and none of them wants to take an Explosion. Combusken can shield itself from Explosion and obtain a Speed boost with Protect, and it resists both of Shiftry's STAB types. Primeape can generate momentum for its team by using U-turn on the turn Shiftry switches.

Faster Pokemon: Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Primeape, Rotom-F, and Pinsir all have the power to OHKO Shiftry due to its frailty. The Choice Scarf set does deal with almost all of them, though, and when facing other sets, they have to take a Sucker Punch before they get to attack Shiftry.

Priority: As a result of Shiftry's frailty, priority often leaves dents in it or KOs it with enough prior damage. Pokemon like Abomasnow, Gurdurr, Hitmonchan, Kangaskhan, and Zangoose all threaten Shiftry with either super effective or strong neutral priority moves.

sets.name: Mixed Life Orb
sets.description:
Moves

Knock Off is one of Shiftry's two Dark-type STAB moves, and on top of hitting a lot of Pokemon that resist Leaf Storm fairly hard, it removes the opposing Pokemon's item. This effectively cripples Pokemon reliant on their Assault Vest or Eviolite to check Shiftry and its teammates, like Eelektross, Hitmonchan, and Ferroseed. Sucker Punch is the second of Shiftry's Dark-type STAB moves. It can be used to score KOs on faster but frailer Pokemon like Alolan Raichu or Floatzel after they take a bit of damage beforehand. Do keep in mind, however, that it fails if the foe doesn't attack, which can be taken advantage of by Pokemon with reliable recovery like Swanna. Leaf Storm is Shiftry's main Grass-type STAB attack, and it can be used to hit physically defensive Pokemon like Aggron and Mawile harder than its Dark-type moves, which neither of them mind all that much. Defog can be opted for if your team lacks hazard control, which is good for more offensive teams due to the pressure Shiftry puts on common hazard setters like Regirock. Alternatively, Low Kick hits Alolan Sandslash, which could otherwise take advantage of Shiftry. Explosion gives Shiftry access to a one-time physical attack with 250 Base Power at the cost of Shiftry itself. Explosion is Shiftry's best attack against Skuntank, which resists both of Shiftry's STAB types and threatens it with Poison Jab, and Explosion also has the secondary advantage of severely weakening even some of the most physically bulky non-Normal-resistant Pokemon in the tier, such as Gurdurr.

Set Details

Special Attack investment isn't necessary, as even without it, Leaf Storm hits its main targets harder than any of the physical attacks do. A Lonely nature is used to increase Shiftry's attacking power without lowering its Special Attack. A Hasty nature can be used if you wish to outspeed certain neutral-natured Pokemon such as Kangaskhan and Stoutland, though this does cause Shiftry to lose out on certain KOs. Chlorophyll doubles Shiftry's Speed under sun, making it even more threatening on and against sun-based teams. Life Orb strengthens all of Shiftry's attacks, but it comes with the downside of recoil damage.

Usage Tips

Use Knock Off a lot early on, as it's Shiftry's most reliable STAB move and cripples defensive Pokemon like Tangela by removing Eviolite, rendering it unable to check Shiftry as effectively. If you're using Defog on Shiftry, bring it in on entry hazard setters that it threatens like Bronzor and Regirock, and Defog on the turn they switch. Sucker Punch is a great tool for revenge killing, but as mentioned before, it can be exploited by Pokemon that can recover their health or set up such as Swanna and Jynx. Exercise caution when using Explosion, as Shiftry only gets one use at the move, so refrain from using it until Shiftry is no longer required and wants to dish out one last heavy hit. Shiftry is easy to wear down due to Life Orb recoil, entry hazards, and its poor bulk, so not letting it take much or any unnecessary damage is smart, especially if it's the team's only form of entry hazard control.

Team Options

Fire-types like Simisear and Turtonator break through bulkier Grass-types and physical walls like Tangela for Shiftry, while Shiftry provides entry hazard removal for them and combats the Ground-, Rock-, and Water-types that threaten them such as Carbink and Lanturn. Fighting-types like Gurdurr, Hitmonchan, and Primeape place pressure on both physical walls and opposing Dark-types for Shiftry, and it pressures Psychic-types in return. Pokemon that resist Fighting such as Musharna, Swanna, and Qwilfish synergize well defensively with Shiftry, as they handle the Fighting-types that force it out, especially those with Mach Punch like Gurdurr and Hitmonchan. They appreciate how Shiftry deals with Electric- and Psychic-types like Lanturn and Alolan Raichu. Slow users of Volt Switch like Eelektross and Lanturn work to get Shiftry in as safely as possible. Each has its own benefits: Eelektross beats Pokemon like Tangela, while Lanturn can cure Shiftry of status with Heal Bell and can check Fire-types. Entry hazard setters such as Qwilfish and Mudsdale pair well with Shiftry because hazards pressure Fire-types and faster but frailer Pokemon, which can't take Shiftry's moves as well if they are up, particularly Sucker Punch. Shiftry can even keep the entry hazards up with Explosion while either severely weakening the opposing Pokemon or securing a KO. If Shiftry's on a sun team, Sunny Day users like Liepard, Regirock, and Volbeat are definitely important. Fellow sun sweepers like Simisear and Victreebel pair well with it too. Victreebel can absorb Toxic Spikes for Shiftry, which helps it remain around for longer, and Shiftry can put holes in teams and make it easier for the other sun sweepers to finish them off.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Knock Off is Shiftry's main Dark-type STAB move that removes the item of the opposing Pokemon and hits a lot of Pokemon that resist Seed Bomb for neutral damage. Sucker Punch is Shiftry's secondary Dark-type STAB move, and it improves Shiftry's matchup against fast but frail Pokemon such as Alolan Raichu and Dodrio, especially after a Swords Dance. Low Kick is an option over Seed Bomb as it allows it to hit Aggron and Alolan Sandslash harder.

Set Details

An Adamant nature helps to increase Shiftry's power and give it stronger priority, but a Jolly nature can be used to let it outspeed neutral-natured Pokemon like Adamant Skuntank. Chlorophyll doubles Shiftry's Speed under sun, letting it outspeed the entire unboosted metagame as well as some Choice Scarf users like Primeape, which makes it threatening on and against sun teams. Life Orb gives all of Shiftry's moves a bit more power, at the cost of some of its health for every attack. Black Glasses is an alternative that doesn't deal recoil damage to Shiftry and still boosts the power of Knock Off and Sucker Punch, but it doesn't give Seed Bomb a boost in power.

Usage Tips

Using Knock Off a lot early on to weaken checks and remove the items of checks is good for pressuring them and making them unable to keep Shiftry in check. Finding opportunities to set up a Swords Dance on Pokemon that Shiftry forces out like Bronzor, Gastrodon, or Sableye is ideal due to their passivity. Once Shiftry manages to use Swords Dance, it should weaken and break as much of the opposing team as it can, paving the way for its teammates to and clean up. Sucker Punch allows Shiftry to check faster but frailer Pokemon as well as setup sweepers. None of them appreciate taking a Sucker Punch, especially if Shiftry uses Swords Dance beforehand. Shiftry is really frail and doesn't like taking even resisted hits when it doesn't have to, so be sure to keep Shiftry as healthy as possible when attempting to set up.

Team Options

This set has problems with physical walls due to a lack of mixed coverage, so good partners are Pokemon such as Simisear and Drampa that can severely weaken or KO physically defensive walls like Tangela and Alolan Persian. Primeape greatly appreciates Shiftry's ability to pressure Ghost-types like Sableye and Jellicent, and in return gives Shiftry set-up opportunities with U-turn. Similarly, Hitmonchan is able to check Ice- and Fire-types like Aurorus and Simisear for Shiftry, and can provide entry hazard removal to aid Shiftry in remaining alive for as long as it can. Skuntank resists both of Shiftry's STAB moves, so Ground- and Steel-types that can handle it like Mudsdale and Aggron are beneficial. Mudsdale in particular is notable because of its ability to check Fighting-types like Primeape, Hitmonchan and Gurdurr that Shiftry struggles with. Other Pokemon that check Fighting-types and can tank Fighting-type moves for Shiftry such as Silvally-Fairy, Musharna, Oricorio-G, and Swanna make for good partners, and Shiftry helps them in return by removing Eviolite from Pokemon such as Gurdurr, Type: Null and Ferroseed, making them easier to handle. Slower users of Volt Switch and U-turn such as Eelektross, Lanturn and Type: Null make for good partners due to their ability to get Shiftry in on some of the more passive Pokemon they tend to bait in, like Audino, opposing non-Ice Beam Lanturn, and Sableye, all of which Shiftry takes advantage of and sets up on. Shiftry likes entry hazards being up on the opposing side so that its moves are even harder to come in on, especially after a Swords Dance, so hazard setters like Metang and Qwilfish pair well with it. If Shiftry is being used on a sun team, Sunny Day users like Liepard, Regirock, and Volbeat alongside other sun sweepers are necessary. Sun sweepers like Victreebel and Leafeon benefit from Shiftry's presence because they are often able to weaken their shared checks, with one allowing the other to clean up as a result.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Knock Off is Shiftry's most reliable physical STAB attack, hits Pokemon like Jynx and Oricorio-G for super effective damage, and removes the items of the opposing Pokemon, which is good for crippling defensive Pokemon. Rock Slide hits Fire- and Flying-types like Simisear and Swanna for super effective damage. Low Kick allows it to hit Aggron and Alolan Sandslash harder than anything else. Alternatively, Explosion is used for taking a huge portion of health from Pokemon that Shiftry lures in, like Skuntank and Gurdurr, as well as for generating momentum. Defog can also be used as a means of emergency hazard control in order to have a better matchup versus entry hazard stacking teams.

Set Details

Choice Scarf allows Shiftry to outspeed Pokemon like Jynx, Oricorio-G, and Swanna, even with an Adamant nature, which lets Shiftry hit as hard as possible. Chlorophyll doubles Shiftry's Speed under sun, making sure Shiftry outspeeds every opposing Chlorophyll user under it.

Usage Tips

Using Knock Off a lot early on is smart, as it keeps opponents from immediately suspecting Shiftry's set. Refrain from using Rock Slide or otherwise making it obvious that you're using a Choice Scarf set until need be, as this will make the set ineffective at luring in faster threats. This set isn't very common in comparison to the other two, so take advantage of how it's unexpected by luring in the faster Pokemon that normally force Shiftry out like Simisear and Skuntank and KOing them. Shiftry serves as a solid revenge killer, as well, due to its lack of reliance on Sucker Punch for picking things off, so take advantage of Choice Scarf by taking down normally faster Pokemon like Alolan Raichu and Oricorio-G. Explosion still packs a punch despite the lack of a Life Orb boost, so use it to deal heavy damage to Pokemon like Skuntank and weakened physical walls.

Team Options

Special wallbreakers like Aurorus, Drampa, and Haunter place pressure on Pokemon that Shiftry struggles with breaking, such as bulky Grass-resistant Pokemon like Tangela, Oricorio-G, and Mawile. In return, Shiftry cripples their switch-ins with Knock Off and can weaken them with Explosion, making them easier to KO. Fighting-types like Primeape appreciate Shiftry luring in and beating Flying-types and keeping out Ghost- and Psychic-types, and they beat the Dark-types that give it trouble like Alolan Raticate and Skuntank. Pokemon such as Silvally-Fairy and Musharna take on opposing Fighting-types such as Hitmonchan, while Shiftry's Explosion weakens or removes Dark- and Poison-types for them. Entry hazard setters like Ferroseed and Qwilfish make Shiftry's moves even harder to switch into, and Shiftry can keep the hazards up for longer by preventing Defog and Rapid Spin with Explosion. Qwilfish also acts as a Fighting-type check for Shiftry. Checks to Fire-types are important, as while Shiftry does outspeed them and possess good options for them, it prefers to have something to fall back on should it get locked into Leaf Blade, so Pokemon like Assault Vest Hitmonchan and Lanturn make for good partners. Checks to Ice-types are important for the same reason, so Shiftry appreciates Pokemon such as Lycanroc, Assault Vest Crabominable, and Alolan Sandslash. Shiftry also handles some of their collective weaknesses to typings like Ground, Psychic and Water. Pokemon that can easily bluff Choice Scarf sets such as Z-Lovely Kiss Jynx and Primeape pair well with Shiftry, preventing any suspicion in regard to Shiftry's set.

Masquerain.overview: Masquerain sports rare access to both Sticky Web and Quiver Dance, which gives it much better offensive presence than other Sticky Web leads such as Smeargle. Masquerain's solid coverage also allows it to threaten opposing entry hazard setters such as Mudsdale, as well as Pokemon such as Hitmonchan which give other Sticky Web leads a hard time. However, Masquerain still faces a lot of competition from other Sticky Web setters such as Leavanny and Smeargle due to Leavanny's better Speed and access to valuable support options in Knock Off and Magic Coat and Smeargle's access to more support options such as Spikes, Spore, and Stealth Rock. As a result of Masquerain's only decent Speed and offensive presence, it is very susceptible to Taunt from Pokemon such as Skuntank, which isn't a problem for the faster Leavanny because it outspeeds Skuntank. Masquerain also has a difficult time against Defoggers or Rapid Spin users like Swanna and Cryogonal that can get rid of Sticky Web with little to no issue. Masquerain's poor bulk and defensive typing don't grant it many opportunities to switch in, meaning that it can only work efficiently as a lead.
Masquerain.comments:
Other Options

A more offensive set centered around Quiver Dance and making use of Buginium Z or Waterium Z can let Masquerain break through specially defensive foes such as Eelektross and Cryogonal, but it can struggle to find setup opportunities due to its mediocre bulk and its Speed tier leaves it easily revenge killed by fast Choice Scarf users, such as Primeape and Dodrio, even at +1 Speed, limiting its late-game cleaning potential. Roost seems appealing, but Masquerain has trouble finding room for it on either set and much prefers the coverage, and it has trouble recovering lost HP on strong attackers such as Kangaskhan and Stoutland. Scald can be used over Hydro Pump as its chance to burn can come in handily against switch-ins such as Skuntank and Alolan Sandslash, but it is notably weaker and leaves Masquerain more vulnerable to Pokemon like Regirock. Ice Beam can be used to hit Pokemon such as Drampa and Oricorio-G harder, though it has limited use outside of this.

Checks and Counters

Taunt and Encore: Masquerain is incapable of doing much of anything should it be Taunted by Sableye or Skuntank, and none of its moves are particularly desirable to be locked into by Encore from Pokemon like Audino. Oricorio-E and Oricorio-G are especially problematic for Masquerain to face, as besides crippling Masquerain with Taunt, they take little damage from most of its moves and can even copy Quiver Dance boosts due to their ability in Dancer.

Entry Hazard Removal: Common Defoggers such as Swanna, Cryogonal, and Altaria are annoying for Masquerain to deal with, as Masquerain cannot OHKO them depending on its coverage, and they don't have issues either KOing it or stalling it out with Toxic and then Defogging. Although the matchup is tougher for them, spinners such as Alolan Sandslash and Kabutops can be annoying for Masquerain to deal with as well, as they have the ability to threaten Masquerain with their super effective STAB attacks.

Rock-types: Rock-types such as Aurorus, Regirock, and Lycanroc can all KO Masquerain with their respective STAB attacks, even with an Attack drop from Intimidate. Lycanroc can even revenge kill Masquerain after a Quiver Dance with Accelerock, while Aurorus can OHKO Masquerain through its Focus Sash due to Snow Warning. It's worth noting that none of them appreciate taking a +1 Hydro Pump.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Combusken and Simisear have no issues KOing Masquerain with Fire Blast, even if it has +1 Special Defense. Similarly to Rock-types, however, none of them want to take a +1 Hydro Pump.

sets.name: Sticky Web Lead
sets.description:
Moves

Sticky Web, the main reason to use Masquerain, decreases the Speed of all opposing Pokemon upon entry, which is good for supporting Masquerain's teammates. Bug Buzz is Masquerain's main and most powerful STAB move, and it hits Dark-, Grass-, and Psychic-types like Absol, Torterra, and Musharna for super effective damage. Hydro Pump gives Masquerain the ability to threaten not only common users of Stealth Rock such as Mudsdale and Regirock but also Pokemon like Simisear, while Air Slash gives it a secondary STAB option for hitting Fighting-types harder than any of its other moves. Finally, Quiver Dance slightly increases Masquerain's offensive presence and makes it less susceptible to Taunt.

Set Details

Maximum investment in both Speed and Special Attack serves to maximize Masquerain's offensive presence. A Timid nature allows Masquerain to outspeed Pokemon such as neutral-natured Shiftry and Skuntank and gives it an easier time attempting to set up Sticky Web. Focus Sash always allows Masquerain to take one attack from full, which means that Masquerain will almost always successfully set Sticky Web at least once. Intimidate can help Masquerain set up Sticky Web or Quiver Dance against targets like Gurdurr later on should it need to switch out.

Usage Tips

Leading with Masquerain is almost always ideal due to this giving it the best possible chance it can get to set Sticky Web up as soon as possible. Using Quiver Dance afterwards is smart, as this gives it a slightly better matchup against Defoggers, prevents it from becoming setup fodder, and makes it more likely that Sticky Web will remain up. If Masquerain cannot beat a certain Defogger like Swanna, preserving it until the Defogger is removed is ideal, as Masquerain's main priority is setting up Sticky Web and they will render its attempts pointless. This can be difficult, however, due to its poor bulk and 4x weakness to Stealth Rock. Masquerain has to play carefully around Taunt users such as Sableye, as they can prevent it from doing much of anything outside of firing off weak attacks.

Team Options

Masquerain only fits on dedicated Sticky Web teams, so slower setup sweepers and wallbreakers that can take advantage of their grounded checks being slowed down such as Carracosta, Turtonator, and Zangoose make for good partners. Spinblockers such as Golurk and Oricorio-G prevent the removal of Sticky Web via Rapid Spin. They both also have the advantage of pressuring Defoggers with their strong STAB attacks, and Golurk can even provide Stealth Rock support to weaken the Flying-types that aren't affected by Sticky Web. Haunter can be considered too, as it can prevent Defog with Taunt and possibly take out annoyances with Destiny Bond if need be; however, it is more frail than the two previously mentioned Ghost-types and has a harder time against Skuntank. Pawniard and Primeape make for great teammates due to them both being able to deter and punish the use of Defog because of their shared ability in Defiant. They both also check Skuntank, a major annoyance for Masquerain. Checks to Flying-types like Swanna are important, as they are immune to Sticky Web and can usually remove Sticky Web with ease. Alolan Raichu fits this role perfectly, and it appreciates Sticky Web giving it an easier time cleaning up opposing teams.

Slaking.overview: Slaking seems like an appealing option at first glance due to its sky-high Attack stat, great bulk, and expansive movepool. Unfortunately, any sort of viability Slaking could have is completely undermined by Truant, making it immobile every other turn and hopeless against users of Protect and Substitute. This can also be taken advantage of by the opposing team to generate momentum for powerful threats such as Drampa and Crabominable if Slaking predicts incorrectly, and Pokemon such as Gurdurr, Lycanroc, and Omastar can use Slaking as setup fodder. Because of Truant, Slaking has little to no reason to be used over other Normal-types like Stoutland and Kangaskhan.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: An all-out attacking set can best utilize Slaking's large offensive movepool, as most other options, including Choice Band, are even easier to exploit due to Truant. For this reason, other attackers such as Stoutland and Aggron are heavily preferred, as they possess abilities that aid them in wallbreaking rather than being hindrances, thus allowing them to perform far more consistently.

Ninjask.overview: Ninjask is able to distinguish itself by being the fastest unboosted Pokemon in the metagame. Its stellar Speed stat allows it to revenge kill some of the fastest Pokemon in the tier, such as Floatzel, Alolan Raichu, and Jynx, with a little prior damage. With Tectonic Rage, Ninjask is able to overpower foes such as Regirock and Aggron. These traits give Ninjask a decent amount of staying power against offensive and balanced builds. However, Ninjask's offensive presence only goes so far because its mediocre bulk, nasty 4x Stealth Rock weakness, and five common weaknesses to Fire-, Flying-, Ice-, Rock-, and Electric-type attacks mean it is revenge killed rather easily. Furthermore, Ninjask is often an inconsistent revenge killer due to its mediocre Attack stat, and it is left vulnerable to strong priority users such as Lycanroc, Kangaskhan, Abomasnow, and Absol. Ninjask's rather average Attack stat also means that it struggles to break Pokemon such as Mudsdale and Regirock, which are able to sponge Ninjask's unboosted attacks and deal good damage in return.
Ninjask.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Band can be used with U-turn for maximum damage output and momentum, though Ninjask can't really take advantage of this effectively because of its 4x weakness to Stealth Rock. The ability Infiltrator allows Ninjask to check Pokemon like Alolan Raichu that are behind a Substitute, but Ninjask prefers Speed Boost because outspeeding the tier at +1 is more important.

Checks and Counters

Stealth Rock: Ninjask's crippling weakness to Stealth Rock means it has limited opportunities to revenge kill foes, set up Swords Dance, and switch onto the field. Stealth Rock setters such as Regirock and Alolan Sandslash also deal with Ninjask easily if it is unboosted.

Flying-type Pokemon: Flying-types such as Swanna and Oricorio-E can revenge kill Ninjask easily with their Flying-type STAB moves, since Ninjask does not have a reliable way at breaking them other than relying on its weak Aerial Ace.

Priority: Powerful priority attacks, such as Kangaskhan's Fake Out, Lycanroc's Accelerock, and Absol's Sucker Punch are extremely threatening to Ninjask, as its poor bulk prevents it from taking these attacks.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Physically bulky Pokemon such as Regirock, Jellicent, and Sableye can all switch into Ninjask's attacks and take little damage in return. Regirock can use Protect to scout for Tectonic Rage and then threaten Ninjask out with Stone Edge, while the latter two can cripple Ninjask with Will-O-Wisp.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Leech Life is Ninjask's strongest STAB attack that helps it partially mitigate Stealth Rock damage by recovering a bit of HP. Combined with Groundium Z, Dig allows Ninjask to use Tectonic Rage to remove Pokemon such as Aurorus and Aggron; however, be wary that Dig is fairly unreliable after you've used your Z-Move due to the charge turn and low damage output.

Set Details

A Jolly nature allows Ninjask to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, as well as some boosted like +2 Timid Omastar and Alolan Sandslash under hail. Adamant can also be used for more damage output, but loses out on outspeeding foes such as Choice Scarf Kabutops, as well as the aforementioned Omastar and Alolan Sandslash. Speed Boost is the preferred ability, which allows Ninjask at +1 to outspeed fast Choice Scarf users such as Primeape. Groundium Z allows Ninjask to use Tectonic Rage to break through common checks like Aggron, but once again it should be used wisely.

Usage Tips

When facing offensive teams, Ninjask should usually be utilized early-game or mid-game to revenge kill faster foes such as Alolan Raichu and Jynx. Make sure that Stealth Rock is off the field, as it really hampers Ninjask's longevity. If Ninjask is playing against bulkier teams, it should be used as a late-game sweeper because it functions a lot better once the opposing team is sufficiently weakened. Likewise, Ninjask should avoid setting up if bulky Pokemon such as Mudsdale and Regirock are not weakened, since it struggles to break through them even after a +2 Attack boost. Be aware that Tectonic Rage is required to secure OHKOs on bulky threats such as Aggron, so Ninjask should use its Z-Move cautiously, as wasting it will make breaking through bulkier teams harder. Lastly, Ninjask does not have the best bulk or typing to set up safely, but setting up on Fighting-types such as Gurdurr or Primeape locked into Close Combat is usually the best opportunity because they are forced out by Aerial Ace.

Team Options

Entry hazard removal is absolutely mandatory for Ninjask because it is 4x weak to Stealth Rock, so Pokemon such as Hitmonchan and Skuntank make for good partners. Hitmonchan is also able to check Pokemon like Abomasnow, which Ninjask struggles with otherwise. Ninjask appreciates entry hazard setters that are able to weaken opposing teams to the point it can break through grounded foes such as Regirock with Tectonic Rage more easily, making Pokemon with access to Spikes like Ferroseed and Qwilfish ideal partners. Offensively, Ninjask partners well with special attackers such as Aurorus and Drampa that can whittle down checks and counters like Eelektross. On the other hand, defensive Pokemon such as Regirock and Tangela can check strong priority users such as Kangaskhan and Lycanroc. Pursuit trappers like Skuntank and Absol are able to pressure bulkier Ghost-types like Sableye for Ninjask, letting it clean easier. Lastly, Pokemon with access to Volt Switch such as Eelektross can get Ninjask onto the field safely. Eelektross is especially good because it has a slow Volt Switch and is good at pressuring some of Ninjask's checks such as Mudsdale.

Shedinja.overview: Shedinja's unique ability in Wonder Guard allows it to potentially become a deadly late-game wincon, as it's able to completely wall threats such as Alolan Raichu and Hitmonchan lacking Stone Edge. However, being stuck with only 1 HP nullifies any sort of defensive utility Shedinja could have for itself and makes it instantly fall to the ubiquitous users of entry hazards, Toxic and Will-O-Wisp, Leech Seed, and Snow Warning. Wonder Guard also does nothing against common attacking types such as Rock, Flying, and Dark, as well as Pursuit from the likes of Skuntank and Stoutland. All of this means Shedinja requires strenuous team support to function, which ultimately makes it a liability for most teams. Furthermore, Shedinja faces severe competition with Scyther as a setup sweeper, which has superior stats across the board, reliable recovery, and the ability to pivot with U-turn.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Shedinja can utilize its access to Swords Dance and STAB priority Shadow Sneak to attempt the role of a Swords Dance sweeper. Unfortunately, Shedinja's mediocre Attack stat and low-Base Power moves force it to accumulate multiple Swords Dance boosts to pose any serious threat offensively. Its overreliance on Shadow Sneak to hit most foes in tandem with its several exploitable weaknesses often forces Shedinja to switch out, further diminishing its already limited role as a Swords Dance user. The nature and IVs are chosen to minimize the bulk of Ditto transformed into Shedinja, since they have no effect on Shedinja's bulk.

Delcatty.overview: Delcatty's bad movepool and poor stats bar its decent Speed make it completely outclassed by other Normal-types such as Stoutland and Alolan Raticate.
