Dragon Pulse prevents Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Haunter from freely using Taunt and Substitute against Altaria while also helping to rack up chip damage overall. Roost keeps Altaria healthy, allowing it to remove hazards and check Pokemon such as Swanna more comfortably throughout the game.

Set Details

96 EVs are invested in Speed to outspeed Modest Jellicent, letting Altaria use Roost before taking an attack. Leftovers grants Altaria passive recovery during the match. Natural Cure relieves Altaria of status, mainly Toxic poison, upon switching out, which improves its matchup against opposing bulky Toxic users such as Regirock. It also helps Altaria check threats such as Lanturn lacking Ice Beam.

Usage Tips

Altaria should generally be brought in against foes that it walls, such as Eelektross, and use the forced switch as an opportunity to Defog any entry hazards that are on your side of the field. If there are no hazards to remove or if they are of little concern, Altaria can instead focus on spreading Toxic poison throughout the opposing team to weaken them for late-game. Use Roost whenever Altaria's health begins to dwindle, as it otherwise may not be able to switch into Stealth Rock later in the game to use Defog. It will also have trouble checking threats such as Primeape and Haunter if it's not at full health. If the opponent has a Pokemon that Altaria invites in for free, such as Aggron or Aurorus, double switching is a smart play, as said Pokemon can wreak havoc once on the field. Thanks to Altaria's Natural Cure and good matchup against certain Toxic, Will-O-Wisp, and Thunder Wave users such as Regirock, Jellicent, and Qwilfish, Altaria can be used as a status sponge and pivot into said Pokemon for teammates.

Team Options

Due to Altaria's passive nature, it usually belongs on bulkier builds such as balance, bulky offense, and stall due to its ability to check otherwise troublesome threats such as Simisear and Eelektross. Its passive nature also makes it undesirable on offensive or hyper offensive builds, which are often more momentum based. Pokemon susceptible to entry hazard chip damage such as Aurorus and Lanturn appreciate Altaria's Defog support increasing their longevity. The latter has decent defensive synergy with Altaria; Lanturn offers a check to Aurorus, while Altaria beats Eelektross and Grass-types such as Lurantis. Checks to Ice-types such as Jynx and Aurorus are greatly appreciated. Poliwrath and Lanturn can check Ice-types decently if they're wary of Freeze-Dry or secondary STAB attacks from Pokemon such as Abomasnow. They appreciate Altaria removing Spikes and Toxic Spikes in return; Poliwrath can also check Rock-types such as Aggron in exchange. Sturdier defensive answers to Ice-types also include Bronzor, Alolan Sandslash, and Assault Vest Crabominable, with the latter greatly appreciating Altaria's Defog due to its vulnerability to chip damage. Altaria's passiveness often invites many powerful physical attackers such as Aggron, Hitmonchan, and Alolan Sandslash in for little to no cost. Checks to such Pokemon are appreciated. Gurdurr does well at checking all three, as does Poliwrath. More defensive partners such as Sableye and Tangela accomplish a similar role and help whittle down the opposing team with status, Leech Seed, and Knock Off. In return, Altaria checks special attackers such as Swanna and removes Spikes and Toxic Spikes. Altaria likes a teammate to beat Clefairy, as it ignores Altaria's Toxic and Dragon Pulse and can repeatedly set Stealth Rock or set up with Calm Mind. Aggron and Alolan Sandslash beat it quite comfortably and appreciate Altaria's ability to check special attackers. Altaria synergizes well with typical stall picks such as Audino and Pyukumuku, as they appreciate its ability to remove hazards and check threats such as Kangaskhan and Aurorus. Natu or a secondary hazard remover such as Articuno or Skuntank can be used in addition to Altaria on such archetypes to give the team a better matchup against Spikes Qwilfish, which can otherwise annoy Altaria with Taunt.

Zangoose.overview: Zangoose is a very powerful Normal-type wallbreaker. STAB Facade along with its other attacks hits extremely hard when combined with Toxic Orb and Toxic Boost. Zangoose also boasts excellent coverage options in Knock Off and Close Combat that allow it to hit Ghost-, Rock-, and Steel-types. Its middling Speed stat is somewhat nullified by Zangoose's access to Quick Attack, which lets it hit faster threats and take out weakened foes. This is especially useful for Zangoose's Belly Drum set, which can be a deadly sweeper. However, although it has great offensive capability, Zangoose is hindered a lot by its subpar defensive stats and Toxic damage, which ultimately means it can be easily revenge killed. Zangoose also faces competition from other Normal-types in the tier such as Kangaskhan and Dodrio, which, although not hitting as hard, can usually be more reliable, as they don't have Toxic damage wearing them down each turn.
Zangoose.comments:
Other Options

Protect can be used to ensure the Toxic Orb activates, but this means Zangoose lose out on valuable coverage. Normalium Z can be used over Sitrus Berry on Belly Drum sets to turn Belly Drum into Z-Belly Drum, which restores all of Zangoose's lost HP before it uses Belly Drum. This also gives it the option to boost Quick Attack into Breakneck Blitz to have a stronger hit against foes like Tangela. If Zangoose can manage to safely use Belly Drum once, it can use Z-Belly Drum afterwards to completely regain its HP; however, this is far more situational and leaves Zangoose weaker than if it was holding a Sitrus Berry. A Choice Scarf set with Double Edge, Knock Off, Close Combat, and Final Gambit or Return is an option that improves Zangoose's Speed and changes its role to more of a revenge killer rather than a wallbreaker.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Gurdurr, defensive Poliwrath, and Throh can all take a Facade and knock out or phaze Zangoose with their super effective STAB moves. Hitmonchan and offensive Poliwrath threaten Zangoose with priority Mach Punch and Vacuum Wave, while Primeape can naturally outspeed Zangoose, take a Quick Attack, and reply with a Close Combat.

Ghost-types: Sableye and other Ghost-types with a Colbur Berry like Jellicent and Golurk are immune to Zangoose's Facade, don't take enough damage from Knock Off, and are able to deal a lot of damage back with Scald or Earthquake. Offensive Ghost-types such as Oricorio-G and Haunter outspeed Zangoose and can hit it hard with their respective STAB moves, not having to worry about Quick Attack because they are immune to it.

Rock-types: Regirock and Carbink are able to take Facade really well and both can survive a Close Combat too. Offensive Rock-types like Lycanroc check Zangoose too, as they resist Quick Attack and threaten Zangoose with their respective STAB moves.

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon that aren't that frail such as Oricorio-E and Alolan Persian are able to outspeed and revenge kill Zangoose without taking too much damage from Quick Attack.

sets.name: Toxic Orb Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Moves

Facade is Zangoose's strongest move that can reach insane amounts of damage in conjunction with STAB and Toxic Boost. Knock Off allows Zangoose to hit Ghost-types such as Golurk and Jellicent that would otherwise switch in. Close Combat is used to get the super effective hit on Rock- and Steel-types such as Regirock, Probopass, and Aggron, which can stomach Zangoose's other attacks. Swords Dance is an option to boost Zangoose's Attack to tremendous levels, helping it muscle past Pokemon such as Sableye and turning it into a fearsome sweeper with Quick Attack. However, the lack of Close Combat coverage means that Zangoose finds it a lot harder to break past Normal-resistant Pokemon like Regirock, Alolan Sandslash, and Carracosta. Quick Attack is good for cleaning up weakened Pokemon, which is also a good way to activate Zangoose's Toxic Orb in the process.

Set Details

Toxic Orb is necessary to activate Zangoose's Toxic Boost ability and power up its Facade. An Adamant nature makes Zangoose slightly better at wallbreaking, while a Jolly nature is an option to outspeed base 80 Speed Pokemon such as Shiftry as well as outpacing Pinsir and Adamant Kangaskhan.

Usage Tips

Zangoose should be used as a wallbreaker, breaking down the opposing team's defensive core so that a partner can clean up later on. Free switches from a slow U-turn or Volt Switch are vital for Zangoose to function well because it does not like taking hits and it needs its Toxic Orb to activate so that it can deal the maximum amount of damage. Bringing Zangoose in against a very low HP Pokemon and knocking them out with an attack is another good way to activate Toxic Orb. Make sure to be wary of double switches from your opponent's Ghost-, Rock- and Steel-types, as those can rack up Toxic damage and limits the number of turns Zangoose can stay in. If you are using Swords Dance, setting up can be quite hard due to Zangoose's terrible bulk. Try to set up on predicted switches, Protects aiming to stall out Zangoose's Toxic damage, Choice-locked Ghost-types, or very passive Pokemon like Clefairy.

Team Options

Primeape is a good partner, not only because of its access to U-turn, but also because Zangoose breaks down physical walls such as Mudsdale and Musharna really well, allowing Primeape to use Close Combat freely. Fire-types like Combusken and Simisear are great partners, as they can take on Sableye, which gives Zangoose issues. Pokemon that resist Fighting such as Jellicent can stop Pokemon like Gurdurr and Primeape that try to revenge kill Zangoose. Healing Wish support from Pokemon like Mr. Mime is appreciated, as Zangoose is often worn down a lot by its Toxic Orb. Entry hazard removal can be crucial, since Zangoose has limited health already and hates to be worn down more by Stealth Rock and Spikes. Some options include Hitmonchan and Swanna, as they can threaten defensive answers to Zangoose like Regirock.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
Moves

Belly Drum maximizes Zangoose's Attack, which immediately turns it into an offensive threat and dangerous late-game cleaner at the cost of 50% of its HP. Quick Attack makes up for Zangoose's merely decent Speed tier and becomes fairly powerful after it uses Belly Drum, allowing it to KO certain offensive checks such as Primeape and making it quite difficult to revenge kill without a faster Ghost-type. Knock Off provides Zangoose with coverage for Ghost-types such as Spiritomb, Jellicent, and Golurk, which are immune to Quick Attack. Close Combat rounds out Zangoose's coverage, giving it the ability to heavily damage Rock- and Steel-types that resist Quick Attack such as Regirock, Aggron, and Alolan Sandslash. Return could be considered over Close Combat in order to give Zangoose a more reliable, powerful STAB option that OHKOes the likes of Mudsdale at +6, though opting for it over Close Combat means that Zangoose cannot bypass Rock- and Steel-types. Furthermore, Return isn't really necessary, since Zangoose is already powerful enough to OHKO most threats with Quick Attack or Close Combat at +6.

Set Details

Jolly nature is ideal in order to outspeed Skuntank and Pinsir, allowing Zangoose to Quick Attack the former before a potential Sucker Punch. 4 EVs are placed in HP to ensure that Sitrus Berry will activate after Zangoose uses Belly Drum. Sitrus Berry restores 25% of Zangoose's HP, which leaves it at 75% after it uses Belly Drum. Immunity renders Zangoose immune to poison, meaning that it can freely switch in on Toxic Spikes and cannot be put on a timer with Toxic.

Usage Tips

Since Zangoose is a late-game cleaner, it should refrain from attempting to set up until after very physically bulky Pokemon like Mudsdale and faster Ghost-types such as Haunter and Oricorio-G have been either weakened or removed, as it is unlikely that it will get a second chance to attempt to do so. However, despite excelling as a late-game cleaner that can shred offensive teams, Belly Drum Zangoose is also capable of wallbreaking against balance teams. Zangoose's meager defenses and lack of resistances or immunities barring Ghost prevent it from reliably switching in on even weaker attacks, meaning that it should only be brought in following the use of Memento, through the use of U-turn or Volt Switch, or after a teammate is KOed. Zangoose should be cautious of switching in while entry hazards are up, as they further shorten its longevity and limit its ability to safely use Belly Drum and switching in on Toxic Spikes reveals Zangoose's set. Zangoose should mainly set up against slower Pokemon that it forces out like Aurorus.

Team Options

Belly Drum Zangoose fits on offensive teams, primarily Sticky Web teams, as they are more than capable of providing the support that Zangoose needs in order to do its job well. Sticky Web support from Pokemon such as Smeargle and Shuckle slows foes down, which can give Zangoose an easier time sweeping and leave it less reliant on Quick Attack against faster foes. Furthermore, the former can use Spore to help Zangoose create setup opportunities as well as Nuzzle to keep faster foes like Primeape in check, while the latter can provide useful Knock Off support or wear down Pokemon with Toxic. Zangoose appreciates being paired with Pursuit trappers such as Skuntank and Spiritomb, since they can remove faster Ghost-types that easily revenge kill Zangoose like Haunter and Oricorio-G. The former can also provide entry hazard removal, while the latter can cripple physical attackers with Will-O-Wisp, which can potentially ease setup. Memento support from the likes of Alolan Dugtrio, Jumpluff, and the two previously mentioned Pursuit trappers is very much appreciated due to Zangoose's frailty giving it a difficult time freely setting up. Jumpluff can additionally put foes to sleep with Sleep Powder, which can make cleaning for Zangoose easier. Dual screens support from Electrode augments Zangoose's bulk, which is useful for giving it an easier time with both setting up and stomaching attacks subsequent to using Belly Drum. Electrode is also capable of generating momentum with Explosion or Volt Switch. As a late-game cleaner, Zangoose appreciates being paired with strong wallbreakers like Aurorus that can pave the way for Zangoose to finish teams off by either heavily damaging or removing physically bulky Pokemon like Tangela. Entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Ferroseed and Qwilfish is appreciated, as the chip damage can be useful for guaranteeing certain KOs such as on Skuntank with +6 Quick Attack. Entry hazards being up also prevents Sturdy users like Regirock and Golem from taking one hit and KOing Zangoose in return. Entry hazard removers like Swanna, Kabutops, and Rotom-F can prove useful for limiting the damage that Zangoose has to take prior to using Belly Drum, which gives it an easier time setting up and subsequently cleaning. Swanna is also capable of checking Fighting-types, specifically Gurdurr, for Zangoose as well as threatening physically bulky Pokemon like Alolan Persian and Sableye with Supersonic Skystrike.

Seviper.overview: In theory, Seviper seems like a functional breaker with its decent mixed attacking stats and movepool. In reality though, it struggles much more than one would think due to lacking bulk, an average Speed tier, and a reliance on Sucker Punch without STAB to hit faster threats, leaving it open to offensive pressure from the likes of Stoutland and Pinsir. It also receives some competition from fellow Poison-types in Skuntank, Haunter, and Victreebel, as they have additional utility such as Defog, Destiny Bond, and Strength Sap, respectively, and they all sport better Speed tiers and a secondary typing.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description: Seviper can try to catch Poison-type checks such as Mudsdale and Alolan Raichu off-guard with its good coverage and workable power. Seviper's great coverage is a notable trait it has as a Poison-type wallbreaker. However, its mediocre bulk and speed prevent it from being able to wallbreak often, so other offensive Poison-types like Skuntank and Victreebel are superior choices for their better defensive utility and additional STAB.

Lunatone.overview: Lunatone's only niche is to attempt to sweep using Rock Polish to outspeed most Pokemon in the tier, but unfortunately, Lunatone faces major competition from Omastar as a setup sweeper due to Omastar dealing much more damage than Lunatone. Lunatone's typing hinders it greatly, as it is weak to common typings such as Dark, Water, and Bug and is susceptible to priority such as Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Skuntank. Furthermore, Lunatone is quite slow before a Rock Polish, and common offensive Pokemon in the tier such as Primeape, Kabutops, and Floatzel are able to outspeed it and take it out with ease, and poor physical bulk and a bad defensive typing limit its ability to actually set up. Lunatone finds itself lacking the power to hit bulkier opposing Pokemon such as Eelektross and Jellicent, and these Pokemon are able to whittle it down with their STAB moves.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Lunatone has to rely on Rock Polish to have a better chance of beating faster offensive threats and proceeds to try and hit as hard as it can. However, this set is very hard to use in practice because defensively, Lunatone is too vulnerable to the common typings in the meta and finds it very hard to set up on anything that can hit it too hard and take it out. If you're looking for an offensive setup sweeper, Omastar is preferred over Lunatone because of its far better attacking power and easier time setting up.

Solrock.overview: Solrock is overwhelmed by its competition as a Stealth Rock setter from Pokemon such as Regirock, Torterra, and Bronzor. This is all majorly because of Solrock's mediocre stats compared to their great bulk and other attributes like better defensive typings. While its Rock / Psychic typing may seem good at first, the two occasionally contrast and make Solrock unable to reliably switch into certain Pokemon Regirock and Torterra can like Skuntank and Eelektross.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Solrock should be used as a switch-in to physical hits from Pokemon like Kangaskhan and Stoutland and set up Stealth Rock. Its main niche over its competition is in its access to Will-O-Wisp and reliable recovery, but otherwise you're better off using Pokemon like Regirock and Bronzor for their better bulk and typings.

Whiscash.overview: With access to Dragon Dance, a fairly rare move for Pokemon in PU, and a typing that allows it to resist types that are fairly common in PU, Whiscash may seem like a good choice for a setup sweeper. However, in reality, it has horrible offensive and defensive stats that make it extremely difficult to do damage and seem like a threat. Whiscash’s lack of coverage and severely disappointing stats, even at +1, make it near impossible to sweep an entire team, as its terrible Speed allows it to get revenge killed very easily that makes it very difficult setting up without fainting.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: This set attempts to set up Dragon Dance on Pokemon that can't immediately KO Whiscash such as Skuntank and Alolan Sandslash and attempt to sweep the opponent's team. However, due to its underwhelming offensive presence and lack of good coverage, Whiscash is an awful choice for a setup sweeper. Instead, one could go with a more consistent Shell Smash sweeper such as Carracosta or Omastar. Carracosta and Omastar are better sweepers not only because they have good coverage and can beat Pokemon that would normally check them, but also because of their better offensive and defensive stats. These two Shell Smash users also have better bulk and are much harder to revenge kill than Whiscash, resulting in them being much better choices for sweepers.

Claydol.overview: Claydol has somewhat of a niche in its access to both Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock. While it's not the only viable Pokemon to get both of these moves, it has other advantages such as its typing; Ground / Psychic is a reasonable defensive typing that allows Claydol to serve as a switch-in to Rock- and Ground-types such as Lycanroc and Alolan Dugtrio, while also giving Claydol a means to defeat traditional Psychic-resists such as Skuntank and Metang. It also gives Claydol a notable niche in being both resistant to Stealth Rock and immune to all other entry hazards thanks to Levitate. Finally, its typing also gives Claydol a good offensive matchup against various hazard setters and removers such as Aggron and Hitmonchan. However, while it does have great defensive stats, its HP is extremely underwhelming, preventing Claydol from being able to take a large number of hits, especially with its lack of recovery. Its offensive presence is very mediocre, preventing it from picking up many OHKOs such as Earth Power on Skuntank and leaving it as setup fodder for Pokemon such as Jynx and Calm Mind Oricorio-E. While its typing is good in various ways, it gives Claydol a bad matchup against spinblockers such as Jellicent and Oricorio-G, as well as against common offensive Pokemon such as Torterra and Ludicolo. Alolan Sandslash is rightfully the more popular pick for a Pokemon with both Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock. This is because of its better defensive typing that allows it to check more offensive threats such as Aurorus and Oricorio-G. Furthermore, even if they don't have access to Rapid Spin, Pokemon such as Mudsdale and Regirock largely outclass Claydol as a Stealth Rock user with their better bulk. The same can be said of Rapid Spin users such as Hitmonchan and Kabutops who provide a vastly stronger offensive presence.
Claydol.comments:
Other Options

Leftovers gives Claydol better longevity but leaves it with a much worse matchup against Dark-types and Pursuit trappers like Skuntank and gives it a harder time switching into Pokemon such as Gurdurr. Wiki Berry serves as a one-time recovery for Claydol, but it has the same problem as Leftovers. Groundium Z can allow Claydol to OHKO Skuntank, KO Regirock after an Earth Power, and avoid the increased damage from Knock Off, but overall, Claydol isn't worth using a Z-Move slot on. Psyshock can be run over Psychic in order to pick up 2HKOs on Pokemon such as Roselia and Hitmonchan, but Gurdurr is a much more prevalent target, making Psychic better. Similarly, Earthquake does additional damage to specially defensive targets such as Lanturn and Jynx, but has limited use and is overall inferior to Earth Power. An offensive set can be run to pick up OHKOs on Pokemon such as Skuntank but struggles due to Claydol's mediocre offensive stats.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Ghost-types such as Oricorio-G, Silvally-Ghost, and Jellicent can all switch in to block Rapid Spin, have little fear from Claydol's other attacks bar Toxic, and can 2HKO Claydol with their super effective STAB attacks. Others such as Haunter can potentially switch in but risk being OHKOed by Claydol's Psychic.

Super Effective Attackers: Various Pokemon such as Ludicolo, Rotom-F, and Abomasnow all OHKO Claydol with their super effective STAB moves with little to no prior damage. All of the previously mentioned Pokemon notably also resist or are immune to Claydol's Earth Power. Even with Claydol's Colbur Berry still intact, Dark-types such as Alolan Raticate and Absol beat it one-on-one. Pokemon such as Aurorus OHKO Claydol but take a decent amount of damage in the process.

Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers such as Type: Null and Spiritomb can set up freely on Claydol while resting off Toxic damage. Others such as Torterra, Leafeon and Pinsir can also give Claydol a hard time if it isn't running Toxic.

sets.name: Rapid Spin
sets.description:
Moves

Claydol's main role is to remove entry hazards, so Rapid Spin is crucial. It can also run Stealth Rock, but if another teammate is already running it, Toxic should be used to cripple bulky Pokemon that take little from Claydol otherwise such as Cryogonal and Articuno. Psychic is run in order to 2HKO Gurdurr, while Earth Power 2HKOes Skuntank.

Set Details

Colbur Berry allows Claydol to avoid the 2HKO from Skuntank's Crunch or Dark Pulse while also reducing damage from coverage moves such as Gurdurr's Knock Off. The Speed EVs allow Claydol to outspeed Jellicent, Aggron, and Modest Aurorus.

Usage Tips

Claydol should switch in to take resisted hits from Pokemon such as Hitmonchan and Lycanroc, but it has to watch out for being worn down. Furthermore, some Pokemon that Claydol can check have other moves that do a lot to it or cripple it, such as Aggron's Heavy Slam, Primeape's U-Turn, and Mudsdale's Toxic. However, if it does manage to come in, Claydol often forces the foe out and can use this as an opportunity to set up Stealth Rock or remove entry hazards. If there are hazards on your side of the field, Claydol can lure in spinblockers such as Jellicent and cripple them with Toxic instead. If Claydol isn't running Toxic, it can still lure the spinblocker but instead double switch to a Pursuit trapper or a strong breaker such as Drampa that can take advantage.

Team Options

Pokemon such as Ferroseed, Qwilfish, and Roselia can stack Spikes on top of Claydol's Stealth Rock, with the former two also being able to wear down Pokemon such as Skuntank and the latter providing a solid switch-in to Jellicent. Conversely, Pokemon that fear being worn down by entry hazards such as Aurorus and Choice Specs Jellicent appreciate Claydol's ability to remove them. Flying-types such as Dodrio and Scyther also enjoy Stealth Rock being off the field and can serve as checks to Grass-types such as Victreebel, Lurantis, and Ludicolo. However, these same Grass-types also make for good teammates, as they can help against Water-types such as Omastar and Jellicent. Pursuit users such as Stoutland and Spiritomb can trap and deal great damage to Ghost-types such as Oricorio-G and Silvally-Ghost, which greatly limits their spinblocking capabilities. Ghost-types can also spinblock for Claydol, while Primeape can ward off Defog users with Defiant. All of these Pokemon, as well as other offensive threats such as Kangaskhan and Lycanroc, also benefit from Claydol's hazards and Toxic wearing down the opposing team.

Cradily.overview: Cradily is a fairly niche defensive Stealth Rock setter that manages to set itself apart with unique resistances and immunities. Its good bulk and access to reliable recovery allow it to consistently set up Stealth Rock multiple times in a match while checking strong threats such as Jellicent. Cradily's unique type combination and access to Storm Drain give it useful immunities and resistances to Water, Normal, and Electric, allowing it to check Pokemon such as Jellicent, Kangaskhan, and Eelektross. However, Cradily is highly susceptible to common Ice- and Fighting-types such as Aurorus and Throh. Additionally, many Water- and Normal-types pack Ice- or Fighting-type coverage, meaning Cradily is not a reliable counter to Pokemon such as Omastar and Stoutland. Base 81 offenses make Cradily unable to do much damage against anything that resists its STAB moves, forcing it to rely on badly poisoning them with Toxic. It is terribly slow and thus usually forced to take two hits when switching in, limiting its ability to switch into strong hits and set up Stealth Rock. Being passive can also invite setup sweepers that are not worried about Toxic such as Gurdurr and Oricorio-G. All of these flaws mean that Cradily faces severe competition from other Stealth Rock setters such as Regirock and Torterra.
Cradily.comments:
Other Options

Earthquake is an option to hit Skuntank and Alolan Sandslash harder, but Cradily barely has room to run two STAB attacks to begin with. A Curse or Swords Dance set can be used with Seed Bomb and Rock Slide, but it is hard to sweep with, as Cradily is slow and weak even when boosted. Rocky Helmet can be run over Leftovers to provide chip damage against contact moves, but the lack of passive recovery makes it harder to set up Stealth Rock and makes Cradily more reliant on Recover to keep itself healthy. Mirror Coat can be used to get surprise KOs against foes such as Drampa, but it's not very consistent and Cradily is already starved for moveslots. Ancient Power makes better use of Storm Drain than Rock Slide but can allow Calm Mind Oricorio-E and Oricorio-G to set up on Cradily.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Hitmonchan, Primeape, and Gurdurr can all OHKO or 2HKO Cradily with their super effective STAB attacks. Hitmonchan can also remove Stealth Rock set by Cradily, while Gurdurr does not mind switching into Toxic thanks to its Guts ability.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Metang, Ferroseed and Alolan Sandslash can freely switch in on Cradily and set up entry hazards or remove Cradily’s Stealth Rock.

Toxic: Cradily is extremely susceptible to chip damage, and Toxic poison prevents it from reliably countering any of the threats it could normally switch into, as they are free to spam attacks until the Toxic damage increases to lethal levels. In particular, Toxic Spikes from Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Roselia, the latter which can easily switch into Cradily, can severely cripple its effectiveness.

Ice-types: If Cradily lacks Rock Slide, Ice-types such as Aurorus, Abomasnow, and Articuno can freely switch in and threaten it with super effective Ice-type moves.

Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers that are not crippled by Toxic such as Calm Mind Clefairy and Safeguard Bellossom fear nothing from Cradily and can break through it once enough boosts have been accumulated.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Moves

Toxic is Cradily's main way of dealing damage and pressuring certain setup sweepers such as Ludicolo. Rock Slide is the preferred STAB move, as it allows Cradily to pressure common threats such as Oricorio-G and Swanna. Giga Drain is an option to beat Water-types such as Carracosta and Gastrodon while providing additional recovery. Whichever move is chosen, Cradily finds itself incapable of doing significant damage to certain key threats, so running both Rock Slide and Giga Drain in lieu of Toxic is an option, albeit one which leaves Cradily far more susceptible to setup sweepers.

Set Details

A Calm nature should be used over a Careful nature when running Giga Drain over Rock Slide. Leftovers gives Cradily some passive recovery, allowing it to rely less on Recover. Storm Drain allows Cradily to better switch into Water-type Pokemon like Ludicolo.

Usage Tips

Find opportunities to bring in Cradily early-game to set up Stealth Rock, ideally as quickly as possible. Use Recover to keep Cradily as healthy as possible so it can switch into Pokemon such as Eelektross and Swanna and set up Stealth Rock multiple times in a match. Certain stronger attackers that Cradily could normally counter such as Ludicolo are capable of 2HKOing it with only slight prior chip damage. Bring Cradily into Water-type Pokemon like Jellicent, Lanturn, and Carracosta and force them out with the threat of Giga Drain or Toxic. Use these forced switches as opportunities to set up Stealth Rock or use Recover if Cradily is not healthy. Avoid using Cradily's STAB move early in the match to make the opponent wary of switching in Pokemon like Abomasnow and Oricorio-E that can switch into Cradily depending on its STAB move. Make use of Cradily's immunity to Water to ease prediction against opposing Water-type Pokemon like Carracosta and Ludicolo, as they are less likely to use Water-type moves as long as Cradily is healthy. Cradily should avoid Toxic at all costs from Pokemon such as Ferroseed, which can cripple it very badly, and super effective coverage moves from Pokemon it can otherwise counter. Scouting for lures such as Z-Focus Punch Kangaskhan will drastically increase Cradily's survivability.

Team Options

Cradily is best fit on bulkier teams, so it should be paired with other defensive Pokemon. Cradily appreciates Poison- and Steel-type Pokemon gone, as they are immune to Toxic and resist Giga Drain. Musharna is able to threaten Poison-types with Psychic, and Gurdurr takes on Steel-types while having Guts to absorb status. Cradily is vulnerable to all forms of entry hazards, especially Toxic Spikes. Defog users such as Skuntank and Swanna make for good partners, with Skuntank in particular being able to absorb Toxic Spikes. Fighting-type checks such as Oricorio-G and Qwilfish are very valuable partners for Cradily. Cleric support from Pokemon such as Lanturn and Articuno can be used to remove status from Cradily and its team. Fire-type Pokemon like Combusken and Simisear appreciate Storm Drain support from Cradily. Meanwhile, Cradily benefits Rock-, Ground-, Fire-, and Flying-types by countering many Water- and Electric-types. It can also be a good partner for physically frail Pokemon such as Cryogonal, as it can discourage Normal-type wallbreakers like Stoutland from freely spamming their STAB moves.

Armaldo.overview: While a sky-high Attack stat and access to Rapid Spin give Armaldo the facade of being a viable offensive spinner, it's completely outclassed. Its horrendous typing gives it few useful resistances and weaknesses to common types like Water and Rock, which also makes it weak to Stealth Rock on top of being vulnerable to every other entry hazard. This, combined with its very low Speed stat, makes it hard for Armaldo to remove entry hazards as consistently as other spinners, as it'll often be taking a lot of damage in the process. It also can't remove entry hazards against common setters like Aggron and Regirock. All of these facts combined make it mostly outclassed by other offensive entry hazard removers such as Hitmonchan, Skuntank, and Alolan Sandslash.

sets.name: Offensive Spinner
sets.description: With this set, Armaldo attempts to be an offensive spinner with its nice offensive presence and coverage moves. It even has the perk of being able to heavily damage Ghost-types such as Jellicent. Still, Armaldo finds itself outclassed by Hitmonchan and Alolan Sandslash, which have similar offensive presence, have far more defensive presence, and aren't nearly as weak to entry hazards.

Castform.overview: Castform may have a wide variety of support and coverage moves at its disposal, but it lacks the stats to utilize them properly. Worse still, it relies on having the right weather up to even get STAB on a lot of these moves, meaning it has no breaking power outside of weather, and thanks to its weak offensive stats, it still hits like a wet paper bag even with weather up. Its low Speed tier and lack of a Speed-boosting ability means it's easily revenge-killed. Please refrain from using Castform on any serious team and just use Ludicolo instead.

sets.name: Z-Rain Dance
sets.description: The goal of this set is simple: set up Z-Rain Dance and attempt to "sweep". Castform's wide coverage movepool seems enticing, but the limited duration of this rain means it has limited time to actually do anything, not to mention the fact that other rain sweepers, such as Omastar and Ludicolo, have just as good coverage. In addition, its poor stats and lack of a STAB move outside of rain mean you will usually just end up using it as fodder. If you want an offensive rain sweeper, use Ludicolo: it can sweep without relying on a Z-Move, it has much better stats, and it has all the coverage it needs between its STAB moves and Ice Beam.

Kecleon.overview: Due to its high special bulk and unique offensive attributes, Kecleon can make a good user of Assault Vest, able to check a majority of special attackers in the tier, including Alolan Raichu, Simisear, and Oricorio-G. Its Dark / Fighting coverage between Knock Off and Drain Punch can be tricky to switch into, especially with Protean giving Kecleon STAB for every move. Furthermore, Kecleon has useful priority in Shadow Sneak that can let it revenge kill threats like Jynx and Oricorio-G, and it also has access to Sucker Punch. Protean can make Kecleon difficult to play around because it can change its typing to resist or become immune to the opposing Pokemon's attacks, such as clicking Shadow Sneak in front of a Fighting-type. Unfortunately, poor physical bulk and awful Speed make Kecleon easily taken out by physical attackers like Kangaskhan and Absol. Additionally, Kecleon struggles greatly with status, and due to its only moderate Attack stat, it is easy to wall with bulkier Pokemon like Mudsdale and Gastrodon. While Kecleon may face competition with other Assault Vest tanks like Eelektross and Hitmonchan which offer better role compression, its unique priority and Protean coverage give it a niche.
Kecleon.comments:
Other Options

Fake Out can be run in the last slot to provide reliable dual priority, although it is fairly weak and does not hit Pokemon super effectively. Trick Room can be used with a Life Orb set as an individual sweeper or as part of dedicated Trick Room teams. Kecleon can also use a Life Orb set with Speed investment that can break more walls, but it sacrifices most of its special bulk and faces competition from faster or stronger attackers like Absol and Aggron. Iron Tail can be used to hit Fairy-types, although they are not too common and Clefairy already fears Knock Off. Kecleon has several special coverage options like Fire Blast to hit Tangela and Grass Knot to hit Gastrodon. However, they only hit very specific Pokemon and you have to sacrifice either a coverage move or priority move to run them. Kecleon can run a fully special set to take advantage of this coverage, but it is very weak. Return or Double-Edge can be used as a powerful neutral attack, but this doesn't help Kecleon break through any specific Pokemon, and Kecleon would usually prefer another move. Kecleon has the bulk and movepool to run a special wall set with Recover and maximum EV investment in HP and Special Defense, but it is vulnerable to status and outclassed by Clefairy and Audino. Kecleon can set Stealth Rock, although it usually prefers another move and it cannot run this move with Assault Vest.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Pokemon such as Mudsdale, Poliwrath, and Gastrodon can easily avoid a 2HKO from Kecleon's attacks and cripple it with status, and Gastrodon can also recover off the damage.

Physical Attackers: Kecleon has poor physical bulk and can be easily outsped and killed by Pokemon like Kangaskhan and Kabutops. Certain Fighting-types like Gurdurr and Hitmonchan threaten Kecleon as well, but they may find it difficult if Kecleon has already transformed into a Ghost-type.

Status: Kecleon is easily crippled by burn from moves like Jellicent's Will-O-Wisp and Gastrodon's Scald, and Toxic from Pokemon like Regirock and Lanturn wears it down easily.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Moves

Knock Off is Kecleon's strongest move in most situations and provides utility by removing items. Drain Punch recovers health and provides good coverage with Knock Off. Shadow Sneak is a reliable priority attack that lets Kecleon revenge kill Jynx and Alolan Raichu and annoy Fighting-types thanks to Protean. Sucker Punch is an additional priority option that is stronger than Shadow Sneak and is better for chip damage versus Pokemon such as Stoutland, although it's not reliable and can be played around with non-attacking moves. Alternatively, Power-Up Punch boosts Kecleon's Attack, allowing it to break bulkier Pokemon like Clefairy and giving it a chance to sweep unprepared teams.

Set Details

84 EVs in Speed are used to let Kecleon outspeed uninvested base 50 Speed Pokemon such as Audino. The remaining EVs are dumped into HP to increase Kecleon's overall bulk. Assault Vest helps Kecleon easily tank most special attacks. Protean is the best ability as it gives Kecleon STAB bonus for each move and also changes Kecleon's typing, which can often be used to its advantage.

Usage Tips

Kecleon should function as a special tank and switch-in to special attackers such as Omastar and Oricorio-G throughout the game. Early-game, Kecleon should generally be used to annoy bulkier Pokemon with its Dark / Fighting coverage while tanking hits. Knock Off should be used the most to remove Pokemon's items on the switch, and Drain Punch can be used to recover small amounts of health and hit Fighting-weak Pokemon. Use Protean to your advantage, such as using Shadow Sneak in front of a Fighting-type or using Drain Punch to prevent Dark-types from being able to revenge kill Kecleon. You can even block Rapid Spin by using Shadow Sneak if necessary. Protean can easily become a disadvantage if you're not careful though, such as getting Pursuit trapped while transformed into a Ghost-type. If you're running Power-Up Punch, Kecleon should use it against weaker special attackers like Eelektross after its checks and counters have been eliminated or worn down, giving it a chance of sweeping teams. Be careful not to wear Kecleon down too much if it is needed to check special sweepers like Simisear later on in the game or revenge kill Pokemon with its priority.

Team Options

Physical tanks like Jellicent and Qwilfish take physical attacks and resist Fighting whereas Kecleon takes special attacks for them. Mudsdale makes for a good entry hazard setter for teams with Kecleon, which is important because Kecleon appreciates the chip damage to pick foes off with its priority. Pokemon weak to Psychic-types and Ghost-types appreciate Kecleon's support, so Fighting-types like Gurdurr make good partners. Gurdurr is also able to absorb Will-O-Wisp for Kecleon and take on strong physical attackers like Kangaskhan that Kecleon hates. Kecleon helps take on other special attackers as well, such as Swanna, Simisear, and Oricorio-G. Balanced teams that have physical tanks but are lacking in terms of special bulk will appreciate Kecleon functioning as a check to almost any special attacker. Special wallbreakers like Simisear and Choice Specs Aurorus will help break the physical walls like Gastrodon that wall Kecleon. Status support is appreciated because of how Kecleon gives a free switch to common walls that use Will-O-Wisp or Toxic like Gastrodon and Jellicent. Heal Bell support from Pokemon like Clefairy can keep Kecleon healthy, and even simply Toxic-immune Pokemon like Alolan Sandslash and Skuntank can be helpful for this reason. Skuntank also provides hazard removal and removed Toxic Spikes, which helps Kecleon check special attackers over the course of the game without getting worn down too quickly.

Banette.overview: Banette has a decent Attack stat, priority moves like Sucker Punch and Shadow Sneak, support moves like Will-O-Wisp, and an immunity to sleep. However, Banette has very low stats across the board otherwise, making it too frail and too slow to be viable in PU. Besides, it gets Pursuit trapped or revenge killed incredibly easily by threats like Skuntank. Even its immunity to sleep isn't unique enough to be a niche, as many Grass-types like Victreebel, Abomasnow, and Tangela are also immune to Spore and Sleep Powder anyway. In the end, there are better Ghost-types in the tier, like Golurk and Jellicent, which have higher bulk and better offensive movepools and typings.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Banette is just not strong enough to be a decent wallbreaker due to its lack of stronger STAB attacks, although it can at least pick off weaker foes with priority. As a physically offensive Pokemon, Golurk has slightly better bulk that lets it spinblock more effectively, better offensive stats, better coverage moves that allow it to hit its checks, and a better typing and mobility that allow it to hit way harder than Banette. Golurk can also support its team better with Stealth Rock.

Tropius.overview: Tropius attempts to stall opposing Pokemon with Substitute and Leech Seed. However, Tropius faces a lot of competition from Tangela as a defensive Grass-type, as Tangela is much more bulky thanks to Eviolite, gets more reliable recovery in Regenerator, and possesses a nice matchup against physically offensive Pokemon in the tier such as Stoutland and Lycanroc. Tropius struggles against the latter especially due to its Grass / Flying typing, which gives it a Stealth Rock weakness which heavily reduces its longevity. Low Speed hinders Tropius as well and makes even harder to set up Substitute since offensive Pokemon like Lycanroc and Aurorus are able to outspeed it and force it out.

sets.name: SubSeed
sets.description: SubSeed Tropius wears down opposing Pokemon and attempts to cause switches, since Leech Seed and Sitrus Berry recovery under Substitute allows Tropius to recover back damage that it has taken as an attempt to stall the opposing Pokemon. Unfortunately, this set is very hard to actually pull off since Tropius is very slow, and a lot of offensive Pokemon like the aforementioned Lycanroc can easily force it out, making sure that Tropius can never actually set up Substitute. It is recommended to use Tangela as a defensive Grass-type because Tangela isn't as easily forced out as Tropius since Tangela's colossal physical bulk allows it to tank a number of hits compared to Tropius. Furthermore, Tangela is able to run Knock Off and Sleep Powder to cripple opposing Pokemon, providing significantly more defensive utility than Tropius.

Chimecho.overview: On paper, Chimecho has a lot of things going for it. It has a solid support movepool, including reliable recovery in Recover, entry hazard removal in Defog, and rare access to Healing Wish. It also has a solid ability in Levitate, making it a pivot into certain Pokemon such as Mudsdale. However, this all falls apart when one looks at Chimecho's stats and typing, which are pretty bad for the type of Pokemon it is supposed to be. There are plenty of Psychic-type in the tier which provide similar utility while still being vastly more competent choices, such as Musharna and Claydol. They also have ways against the Dark-types that counter Chimecho such as pivoting with U-turn or Healing Wish or using Choice Specs Dazzling Gleam and Ground-type STAB moves.

sets.name: Supporter
sets.description: This set utilizes Chimecho's solid support movepool to give it a niche. However, it isn't as bulky as one might like, and its typing makes it vulnerable to several threats in the PU metagame such as Skuntank, Jellicent, and Spiritomb. As a Healing Wish user, it is outperformed by Musharna, which has better offensive presence, and as an entry hazard remover, it is completely outclassed by Claydol, which also has access to Levitate while resisting Stealth Rock, performing better against common hazard setters like Regirock and Aggron, providing Stealth Rock support, and having better bulk.

Absol.overview: Absol has a fearsome Attack stat, which in conjunction with Knock Off and Choice Band makes it very hard to switch into. Its good coverage options in Superpower and Play Rough allow it to hit Steel-, Dark-, and Fighting-types like Aggron, Shiftry, Hitmonchan, and Gurdurr. It also has access to Swords Dance to further its wallbreaking potential and Sucker Punch, which makes it a very useful tool against offensive Pokemon and can often be used to sweep after a boost. However, Absol relies greatly on Sucker Punch to outspeed faster Pokemon because of its rather lacking base 75 Speed stat, which can be played around with passive moves like Substitute from Pokemon like Oricorio-G. It's also still easily revenge killed by Pokemon like Silvally-Fairy and Alolan Persian, which don't care about Sucker Punch. Due to its lackluster bulk, Absol can easily get KOed throughout the match in general. Finally, Absol sees heavy competition as a Dark-type for a team slot due to the presence of Alolan Raticate and Skuntank; the former has a lot more power behind its moves thanks to Hustle, while the latter provides a lot more utility and is a lot more easy to fit on a team.
Absol.comments:
Other Options

Pursuit can be used to force mind games against Pokemon like Haunter, Jynx, and Alolan Raichu, which may try to switch out fearing Sucker Punch or Knock Off; it's also useful to take a chunk out of certain Pokemon that cannot touch Absol like Sableye and Bronzor, which will want to switch out. A set utilizing a Choice Scarf can be used to naturally outspeed Pokemon like Alolan Raichu and Oricorio-G, but this will mean Absol has to give up its ability to pick off teams with Swords Dance and Sucker Punch. Lum Berry can be used to avoid a status ailment like a burn or paralysis, which otherwise cripples Absol's sweeping potential greatly, and it also lets Absol set up a Swords Dance more easily. Substitute can ease up prediction and avoid status ailments as well, but this will mean Absol has to give up a moveslot that is vital for its coverage and overall usefulness. Taunt and Magic Coat can also be useful but they are too situational to deserve a moveslot.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Hitmonchan, Primeape, and Gurdurr can all threaten Absol with their respective STAB moves; Gurdurr can switch into Play Rough once and threaten it with Mach Punch, while Hitmonchan and Primeape can revenge kill it.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Granbull can switch in on almost any move from Absol, but they have to be wary of the rare Iron Tail. Clefairy can also be used as a check, but it tends to struggle against Absol if it's boosted. Clefairy also has to watch out for Knock Off, since the loss of its Eviolite greatly cuts into its bulk.

Status: Status ailments like burn, paralysis, and poison from Pokemon like Jellicent, Regirock, and Audino can cut Absol's power, Speed, or longevity, crippling its ability to wallbreak and sweep, but these Pokemon have to be wary of Absol's Knock Off or coverage moves like Superpower, in Regirock's case.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Physically defensive Pokemon like Tangela, Mudsdale, and Regirock can check Absol, but they don't like having their items removed by Knock Off and, once weakened enough, can be KOed by a boosted Knock Off. Regirock also has to watch out for Superpower.

Priority Moves: Because of Absol's lackluster bulk, it can easily get worn down and KOed by common priority moves like Aqua Jet and Fake Out from Pokemon like Floatzel and Kangaskhan, and especially Mach Punch from Hitmonchan and Gurdurr.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Moves

Sucker Punch allows Absol to heavily damage or revenge kill Choice Scarf users such as Alolan Sandslash and Rotom-F, as well as naturally faster threats such as Alolan Raichu and Dodrio. Superpower is used to dent or KO Steel-, Dark-, and Rock-type Pokemon such as Ferroseed, Skuntank, and Carracosta. Alternatively, Play Rough can be used to hit expected Fighting- and Dark-type switch-ins such as Gurdurr and Alolan Persian hard. However, Absol is already able to 2HKO other Fighting-types such as Hitmonchan and Combusken without it, Gurdurr doesn't appreciate losing its item to Knock Off, and Absol often prefers being able to heavily damage walls such as Regirock and common Steel-types such as Alolan Sandslash. Pursuit grants Absol the ability to function as one of the most powerful trappers in the tier, allowing it deal great amounts of damage to diverse threats such as Eelektross, Oricorio-G, and Cryogonal as well as Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Haunter and Musharna. Iron Tail is an option that gives Absol a way of dealing with Fairy-types that normally wall it such as Silvally-Fairy and Clefairy, but these threats aren't nearly as common, and Absol often has a hard time fitting it into its moveset.

Set Details

A Jolly nature can be utilized to outspeed Pokemon such as Victreebel, Ludicolo, and Adamant Stoutland, but Absol usually prefers to hit as hard as possible. Justified allows Absol to get a +1 Attack boost off of Dark-type attacks such as Knock Offs from Sableye and Alolan Persian.

Usage Tips

This set can be used early- to mid-game to remove items from physical walls such as Regirock, Tangela, and Gurdurr. Attempt to bring in Absol through slow pivots such as Eelektross and Lanturn, since its low defenses only allow it to switch in safely on passive Pokemon such as Sableye or expected Psychic-type moves from the likes of Musharna. Be wary of Colbur Berry from Pokemon such as Musharna and Jellicent, since the former is able to KO Absol with Dazzling Gleam, while the latter can cripple it with Will-O-Wisp. Absol's ability to force out switch-ins turns it into a threatening Pursuit trapper. When facing Psychic- or Ghost-types such as Spiritomb and Alolan Raichu or specially defensive Pokemon such as Lanturn and Cryogonal, you must attempt to predict if your opponent would want to switch them out or stay in and decide to Pursuit trap them or utilize another move as appropriate. Getting rid of specially defensive Pokemon allows special sweepers to potentially win late-game, while removing Ghost- and Psychic-types helps Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Throh. Utilize Superpower to hit expected Steel-, Dark-, and Rock-type switch-ins such as Alolan Sandslash, Alolan Persian, and Regirock for maximum damage. Play Rough can catch Fighting-types on the switch such as Gurdurr, effectively 2HKOing it even before its Eviolite has been removed. Both of these options should be utilized on predicted switch-ins and can be taken advantage of by the opponent, such as the drop in Attack and Defense after Superpower, so you should attempt to be careful of which move you're letting Absol be locked into. Furthermore, being locked into Sucker Punch can result in sweepers such as Alolan Raichu and Oricorio-G attempting to set up on Absol, so only resort to this move when the opposing Pokemon aren't given this opportunity or if you have another way of dealing with these threats. Though better suited for early- to mid-game, the amount of power packed in Sucker Punch can allow Choice Band Absol to function as a late-game cleaner; however, this requires great amounts of chip on Choice Scarf users such as Primeape, as well as the prior removal of Pokemon such as Gurdurr and Silvally-Fairy.

Team Options

Entry hazards from the likes of Mudsdale and Qwilfish wear down answers to Absol such as Silvally-Fairy and Tangela. Both are also able to threaten or beat Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and certain Hitmonchan sets, which in return supports Absol. Other Fighting-type checks such as special Victreebel and Musharna are able to counter Gurdurr and Throh; in return, Absol is able to threaten specially defensive Pokemon such as Cryogonal and Eelektross. Musharna is also able to allow Absol to be more of a nuisance late-game with Healing Wish while also utilizing Future Sight to help Absol spam its STAB moves more freely, securing damage and forcing in Pokemon that won't appreciate its damage output. Slow pivots such as Eelektross and Lanturn are able to bring in Absol safely, which is highly necessary due to its fragility. Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Primeape appreciate Absol's ability to Pursuit trap Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Sableye and Musharna. Choice Scarf Primeape can even use U-turn on their expected switch-ins, allowing Absol to Pursuit trap them or remove their items with Knock Off. Entry hazard removers such as Alolan Sandslash value Choice Band Absol's ability to Pursuit trap common spinblockers such as Jellicent and Sableye. Defog users like Silvally-Fairy are able to check Fighting-types like Gurdurr for Absol as well as provide pivoting, while Absol is able to cripple Stealth Rock setters like Mudsdale and Regirock. Physical cleaners such as Carracosta and Lycanroc greatly benefit from Choice Band Absol removing Eviolite from physical walls such as Tangela, Regirock, and Gurdurr. Special sweepers like Omastar, Alolan Raichu, and Combusken appreciate Choice Band Absol's ability to Pursuit trap and remove items from specially defensive Pokemon such as Lanturn, Eelektross, and Cryogonal; Alolan Raichu also appreciates Absol getting rid of Ghost-types like Haunter, while Combusken appreciates its ability to deal with Psychic-types like Musharna.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Sucker Punch lets Absol handle faster Pokemon like Dodrio, Simisear, and Floatzel, which can threaten Absol because of how frail and slow it is. Superpower allows Absol to hit Dark-types like Shiftry, Alolan Persian, and Alolan Raticate for super effective damage. It also hits Steel- and Rock-types like Aggron, Carracosta, and Regirock for greater damage than Knock Off or Sucker Punch. Play Rough hits the aforementioned Dark-types without having to deal with the Attack and Defense drops from Superpower while also hitting troublesome Fighting-types like Hitmonchan, Primeape, and Gurdurr for a good amount of damage.

Set Details

An Adamant nature maximizes Absol's wallbreaking potential, while a Jolly nature allows Absol to Speed tie with positive-natured base 75 Speed Pokemon and outspeed neutral-natured base 85 Speed Pokemon like Pinsir. Justified gives Absol an Attack boost whenever it gets hit by a Dark-type move like Knock Off. Life Orb further enhances Absol's damage output at the cost of 1/10th of its HP every turn it attacks, while Darkinium Z gives Absol a one-time nuke with 140 Base Power and allows Absol to switch into Knock Off for a free boost more easily without the risk of losing its item.

Usage Tips

Use Absol to punch holes early- to mid-game if this allows a teammate of Absol to clean up later, but Sucker Punch in conjunction with Swords Dance can be useful to pull off a late-game sweep if the opposing team has been weakened. Get Absol in on weaker attacks that it resists or attacks that it's immune to like Knock Off, Psyshock, and Psychic from Pokemon like Shiftry, Alolan Raticate, and Alolan Raichu to get a turn to set up or use Sucker Punch. VoltTurn is another way to get Absol in and prevent it from taking a hit, and switching into Knock Off is especially useful if Absol is carrying Darkinium Z, as Knock Off will not be boosted and Absol will receive an Attack boost from Justified. Absol can switch in on passive Pokemon like Sableye to threaten the opposing team with Knock Off or set up a Swords Dance to sweep or weaken the opposing team for its teammates. Try to force Pokemon like Musharna and Alolan Raichu out to set up a Swords Dance and sweep if its checks and counters are weakened, but be aware that Musharna can run Colbur Berry and that Alolan Raichu can play around Sucker Punch with Nasty Plot, making it very threatening if Absol runs out of Sucker Punch PP. Use Play Rough whenever you predict Fighting- or Dark-types like Gurdurr, Primeape, Hitmonchan, Alolan Persian, and Absol to switch in. However, Absol can't stay in on these Fighting-types because they can and most likely will threaten it with their respective STAB moves.

Team Options

Pokemon like Qwilfish and Roselia can set up entry hazards to wear down many of Absol's common switch-ins like Hitmonchan, Silvally-Fairy, and Regirock while also sponging super effective attacks for Absol. Absol can also take advantage of Psychic-types that might want to switch in on Qwilfish. Pokemon like Primeape and Hitmonchan appreciate Absol's ability to take advantage of the Ghost- and Psychic-types they struggle with; the former can also bring in Absol via U-turn. Pokemon that can switch into Fighting-type attacks like Victreebel and Oricorio-E greatly benefit Absol; in return, Absol can take advantage of the specially defensive walls that can threaten them such as Audino. Absol likes to be brought in via slow VoltTurn so it doesn't have to take a hit; Pokemon like Lanturn, Eelektross, and Silvally-Fairy can fill this role. Clerics like Altaria, Lanturn, and Healing Wish Musharna can remove status ailments like burn and paralysis from Absol, which otherwise greatly cripple it. Pokemon such as Primeape and Gurdurr appreciate Absol's ability to weaken Mudsdale, Qwilfish, and Tangela.

Glalie.overview: Glalie's access to Spikes and workable overall stats make it look like a decent choice, but this sadly isn't the case. It is hopelessly outclassed by other Spikes users; Qwilfish has a better typing, movepool, and ability, making its job easier. Glalie's merely average Speed leaves it outsped by numerous Pokemon, notably opposing Qwilfish, which can prevent Glalie from setting Spikes with Taunt.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: This set's goal is to make Glalie a suicide lead thanks to Spikes, Taunt, and Explosion. Taunt blocks Defog and Explosion blocks both Rapid Spin and Defog. As appealing as this sounds, this set is totally outclassed by Qwilfish. Regardless of its different typing, it's a superior Spikes setter thanks to its higher Speed and better movepool.

Walrein.overview: Walrein could fulfill the role of a special wall thanks to its decent bulk. However, it's outclassed by Eelektross and Lanturn. Walrein has an okay support movepool, but despite this, it is very slow and has almost no offensive moves to back it up, making it a very passive Pokemon. Despite working best as a decent Ice-type check, it is weak to Stealth Rock and many offensive threats like Kabutops, Lycanroc, and Victreebel are able to deal a lot of damage to it. This, along with its lack of reliable recovery, makes Walrein much frailer than one would expect.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: This set uses Walrein's support movepool to poison foes, rack up entry hazard damage, and stop setup sweepers with Roar while being immune to Taunt. Even then, this set is very passive and lacks recovery, as well as Scald, which is something that other Water-types like Jellicent and Omastar do have that helps them cripple physical attackers. In the end, Lanturn, Cryogonal, and Eelektross function as better walls and tanks despite Walrein's positives due to their better offensive presence or because they aren't weak to Stealth Rock.

Huntail.overview: Huntail faces too much competition from other Shell Smash users in PU to ever be worth considering; Omastar and Turtonator have access to stronger Special Attack stats and STAB moves, while Carracosta has better bulk with access to a reliable priority attack in Aqua Jet. Huntail only has one small niche in its access to Sucker Punch, which gives it a tool to outspeed would-be revenge killers like Choice Scarf Dodrio. On the downside, finding setup opportunities with Huntail is difficult because it has mediocre bulk and doesn't have access to Solid Rock. Additionally, being susceptible to all form of entry hazards means that Huntail has to be preserved for late-game, since it gets worn down easily, making setup opportunities even more difficult. Also, unfortunately, even after a +2 Speed boost from Shell Smash, Huntail is easily revenge killed by faster foes such as Choice Scarf Primeape and Rotom-F, which take a +2 Sucker Punch. Furthermore, despite having Ice Beam, Huntail struggles at breaking through certain Grass-type Pokemon like Ferroseed and Abomasnow. Huntail also has trouble getting past bulky Water-types, like Gastrodon, which can wall it and thus prevent a sweep.
Huntail.comments:
Other Options

Hidden Power Fire can be used to OHKO Ferroseed after a +2 Special Attack boost, while Hidden Power Grass can be used to OHKO Gastrodon after the boost; however, finding slots for both of these moves can be hard, and not running Ice Beam means Pokemon like Drampa become annoying to deal with. Waterium Z is a final alternative that can be used for the immediate boost in power, but White Herb is preferred so priority users can't revenge kill Huntail as easily.

Checks and Counters

Water-type Pokemon: Water-types such as Gastrodon and Poliwrath resist Huntail's STAB attacks. Gastrodon can wear Huntail down with Earth Power, while Lanturn can take +2 Sucker Punch and get off big damage with Volt Switch.

Grass-type Pokemon: Grass-types such as Lurantis and Abomasnow are big threats to Huntail. Lurantis sports excellent bulk, resists Huntail's Water-type attacks, tanks Ice Beam even at +2, and threatens back with Grass-type attacks. Abomasnow is also able to tank +2 Ice Beam. Ferroseed is especially annoying for Huntail with a combination of Thunder Wave, Leech Seed, and Toxic.

Choice Scarf users: Due to Huntail's mediocre Speed stat, it is outsped even at +2 by common Choice Scarf users such as Primeape and Kabutops, both of which can also take a boosted Sucker Punch when healthy.

Priority: Priority attacks, such as Hitmonchan's Mach Punch and Absol's Sucker Punch, are threatening to Huntail, as its mediocre bulk prevents it from tanking these attacks if it is low on health. Kangaskhan has a special mention because it has dual priority, though Huntail can potentially play around it with Shell Smash.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description:
Moves

Sucker Punch allows Huntail to pick off weakened Choice Scarf users, which is important because Huntail is very slow. Ice Beam helps Huntail break through Grass-types such as Tangela and Torterra.

Set Details

A Naughty nature is used to avoid lowering power when using Ice Beam and lets Huntail be as strong and fast as possible. White Herb allows Huntail to preserve its defenses after a Shell Smash, making it less susceptible to priority attackers such as Hitmonchan. Water Veil allows Huntail to ignore Will-o-Wisp from Pokemon like Sableye and Spiritomb.

Usage Tips

Ideally, Huntail should be saved for late-game when Pokemon such as Gastrodon and Ferroseed are weakened enough for it to effectively sweep through the rest of the team. Huntail finds very few setup opportunities, so be careful in choosing when to set up. Using Shell Smash will often cost Huntail most of its health, so try to remove any entry hazards such as Toxic Spikes before attempting to set up. Furthermore, Huntail should avoid setting up if Choice Scarf users such as Swanna and Primeape are at full HP because they are faster than Huntail after +2 and Huntail can't score OHKOs with Sucker Punch without prior damage; however, Huntail can be used to punch holes early-game against more offensively oriented teams if standard checks are not present.

Team Options

Huntail appreciates Memento support from Pokemon such as Jumpluff and Skuntank to make it easier for Huntail to set up with Shell Smash. Jumpluff is also a good partner for Huntail because it chips away at bulky Grass-types such as Ferroseed with Acrobatics. Huntail pairs well with wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan and Absol that can punch holes through the opposing team and remove Huntail's defensive answers so it has an easier time sweeping. In return, Huntail is able to severely weaken the former's checks such as Regirock. Huntail is frail, so being brought safely into the match from Volt Switch users such as Eelektross is ideal. Eelektross is especially good because it can pressure Huntail's checks such as Ferroseed, Gastrodon, and Choice Scarf Electric-types that revenge kill Huntail. Additionally, Huntail hates all sort of entry hazards, so Pokemon like Skuntank and Cryogonal are appreciated. Skuntank, in particular, can absorb Toxic Spikes and opt to lure Huntail's checks with Fire Blast and take them out, making it easier for Huntail to set up.

Gorebyss.overview: With access to Shell Smash, Gorebyss is able to serve as a setup sweeper and wallbreaker. Its nice Special Attack, powerful STAB move in Hydro Pump, and various coverage options such as Ice Beam, Hidden Power Grass, and Hidden Power Fire all help Gorebyss in performing its roles. However, its low Speed largely hinders Gorebyss, making it much easier for Choice Scarf users such as Primeape and Dodrio to revenge kill it, even after a Shell Smash. If Gorebyss has taken enough damage, it can also be revenge killed by priority users such as Skuntank, Kangaskhan, and Hitmonchan. This leads to large competition from Carracosta, which has priority in Aqua Jet to make up for its low Speed, better bulk, Solid Rock, a secondary STAB move in Stone Edge, and the ability to run a mixed set, making it even harder to stop after it sets up a Shell Smash. However, its biggest competition comes from Omastar, which is stronger, faster, and bulkier than Gorebyss and has a useful secondary typing to boot. Between Omastar and Carracosta, there is practically no reason to use Gorebyss in the current meta.
Gorebyss.comments:
Other Options

Surf can be a more reliable STAB option over Hydro Pump due to its higher accuracy, but it can be simply too weak at times, and it makes it easier for specially defensive Pokemon to wall Gorebyss. Scald is another option with even less power than Surf but with a chance to burn foes. Life Orb allows Gorebyss to constantly deal out a little more damage as it sweeps, but it can wear Gorebyss down over time, and it can leave Gorebyss more vulnerable against walls, faster foes, and priority users, making it generally less reliable than the other item options. Signal Beam is a coverage option that hits Grass-types, including Abomasnow and Ludicolo, which are neutral to Ice Beam, as well as Psychic-types such as Jynx, but this coverage is already accomplished by Hidden Power Fire, and if ran over Ice Beam, it leaves Gorebyss walled by Dragon-types such as Drampa and Altaria. Finally, Psychic can be run alongside Hidden Power Fire for almost perfect neutral coverage, but this leaves Gorebyss struggling more against certain bulky Water-types such as Lanturn.

Checks and Counters

Choice Scarf Users: Choice Scarf users such as Primeape, Dodrio, Rotom-F, and Alolan Raichu can still outspeed and OHKO Gorebyss even after a Shell Smash or with some chip damage if Gorebyss is using White Herb.

Bulky Water-types: Lanturn and Poliwrath can take a hit, even when Gorebyss is at +2, and take little from Hydro Vortex, and they KO Gorebyss with Volt Switch or force it out with Circle Throw, respectively. However, Gorebyss can 2HKO both with +2 Hidden Power Grass. Pyukumuku ignores the stat boosts of Shell Smash thanks to Unaware and can stall Gorebyss with Toxic, but it can be stopped by Substitute. If Gorebyss is not running Hidden Power Grass, Gastrodon can take a hit before retaliating with Toxic or dealing a good amount of damage with Earth Power, but it is 2HKOed by Ice Beam.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: If Gorebyss is not running Waterium Z, certain specially defensive Pokemon such as Eelektross, Type: Null, Audino, and Clefairy can take a hit before KOing Gorebyss with Volt Switch or Return, or crippling it with Toxic or Thunder Wave in order to stop its sweep. Audino and Clefairy can be played around with Substitute. However, even without Waterium Z, they do not appreciate taking a +2 Hydro Pump and can still be KOed in situations with previous damage. Substitute and Hidden Power Fire can give Ferroseed trouble, which can otherwise take a hit and whittle Gorebyss down with a combination of Leech Seed, Protect, and Gyro Ball and cripple it with a potential Thunder Wave.

Priority Users: If Gorebyss has taken a good amount of damage in the process of setting up and sweeping, priority users such as Skuntank, Kangaskhan, Hitmonchan, and Shiftry can come in to KO Gorebyss without having to fear being outsped. This is especially easy if Gorebyss is at -1 defenses.

Taunt and Encore Users: Faster Taunt users such as Skuntank, Sableye, and Alolan Persian can stop Gorebyss from being able to set up a Shell Smash, and either switch into a better matchup, cripple it with Thunder Wave, Toxic, or Will-O-Wisp, or go for a KO. However, none of them appreciate taking Hydro Vortex. Both Liepard and Volbeat can lock Gorebyss into Shell Smash with Encore while not minding the Speed boost due to Prankster, although they must stay wary that Gorebyss can bypass this for one turn using its Z-Move.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description:
Moves

Ice Beam gives Gorebyss coverage against Grass- and Dragon-types such as Victreebel, Drampa, and Altaria, which resist Hydro Pump. Hidden Power Grass hits Water-types such as Gastrodon, and can 2HKO other bulky Water-types such as Lanturn and Poliwrath after a Shell Smash. However, if running a Timid nature, Gorebyss can often fail to 2HKO Lanturn. Hidden Power Fire is an alternate option that gives Gorebyss a way to hit Jynx as well as certain Grass-types that only take neutral damage from Ice Beam, such as Ferroseed and Abomasnow. Substitute is another choice for the last slot, which protects Gorebyss from status moves such as Thunder Wave and Toxic, giving it a better matchup against special walls such as Clefairy and Audino. If Gorebyss can maintain its Substitute, it can also grant a layer of protection against Choice Scarf users such as Primeape. It is also notable that, when using a White Herb, Gorebyss can use Substitute on Ferroseed and essentially use it as setup fodder, as Ferroseed fails to break Gorebyss's Substitute with Gyro Ball when Gorebyss is at neutral defenses, even with +2 Speed.

Set Details

Modest is the preferred nature, as it allows Gorebyss to do as much damage as possible and break through bulkier foes such as Lanturn and Audino more easily. Timid is an alternate option that allows Gorebyss to outspeed a few more Pokemon, most notably Choice Scarf Kabutops. However, this is much more situational overall, as Gorebyss prefers the additional damage output when attempting to sweep. Waterium Z gives Gorebyss an accurate, one-time nuke, which is specifically useful for taking on specially defensive Pokemon such as Clefairy and Audino. Alternatively, White Herb negates the lowered defenses from Shell Smash, which allows Gorebyss to better take hits from faster Pokemon and priority users such as Primeape and Skuntank when sweeping, making it more difficult to offensively stop once it sets up. However, be wary that the White Herb can be unintentionally activated through other means such as Intimidate. Although neither of Gorebyss’s abilities benefit it in most occasions, Swift Swim gives it a better matchup against rain teams and allows it to function decently well on said rain teams.

Usage Tips

As a sweeper, Gorebyss can come in late-game, after its potential threats have been taken care of or at least crippled so it can ideally set up and sweep, potentially closing out the match. These threats include Choice Scarf users such as Primeape and Dodrio and bulkier Pokemon such as Lanturn and Clefairy, especially if Gorebyss is not running Waterium Z. When being used as a wallbreaker, Gorebyss should be used mid- to late-game, using its high Special Attack and the Shell Smash boosts to break down bulkier foes such as Regirock and Tangela so that a teammate can come in and have an easier time cleaning the match afterwards. Gorebyss should be brought onto the field through a slow pivot such as Eelektross's Volt Switch or a Memento user such as Alolan Dugtrio in order to maintain as much health as possible. Gorebyss should set up against Pokemon that can do little to it, such as Audino, as they are forced out and can be used as setup fodder. If a Pokemon is Choice locked into a resisted move, such as Choice Scarf Alolan Sandslash locked into Icicle Crash, Gorebyss can also use it to set up a Shell Smash. However, be wary that they can do a decent amount of damage, so Gorebyss should often only use it to set up one Shell Smash at most.

Team Options

Wallbreakers such as Lycanroc, Alolan Raichu, and Drampa can break down the bulky Pokemon that give Gorebyss trouble, such as Type: Null and Ferroseed, and Gorebyss can clean up for them in return. Faster Pokemon such as Primeape and Dodrio appreciate Gorebyss's ability to serve as a wallbreaker, as it can help weaken Pokemon that can stop them, such as Musdale and Gurdurr, before they come in to clean. Entry hazard setters such as Regirock, Ferroseed, and Qwilfish can also help against bulky foes like Type: Null, as the residual damage can potentially whittle them down to the point where Gorebyss can KO them. Type: Null can also support Gorebyss with a slow U-turn, which can serve as a reliable way to get Gorebyss on the field. Musharna can support Gorebyss with Healing Wish, which can potentially give it a second chance to set up and sweep. Regirock and Ferroseed can also provide support in Thunder Wave, which can cripple Choice Scarf users such as Primeape and Dodrio and allow Gorebyss to outspeed them after a Shell Smash. Choice Scarf users can also be crippled by Knock Off users, such as Gurdurr, Alolan Raticate, and Absol. Knock Off can furthermore be used as a way to cripple certain bulky Pokemon, such as Assault Vest holders like Eelektross and Eviolite holders like Clefairy. Eelektross is a good Knock Off user, slow pivot, and check to certain Choice Scarf users that can revenge kill Gorebyss, such as Haunter and Oricorio-G. Gorebyss does not like to be whittled down by entry hazards because it needs to stay as healthy as possible in order to sweep, so it appreciates Defog and Rapid Spin users such as Skuntank, Hitmonchan, and Lurantis to remove the hazards. Memento users such as Alolan Dugtrio and Skuntank can bring Gorebyss without it having to take any damage in the process. They also weaken the opposing Pokemon, making it more easy for Gorebyss to set up a Shell Smash on them. Dual screen users such as Electrode can also give Gorebyss an easier time setting up. Gorebyss can be used on rain teams, in which Rain Dance users such as Volbeat and Liepard and other rain sweepers such as Ludicolo and Kabutops are appreciated.

Relicanth.overview: Relicanth faces stiff competition from the other offensive Rock-types such as Kabutops, Carracosta, and Lycanroc. Relicanth is held back by its low Speed and a middling base 90 Attack stat, not hitting as hard as other wallbreakers, especially Aggron. Relicanth's poor special bulk and common weaknesses also hold it back. Additionally, Relicanth struggles with many common Pokemon in the metagame such as Torterra and Gastrodon, limiting its effectiveness as a wallbreaker.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This set attempts to act as a wallbreaker using a Relicanth's access to a powerful STAB move in Head Smash with a Choice Band. However, Relicanth is mostly outclassed by Aggron as a Rock-type Choice Band user due to its superior Attack stat and typing. Relicanth also competes with other offensive Water / Rock types such as Kabutops and Carracosta, the former of which is faster and both of which have access to priority with Aqua Jet and the ability to boost their stats with Swords Dance and Shell Smash.

Luvdisc.overview: Sadly, there is no reason to use the unviable Luvdisc over other Water-types such as Ludicolo, Kabutops, and Omastar. While it has a nice ability in Swift Swim backed with a nice Speed stat, it lacks the firepower to make use of it, often making it dead weight. It also sports a pitiful bulk, leaving it vulnerable to common priority moves, such as Mach Punch and Sucker Punch.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description: With this set, Luvdisc tries to fulfill the role of a rain sweeper. However, this is better accomplished by Ludicolo, since it sports a better offensive typing and hits significantly harder than Luvdisc while also being able to set up rain for itself more easily due to its higher bulk.
