Team Options

Fast Pokemon such as Floatzel and setup sweepers such as Alolan Raichu, Carracosta, and Lycanroc appreciate Abomasnow's ability to break down bulkier foes such as Regirock and Eelektross so that they can more easily clean late-game. Fire-type checks such as Silvally-Dragon and Lanturn can help against Pokemon such as Simisear that can give Abomasnow trouble. Fighting-types such as Primeape and Hitmonchan can also give Abomasnow issues, so Pokemon such as Jellicent, Oricorio-G, and Silvally-Fairy can come in handy. Slow pivots such as Eelektross and Lanturn can take hits in order to bring Abomasnow in safely. Stealth Rock and other entry hazards work well with hail to whittle down foes such as Regirock and Lanturn, making them easier for Abomasnow to break through. Good examples of hazard setters include Mudsdale and Qwilfish. Conversely, Abomasnow dislikes having to take damage from entry hazards, especially Stealth Rock, so hazard removers such as Skuntank and Hitmonchan can keep Abomasnow healthy. Finally, Abomasnow can form a decent core with Alolan Sandslash, which takes advantage of Snow Warning thanks to Slush Rush, can remove entry hazards for Abomasnow using Rapid Spin, and breaks through certain special walls such as Clefairy. In return, Abomasnow can break through certain physical walls like Jellicent.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Blizzard is Abomasnow's strongest STAB option, and it hits Pokemon such as Dodrio and Oricorio-E super effectively. Giga Drain is Abomasnow's Grass-type STAB attack that gives it a form of recovery and hits some Pokemon that resist Blizzard such as Jellicent, Kabutops, and Aurorus. Focus Blast gives Abomasnow coverage for Steel-types like Alolan Sandslash that would otherwise wall Abomasnow. Earthquake hits Fire-types such as Simisear and Combusken and can hit Steel-types like Aggron more reliably than Focus Blast. It also allows Abomasnow to 2HKO physically frail Pokemon such as Jynx. Energy Ball can be run over Giga Drain for slightly more power, but Abomasnow prefers the ability to regain health.

Set Details

252 EVs in Special Attack and Speed maximize Abomasnow's offensive presence. A Choice Scarf, when combined with a Naive nature, allows Abomasnow to outspeed everything under base 115 Speed, such as Oricorio-E, and it also lets Abomasnow outspeed some boosted Pokemon such as +2 Carracosta. Snow Warning, on top of giving Blizzard perfect accuracy, can be used to stop opposing weathers, which lets Abomasnow revenge kill weather sweepers such as Kabutops and Shiftry. A Naive nature is used so that Abomasnow does not weaken Earthquake and takes decreased damage from priority attacks such as Lycanroc's Accelerock.

Usage Tips

With a Choice Scarf, Abomasnow can serve as a decently fast wallbreaker; it is especially effective against hyper offensive teams, as they often struggle to have a reliable switch-in for Abomasnow's attacks. It does well against weather-based teams, as it can be brought in on a free switch or on a predicted move like Swords Dance on Pokemon such as Kabutops and Leafeon. By negating the weather, Abomasnow is able to outspeed them and pick up the KO. Its Speed also allows Abomasnow to serve as an overall decent revenge killer and cleaner. On top of being brought in after a teammate is KOed, it can also be brought in with the help of a slow pivot such as Eelektross or Lanturn. These methods are used to bring Abomasnow in because it is rather frail and needs to stay healthy to perform its role optimally. Your opponent can struggle to predict Abomasnow's item from Team Preview, so it can take advantage of this to lure in otherwise faster threats such as Simisear that would generally stay in against it or come in to revenge kill it. However, be wary that without an item that boosts its power, Abomasnow's damage output can be somewhat underwhelming at times, and it often requires foes to be weakened before it can KO them. Also be aware that once Abomasnow's Choice Scarf has been revealed, it becomes much easier for the opponent to play around.

Team Options

Setup sweepers such as Oricorio-G and Alolan Raticate appreciate Abomasnow's ability to lure in and take out faster threats such as Dodrio. In return, these setup sweepers can weaken the opposing team before Abomasnow comes in to clean. Wallbreakers like Simisear are also good partners for this reason. Alolan Raticate can also support Abomasnow by using Knock Off on faster Choice Scarf users like Skuntank and Alolan Sandslash. Entry hazard setters such as Mudsdale and Golurk can help whittle down the opposing team, making it even easier for Abomasnow to clean. Eelektross is another good partner that can support Abomasnow with Knock Off and bring it in safely with a slow Volt Switch. While Abomasnow can serve as a decent revenge killer and cleaner, it is not the best way to keep faster foes in check, so teams may want a second Choice Scarf user to more reliably fulfill that role, such as Primeape. Due to its weakness to Stealth Rock and other hazards, Abomasnow appreciates having a form of hazard removal on its team, such as Skuntank or Silvally-Fairy.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Swords Dance boosts Abomasnow's Attack stat, allowing it to more easily break through certain walls such as Clefairy and Eelektross. Wood Hammer serves as Abomasnow's main Grass-type STAB attack, hitting Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types such as Carracosta, Regirock, and Mudsdale, although using it comes at the cost of taking a good amount of recoil. Bloom Doom coming from Wood Hammer more easily breaks through bulky foes such as Gurdurr and Type: Null, and it also ignores the recoil of Wood Hammer. Seed Bomb is an alternate option over Wood Hammer when running a Life Orb because it does not deal additional recoil damage. Ice Shard is Abomasnow's best way to make up for its lackluster Speed; it hits Pokemon such as Dodrio and Oricorio-G and can be decently powerful when combined with a Swords Dance boost. Earthquake hits Steel-types such as Aggron and Probopass, which can otherwise take any attack except +2 Bloom Doom. It can also be used to hit faster Fire- and Steel-types such as Simisear and Alolan Sandslash on the switch. Blizzard is an alternative option that can serve as a decently powerful Ice-type STAB attack; in particular, it hits physically bulky Pokemon like Tangela and Lurantis that would otherwise wall Abomasnow. However, this leaves it much more vulnerable to Fire- and Steel-types.

Set Details

252 EVs in Attack and Speed allow Abomasnow to more easily sweep and break through walls. A Jolly or Hasty nature enables Abomasnow to outspeed Pokemon such as Timid Aurorus and Jolly Golurk. While a Jolly nature is run when using Earthquake, a Hasty nature is used alongside Blizzard to maximize its power. An Adamant or Lonely nature can be run to further raise Abomasnow’s Attack, but this leaves it unable to outspeed the aforementioned Aurorus and Golurk. Grassium Z with Wood Hammer lets Abomasnow use a 190-Base Power Bloom Doom, which lacks the recoil of Wood Hammer and can break past walls like Type: Null. If the team has another Z-Move user, Abomasnow can instead run a Life Orb to boost its overall power. It is run along with Seed Bomb, as Wood Hammer's recoil would otherwise stack with the Life Orb's.

Usage Tips

Abomasnow should take advantage of the Attack boost from Swords Dance to break through bulkier Pokemon such as Clefairy and Musharna so a teammate can come in to clean up. Through a combination of Swords Dance and Ice Shard, Abomasnow can also serve as a decent late-game cleaner, and it can also be used as a setup sweeper, ideally after threats such as Primeape and Stoutland have been KOed or at least put in range of Ice Shard. Abomasnow should set up against bulkier Pokemon that can do little to it, such as Claydol and Audino, although it should stay wary of moves such as Encore and Toxic. Abomasnow can also take advantage of its overall unpredictability to lure in certain Pokemon that can give its other sets trouble such as Clefairy and Type: Null, and it can scare away Pokemon that can deal with the Swords Dance set, such as Tangela. If running Blizzard, Abomasnow can further attempt to bluff its mixed wallbreaker set. Even without a Swords Dance boost, Abomasnow can still put a dent in the opponent's team due to the high Base Power of Wood Hammer and Blizzard, and it can serve as a decent revenge killer with Ice Shard. Abomasnow should be brought onto the field with the help of a slow pivot such as Eelektross or Lanturn, after a teammate has been KOed, or against a predicted non-damaging move such as Clefairy's Stealth Rock or Soft-Boiled.

Team Options

Fast Pokemon such as Alolan Persian appreciate Abomasnow's ability to weaken specially defensive walls that give them trouble such as Gastrodon and Audino, while they in return can help clean up weakened Pokemon and break down physical walls that can potentially stop Abomasnow from sweeping, such as Tangela and Sableye. Thunder Wave users such as Regirock and Clefairy can help cripple faster threats such as Primeape and Floatzel, allowing Abomasnow to outspeed them, but be aware that Abomasnow needs to run a positive Speed nature to outspeed a paralyzed Choice Scarf Primeape. Regirock and Clefairy can also help wear the opponent's team down with Stealth Rock and can serve as soft checks for Fire-types. Probopass stacks a weakness to Fighting-type attacks, but it can serve as a slow pivot and can trap Steel-types that give Abomasnow trouble, such as Alolan Sandslash. Due to Abomasnow's weakness to entry hazards, Pokemon that can provide hazard removal such as Skuntank and Silvally-Water are also appreciated.

Lickilicky.overview: Lickilicky might look good to use on stall teams because it has good bulk, keeps its teammates healthy with Wish, and gets rid of status with Heal Bell without worrying about Taunt users thanks to Oblivious. However, Lickilicky is outclassed by Audino, which takes advantage of Regenerator to recover its own HP upon switching out while passing Wish to a teammate.

sets.name: Wish
sets.description: Lickilicky can pass Wish to its teammates while crippling Pokemon with Toxic, healing its teammates from status with Heal Bell, and phazing Pokemon with Dragon Tail. Lickilicky has a small niche in Oblivious that makes it immune to Taunt from common Pokemon like Qwilfish and Jellicent. However, even with this, Audino can do this job better due to having a better ability in Regenerator that keeps it healthy while passing Wish to its teammates.

Electivire.overview: Electivire is a mixed wallbreaker with great coverage options and a Speed tier that permits it to outspeed and revenge kill common slower wallbreakers like Omastar, Oricorio-G, and Aurorus. Since there are so many different possibilities in terms of sets and coverage moves, Electivire can be unpredictable, though many of its options aren't usually as viable. Despite its offensive prowess, its frailty and middling Speed make it susceptible to faster attackers such as Lycanroc, Choice Scarf users like Primeape and Dodrio, and priority moves such as Kangaskhan's Fake Out and Skuntank's Sucker Punch. Regardless of its impressive Attack, it struggles to break through physical walls, thus forcing it to rely on its weaker Special Attack in some cases. Since its Special Attack is nothing to write home about, it relies on super effective moves specifically designed to break its checks, thus failing to handle those neutral to its attacks such as Clefairy and defensive Spiritomb. It also faces harsh competition from fellow Electric-types, the most noteworthy being Eelektross, which totally eclipses Electivire besides having much lower Speed and lacking niche coverage moves like Earthquake. Other superior Electric-types include Rotom-F, which can break down Ground-types like Mudsdale with Blizzard and cripple other defensive switch-ins with Trick, and Alolan Raichu, which can break past specially defensive switch-ins like Clefairy with Psyshock, and can outpace base 95s that Electivire runs the risk of having to Speed tie with such as Primeape and Jynx.
Electivire.comments:
Other Options

Expert Belt is plausible due to Electivire's impressive coverage, giving it the ability to bluff a Choice item without causing any recoil, which can improve Electivire's longevity. In spite of this, it misses out on a lot of power for its neutral attacks that could make or break the KO, failing to 2HKO Hitmonchan with Earthquake as noted earlier. Choice Band turns Electivire into a dangerous physical wallbreaker, enabling it to break through certain walls such as Regirock and Musharna, but it sacrifices the ability to switch between moves, undermining its role and overall value. Moreover, Electivire is reliant on special coverage to hit Ferroseed and Tangela, and it isn't appealing to lock Electivire into any of its moves, as they either have sufficient Pokemon resistant to immune to them or are relatively weak. Choice Scarf Electivire can be a good offensive pivot with Volt Switch, but it compromises power and, once again, the ability to switch between coverage moves. It is also largely overshadowed by Rotom-F, which has much stronger BoltBeam coverage and access to Trick to cripple its counters. Fightinium Z with Focus Blast can KO Regirock after a little prior damage, but this sacrifices Electivire's overall power and is mediocre due to its one-time use. Similarly, Fightinium Z with Cross Chop can be used to lure specially defensive Audino, guaranteeing the OHKO after Stealth Rock damage with 40 Attack EVs and having an 80% chance to do so without investment. This also allows Electivire to break down Eelektross and Type: Null easier. Alas, it is very situational and surrenders the overall power boost from Life Orb. Z-Electric Terrain can boost Electivire's Speed by 1.5x and strengthen its Electric-type moves, but again it loses a valuable coverage move and requires a turn to set up, which is challenging due to Electivire's middling bulk. Wild Charge can 2HKO Clefairy but is otherwise an inconsistent STAB option that compounds recoil considerably if combined with Life Orb. Hidden Power Grass can 2HKO Ground-types like Golurk and Gastrodon but fails to do enough damage to others like Mudsdale and is otherwise a second-rate coverage move.

Checks and Counters

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Electivire is troubled by specially defensive walls neutral to its attacks such as Eelektross, Clefairy, Musharna, and Hitmonchan. Eelektross, thanks to its ability Levitate, is immune to Earthquake and can comfortably take Electivire's coverage moves, threatening to respond with Knock Off. Clefairy and Musharna will only get 3HKOed by any of Electivire's moves and can provide clerical support, set up with Calm Mind, or stall it out with their respective healing moves. However, Electivire can 2HKO Hitmonchan with Earthquake.

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Torterra, Golurk, and Mudsdale are particularly threatening, as they can take any one move and will OHKO back with STAB Earthquake. In addition, Alolan Dugtrio can outspeed and OHKO with Earthquake but can only come in on a predicted Electric-type attack or free turn.

Faster Pokemon: Lycanroc, Simisear, Floatzel, and Choice Scarf users such as Primeape can comfortably net the OHKO or 2HKO with their STAB attacks due to Electivire's subpar defenses. However, they must be wary of Electivire's strong attacks in return.

Priority Moves: Because Electivire has a relatively low Defense stat, it is susceptible to STAB priority moves including Kangaskhan's Fake Out, Hitmonchan's Mach Punch, and Skuntank's Sucker Punch.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
Moves

Volt Switch allows Electivire to serve as an offensive pivot, switching out of bulkier foes such as Gurdurr and gaining momentum on the Pokemon it checks. Thunderbolt does noticeably more damage but fails to generate any sort of momentum. Flamethrower hits Grass-types like Tangela and Victreebel that resist Electivire's STAB move for super effective damage. Earthquake hits specially defensive tanks that would otherwise counter the set such as Lanturn and Probopass, 2HKOing the former and OHKOing the latter. It can OHKO Skuntank and 2HKO Hitmonchan with Earthquake after Stealth Rock, giving Electivire a slight niche over its nemesis Eelektross. Focus Blast will hit Normal-type tanks such as Audino and Type: Null for super effective damage, yet it is highly unreliable because of its bad accuracy. Alternatively, Ice Punch goes well with Electivire's STAB move, creating a variation of BoltBeam coverage that can hit the entire tier at least neutrally. It threatens offensive Ground-types like Golurk and can OHKO Altaria and offensive Torterra.

Set Details

A Naive nature is preferred over Hasty, as a Naive nature makes Electivire less vulnerable to priority moves like Mach Punch and Sucker Punch, and it doesn't decrease either of its attacking stats, permitting it to hit as hard as possible. Life Orb gives it a much-needed power boost to achieve certain KOs while still allowing it to switch between moves. With a Life Orb, Electivire can 2HKO Hitmonchan with Earthquake, OHKO Victreebel with Flamethrower, OHKO Aurorus with Earthquake, and 2HKO Audino with Focus Blast after Stealth Rock. Motor Drive makes Electivire immune to and enables it to benefit from Electric-type moves, giving it a +1 Speed boost and turning it into a much more imposing wallbreaker that can efficiently KO faster Pokemon like Floatzel. Vital Spirit is another viable option, as it prevents Electivire from being afflicted by sleep-inducing moves such as Jynx's Lovely Kiss and Tangela's Sleep Powder.

Usage Tips

Electivire should primarily be used as a revenge killer and wallbreaker. It can quickly dispose of slower threats such as Skuntank and Aurorus after a bit of prior damage while using super effective moves to get past bulkier Pokemon like Lanturn. Given its tendency to be worn down easily by Life Orb recoil and entry hazard damage, Electivire should be used rather sparingly. Try to bring it in freely after a teammate has fainted or on a free switch-in from U-turn or Volt Switch, as its lackluster overall bulk inhibits its ability to switch into neutral attacks. Electivire can be an effective offensive pivot if it is running Volt Switch, as it can pivot out of unfavorable matchups against tanks like Musharna. Since Electivire has varied super effective coverage, it can often force the opponent to switch, which is an ideal opportunity to create offensive momentum. When brought into a Pokemon that it checks, try to predict by going for the appropriate coverage move that could possibly OHKO or 2HKO the switch-in. For instance, if the opponent plans to bring in Golurk to absorb an Electric-type attack, go for Ice Punch instead to put into KO range. If running Motor Drive, anticipate and come in on Volt Switch from pivots such as Lanturn and Eelektross, disrupting the momentum and simultaneously boosting Electivire's Speed. In contrast, Vital Spirit can be utilized to protect a fellow team member from a Sleep Powder from Tangela and Lovely Kiss from Jynx.

Team Options

Because of its ample coverage choices, Electivire compresses its role and fits well on teams that require a wallbreaker to pressure the slower Pokemon that Electivire punishes, such as Lanturn & Oricorio-G. Stealth Rock greatly helps Electivire to net the OHKO on Pokemon that would normally be able to tank at least one hit. For example, after Stealth Rock damage, Electivire can guarantee the KO on Victreebel with Flamethrower and on Skuntank and Aurorus with Earthquake. Common setters include Torterra, Mudsdale, and Regirock, all of which enjoy Electivire's capacity to check offensive threats like Victreebel. Grass-types make great partners because of exceptional type synergy. Ludicolo and Lurantis can set up on or threaten the Ground-types that check Electivire including Torterra and Mudsdale. In return, Electivire can stomach a Supersonic Skystrike from Oricorio-G or Swanna and terrorize them with an Electric-type STAB move. Electivire appreciates the destructive potential of common physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan and Stoutland. Strong physical attackers can deal with most special walls but are especially good at eliminating Electivire's counter and greatest enemy: Eelektross, as well as Clefairy since both can effectively wall Electivire. Other wallbreakers that benefit from Electivire's role as a pivot include Zangoose, Absol, and Oricorio-G, all of which can manage its counters. They in turn value Electivire's support to wear down bulkier Pokemon like Aggron and Lanturn. Entry hazard removal is necessary to preserve Electivire's health. Rapid Spin support is optimal, as it does not remove the user's hazards that Electivire so desperately needs to net KOs. On the other hand, since there are many more viable Defoggers in the tier such as Silvally-Fairy, Swanna, and Skuntank, Defog is a solid alternative. Electivire can create a VoltTurn core with Pokemon such as Scyther and Primeape to further pressure the opponent's team.

Probopass.overview: Access to Magnet Pull gives Probopass a slight niche in PU, as thanks to this ability, it can remove several bulky Steel-types from the match, such as Aggron, Metang, and Alolan Sandslash. 4x resistances to Normal and Flying are quite useful, as they allow Probopass to, for example, switch in on a Choice Band Stoutland locked into Return and an Oricorio-E's Hurricane. Probopass has a surprisingly customizable movepool, with very useful utility and coverage options such as Taunt to cripple slower walls, Earth Power for Steel-types, and Volt Switch for pivoting working very well with it. Defensively speaking, though, its 4x weaknesses to Fighting and Ground severely hamper its viability, as both types are very common in the metagame in the forms of Pokemon such as Golurk, Torterra, and Gurdurr. It also can be hit very hard by coverage moves of these types used by Pokemon that Probopass otherwise would check, such as Kangaskhan, Stoutland, and Aurorus. Probopass has no reliable recovery, making it prone to getting worn down fast against opposing teams. Even when fully invested, Probopass is often embarrassingly weak against a lot of neutral targets. However, its biggest issue is simply that trapping Steel-types is not an especially valuable niche in PU.
Probopass.comments:
Other Options

Toxic is an option to catch Gastrodon on the switch, which otherwise completely stops Probopass in its tracks. It can be used to cripple Pokemon such as Musharna as well, which is particularly useful because Synchronize cannot affect Probopass. However, Probopass's four-moveslot syndrome means that Toxic has a hard time being fit, as Probopass's moves are all very important to its success. A more defensive set with Sturdy is usable, but for the most part it's outclassed by Regirock, which has better offensive presence and a better typing. It also lacks Probopass's main niche as a trapper. Pain Split gives Probopass a form, albeit an unreliable one, of recovery. It fits more on bulkier sets, but such sets are less practical in general and as mentioned before Pain Split is a very unreliable way of recovery that can easily be played around.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Air Balloon can somewhat help Probopass's poor matchup against Ground-types, but Leftovers variants are easily KOed by strong Earthquakes from Pokemon such as Golurk, Mudsdale, and Torterra. In addition, it needs the right coverage move to deal a decent amount of damage to these Pokemon, which is somewhat hampered by Probopass's four-moveslot syndrome.

Fighting-types: Probopass's 4x weakness to Fighting coupled with a lack of firepower against them leads to it being countered by the likes of Primeape, Gurdurr, and Hitmonchan, which can revenge kill it, set up on it, or easily remove its entry hazards, respectively.

Water-types: Pokemon such as Lanturn, Ludicolo, Jellicent, and Gastrodon can easily switch into Probopass and hit back with Scald or similar moves. Lanturn and Gastrodon are also immune to Volt Switch.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Moves

Flash Cannon is Probopass's STAB move of choice, allowing it to hit Pokemon such as Aurorus and Clefairy for super effective damage. Hidden Power Fire is used to target Steel-type Pokemon that Probopass traps, most notably Alolan Sandslash, but also others such as Ferroseed. Taunt allows Probopass to cripple slower, more passive Pokemon such as Type: Null and Musharna. Earth Power can alternatively be used in the last slot to hit Alolan Raichu and opposing Probopass super effectively. Volt Switch is an option that allows Probopass to pivot around a lot of its common checks. This is particularly useful when combined with Probopass's low base Speed. Power Gem is an alternative STAB move that targets Flying-types such as Oricorio-E and Fire-types such as Simisear, although it can't hit Rock-types such as Regirock super effectively.

Set Details

84 Speed EVs allow Probopass to outspeed uninvested base 50s and under such as Regirock. Magnet Pull is Probopass's main niche in the tier and as such is chosen for this set. It allows Probopass to trap Steel-types for the player's team, mainly the likes of Alolan Sandslash, Ferroseed, and Metang. Air Balloon allows Probopass to trap Choice Scarf Alolan Sandslash far more reliably, as well as slightly deterring Earthquake users such as Pinsir and walling Mudsdale without Rock Slide. However, Leftovers are a valid alternative if using Probopass in a more defensive capacity where longevity is preferred.

Usage Tips

Probopass's main niche is trapping Steel-type Pokemon. Because of this, it's rather easy for the opponent to predict the switching of Probopass into their Steel-type and immediately switch out. Thus, finding the right opportunity to switch Probopass into other Steel-types is crucial to its success in a match. This can be done by either double switching or pivoting Probopass in using either Volt Switch or U-turn. Be cautious when playing against Pokemon known for having Ground or Fighting-type coverage, such as Earthquake Kangaskhan and Jump Kick Dodrio. Due to the threat of such coverage, it shouldn't be treated as a Normal- or Flying-type check for the team. Probopass is quite weak and one-dimensional, so after it successfully removes opposing Steel-types from the match and sets up Stealth Rock, it can often become dead weight or even setup fodder for Pokemon such as Ludicolo. It is highly recommended to avoid recklessly switching Probopass in. Volt Switch variants should pivot on checks, would-be or otherwise, to Probopass like defensive Carracosta and Gurdurr. They also should be wary of using the move when the opponent has a Ground-type still active. Use Taunt to shut down setup or recovery from Pokemon such as Calm Mind Oricorio-E and Type: Null.

Team Options

Pokemon that struggle with Steel-types will appreciate Probopass's ability to take them on reliably. These include Type: Null, Clefairy, and physically offensive variants of Skuntank. Probopass offers very handy resistances to both Flying and Psychic, and there are many Pokemon in PU vulnerable to either of these types. Examples of these include Qwilfish for more defensive builds and Primeape and Pinsir for more offensive ones. Volt Switch variants can be paired with powerful wallbreakers that are hard to get in such as Crabominable and Drampa due to the fact that Probopass's Volt Switch is slow and therefore very reliable in getting the aforementioned Pokemon in. Volt Switch variants also like being paired with other Volt Switch users such as Eelektross and Lanturn or U-turn users such as Primeape to form VoltTurn cores. Eelektross in particular also helps against the Water-types Probopass struggles with. Even without Volt Switch on Probopass, these Pokemon can also get Probopass in on opposing Steel-types more easily, due to the fact that they are checked by common Steel-types in PU such as Metang. A Fighting-type switch-in is useful, as Probopass hates taking on such Pokemon. Examples of this include Oricorio-E, Qwilfish, and Victreebel. Likewise, Pokemon that resist or are immune to Ground such as Tangela, Haunter, and Abomasnow help dodge moves like Earthquake. Probopass can also remove Pokemon such as Alolan Sandslash that these Pokemon don't do too well against. Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Hitmonchan can also be good partners for Probopass due to their ability to reliably beat a lot of specially defensive walls that Probopass has trouble with, mainly Audino and Type: Null. Water-type checks such as Victreebel and Shiftry can help due to Probopass struggling with Pokemon such as Gastrodon and Lanturn.

Dusknoir.overview: Dusknoir is a niche spinblocker with its main attribute being its high defensive stats allowing it to switch in and spinblock with less fear of being greatly weakened. However, this niche is limited by Dusknoir's poor HP stat and lack of reliable recovery. Dusknoir's movepool is also lacking, with a lack of physical Ghost-type moves leaving it heavy reliant on Earthquake to output damage. This, alongside Dusknoir's only average Attack stat, makes it somewhat passive even when holding a Choice Band. Golurk and Spiritomb both outclass Dusknoir offensively due to their secondary typings; Golurk has a powerful STAB Earthquake and Spiritomb has access to a STAB Sucker Punch and Pursuit, with their aforementioned typings also providing more defensive utility due to the additional resistances and immunities that come with them.
Dusknoir.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb can be run over Choice Band so Dusknoir can switch between moves, but Dusknoir can't afford the recoil Life Orb comes with, and it misses the additional power from Choice Band. Sucker Punch is a slightly stronger alternative to Shadow Sneak, but it isn't a very good move to be locked into, especially against Pokemon like Lovely Kiss Jynx and Substitute Alolan Raichu, since it can give them free setup opportunities. It also notably can't be used alongside Frisk. Pursuit can trap foes that try to switch out on Dusknoir, specifically Pokemon like Kabutops locked into Rapid Spin. However, Dusknoir struggles to find space for it between its coverage moves. Dusknoir can run Shadow Punch to give it a slightly stronger STAB move, but this is weaker than Earthquake even after the STAB bonus and Dusknoir's coverage and utility options are preferable. A bulky set with Power-Up Punch can take advantage of Dusknoir's solid bulk in order to slowly set up, but Dusknoir prefers the immediate power. Furthermore, this set is outclassed by Power-Up Punch Kangaskhan, which has better Speed and offensive typing.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: If they can switch in safely, Dark-types like Skuntank, Shiftry, Alolan Raticate, and Absol can take advantage of Dusknoir, by trapping it with Pursuit or taking the opportunity to set up a Swords Dance as Dusknoir is forced out, without much fear of being revenge killed later on by Shadow Sneak. However, all of these Pokemon take heavy damage from Dusknoir's coverage moves, with Skuntank and Shiftry in particular fearing Earthquake and Ice Punch respectively. Sableye can switch into any of Dusknoir's attacks and cripple it with Will-O-Wisp, before recovering any lost HP. Alolan Persian is also notable as its Z-Crystal makes it immune to Trick and can easily use Dusknoir to gain momentum with Parting Shot or set up with Nasty Plot.

Physical Walls: Pokemon like Tangela, Ferroseed, and Gurdurr can all switch into Dusknoir's attacks with ease, although they are greatly crippled by Trick. However, if they do manage to come in, they can cripple Dusknoir with Leech Seed, Toxic, or Knock Off. Gurdurr can also use Dusknoir as setup fodder for Bulk Up and Ferroseed can set up Stealth Rock or Spikes. Others like Regirock and Mudsdale can also switch into most attacks and use Dusknoir to set up Stealth Rock but take a respectable amount of damage from Dusknoir's coverage moves.

Normal-types: Stoutland and Kangaskhan are immune to Shadow Sneak and do not mind Trick, so they can often switch in and hit Dusknoir with their Normal-type STAB moves thanks to Scrappy. Other Normal-types like Zangoose, Ursaring, and Dodrio may not be able to hit Dusknoir with their Normal-type STAB moves but have coverage or a secondary typing that allows them to hit it. They can also use Dusknoir as setup fodder while not having to worry about being revenge killed because of their immunity to Shadow Sneak. However, the first two are easily worn down and the latter is OHKOed by Ice Punch.

Wallbreakers: Dusknoir's lack of recovery, low Speed and limited set of resistances gives it an unfortunate vulnerability to many wallbreakers in the tier. Aggron and Drampa can both finish off Dusknoir from full health, though others like Aurorus and Victreebel require Dusknoir to be chipped into range beforehand. However, none of these Pokemon can reliably switch directly into Dusknoir due to its strong coverage options, and both Aurorus and Drampa are crippled by Trick.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Moves

Earthquake, despite not being a STAB move, is Dusknoir's strongest move. It is notably its best way to hit Skuntank and two of the most common Rapid Spin users in Alolan Sandslash and Kabutops. Shadow Sneak attempts to make up for Dusknoir's low Speed in order to pick up KOs on weakened or frail Pokemon such as Haunter and Jynx. Ice Punch hits Flying-types like Oricorio-E and Dodrio and Grass-types like Torterra and Victreebel. Trick lets Dusknoir cripple defensive Pokemon that would otherwise wall it such as Tangela and Ferroseed.

Set Details

44 Speed EVs allow Dusknoir to outspeed uninvested base 50 Speed Pokemon like Regirock and Audino, notably allowing it to get off Trick on them before they can move.

Usage Tips

Dusknoir's main goal throughout the game is to switch into Rapid Spin users like Kabutops and Alolan Sandslash to keep hazards on the field. It can also switch into other moves it resists or is immune to such as Roselia's Sludge Bomb and Primeape's Close Combat. However, Dusknoir has to watch out for coverage like Kabutops's Knock Off and support moves like Alolan Sandslash's Toxic. Dusknoir also serves as a wallbreaker, although it's somewhat unreliable due to its passiveness at times. Because it is locked into a single move, using Dusknoir requires a lot of predicting switches. Especially watch out for Pokemon like Skuntank, which can Pursuit trap Dusknoir if you get the prediction wrong. Otherwise, Dusknoir can use Shadow Sneak to serve as a revenge killer to pick off foes like Jynx and Alolan Raichu or Trick to cripple a foe late-game when it is at low health.

Team Options

Since Dusknoir's main role is being a spinblocker, it should be on a team with entry hazard setters like Qwilfish, Roselia, Regirock, and Mudsdale. Said hazards also help weaken foes down for Dusknoir. Setup sweepers such as Lycanroc and Absol also appreciate the hazards being kept on the field, and both benefit from Dusknoir's immunity to Fighting and ability to weaken bulky Pokemon for them. Absol can also use Knock Off to remove items like Tangela's Eviolite without Dusknoir having to give away its Choice Band with Trick. Primeape can also fit into this playstyle by deterring Defog users such as Skuntank and Cryogonal from removing hazards from the field thanks to its Defiant ability. Primeape and other Fighting-types like Gurdurr and Hitmonchan are also good teammates because they can help against Dark- and Normal-types like Alolan Raticate and Stoutland, which threaten Dusknoir. Hitmonchan can also remove hazards for Dusknoir, which prevents it from being as easily worn down.

Rotom-Frost.overview: Rotom-F is a solid offensive threat by virtue of its decent stats, diverse utility movepool, and potent STAB combination that targets the majority of the tier neutrally or super effectively. Most notably, Rotom-F makes for an effective user of Defog, as it bears a fantastic matchup against common entry hazard setters such as Mudsdale and Qwilfish. Rotom-F's Speed tier is also of value, as it puts it above prominent Pokemon such as Stoutland and Skuntank, making it highly threatening against bulky offense teams without proper switch-ins. Rotom-F can also run a decent Choice Scarf set that can revenge kill a multitude of Pokemon while still utilizing its good selection of utility moves. Unfortunately, the Pokemon that do outspeed Rotom-F, such as Lycanroc, Primeape, and Simisear, are all considerable threats, as they possess super effective STAB moves against it. Additionally, while Levitate grants Rotom-F an immunity to Spikes and Toxic Spikes, a weakness to Stealth Rock combined with its low HP and inconsistent forms of recovery harms its viability as a Defog user, limiting what it can come in on if Stealth Rock is up. Lastly, though Rotom-F can pivot out of most unfavorable matchups with Volt Switch, it struggles to break past most specially bulky Pokemon such as Type: Null, Clefairy, and Audino. Lanturn notably serves as a complete stop to Rotom-F due to its resistance to Blizzard and ability to punish Volt Switch with Volt Absorb.
Rotom-Frost.comments:
Other Options

Electrium Z is a viable alternative to Icium Z that turns Thunderbolt into Gigavolt Havoc, breaking through Pokemon like Aurorus and Alolan Sandslash with much more ease. Substitute can be used in conjunction with Pain Split to avoid status and pressure bulkier teams, as it allows Rotom-F to safely recover health off of the likes of Audino and Lanturn, but having to give up Defog takes away Rotom-F's major niche. Hidden Power Fighting targets Aurorus and Alolan Sandslash similarly to Electrium Z, but it has very few targets otherwise. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Audino and Lanturn by putting them on a timer, but it provides little other use and is difficult to fit into sets.

Checks and Counters

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Dedicated special walls like Audino, Lanturn, and Type: Null take pitiful amounts of damage from Rotom-F's attacks, though they must be cautious of Trick from the Choice Scarf set. Lanturn in particular acts as a hard counter to Rotom-F, since it possesses a resistance to Blizzard and an immunity to its Electric-type moves. Assault Vest Hitmonchan and Eelektross can't take repeated hits, and the former must be cautious of Will-O-Wisp, but they can soak up any one hit from full health and retaliate with Drain Punch and Flamethrower, respectively. Hitmonchan can remove entry hazards, while Eelektross can use Volt Switch to generate momentum in the event that Rotom-F is forced out. Calm Mind Clefairy can also use Rotom-F as setup fodder, though it doesn't like taking Subzero Slammer damage beforehand.

Revenge Killers: Rotom-F sets lacking Choice Scarf fail to outpace the likes of Primeape, Lycanroc, and Simisear, which can all obliterate it with their super effective STAB moves. The latter two can potentially use their respective setup moves if they manage to force Rotom-F out.

Residual Damage: Due to Rotom-F's inconsistent forms of recovery, low HP, and weakness to Stealth Rock, it's prone to getting worn down when attempting to remove Stealth Rock with Defog.

sets.name: Offensive Defog
sets.description:
Moves

Thunderbolt works as an alternative Electric-type STAB move that doesn't force Rotom-F to switch out and has increased damage output against the likes of Jellicent and Articuno. Will-O-Wisp cripples switch-ins to Rotom-F such as Assault Vest Crabominable and Hitmonchan by causing residual damage and severely weakening their attacks. Pain Split compensates for Rotom-F's lack of reliable recovery by healing off damage against switch-ins with high HP stats like Audino and Lanturn.

Set Details

Icium Z converts Blizzard into Subzero Slammer, dealing high damage to targets like Stoutland and Gurdurr while boasting perfect accuracy. Alternatively, Iapapa Berry acts as one-time health recovery outside of Pain Split when at low health and can be activated through Stealth Rock and residual damage. Note that sets using Iapapa Berry should run the 4 remaining EVs in HP to activate the item after three rounds of Stealth Rock damage.

Usage Tips

Rotom-F finds ample opportunities to revenge kill Pokemon like Jellicent and Oricorio-G or remove entry hazards throughout most of a match. Rotom-F can pivot into moves like Mudsdale's Earthquake, as well as into weaker entry hazard setters such as Qwilfish, in order to fire off a powerful attack or remove entry hazards upon a forced switch. Avoid reckless switching if Stealth Rock is on the field, as Rotom-F can easily by worn down by it despite its role as a Defogger. However, Iapapa Berry variants of Rotom-F can periodically switch into Stealth Rock in order to activate their item and heal themselves. Volt Switch should be used generously to pivot out of Pokemon that check Rotom-F like Audino and Clefairy, dealing a slight amount of damage and providing momentum, which gives Rotom-F's team the upper hand. Rotom-F's utility moves can be used effectively against Pokemon that may attempt to pivot into it; Assault Vest Crabominable and Hitmonchan are greatly crippled by Will-O-Wisp, whereas Rotom-F can gain health off of Pokemon like Lanturn and Audino through Pain Split. Icium Z is best utilized to severely weaken or even OHKO bulkier Pokemon that Blizzard misses out on, like Eelektross and Stoutland. It's also helpful in situations where Blizzard's poor accuracy can potentially jeopardize Rotom-F's ability to take out foes such as Golurk and Drampa.

Team Options

Rotom-F can form an excellent offensive core with physical wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as Stoutland, Choice Band Skuntank, and Lycanroc, as it highly appreciates their ability to break past Clefairy and Audino and can dispatch the likes of Mudsdale and Tangela in return. Stoutland and Skuntank are notably able to chip Lanturn with Pursuit. Gurdurr can also remove the items of Pokemon like Clefairy and Lanturn with Knock Off while being a reliable switch-in to threats to Rotom-F such as Lycanroc and Hitmonchan. Pokemon like Primeape and Scyther can be paired with Rotom-F to create a VoltTurn core, increasing the amount of momentum its team has, and they can be brought in more often due to Rotom-F's ability to remove entry hazards. Rotom-F can also break down Jellicent and Oricorio-E to support these Pokemon. Other Pokemon like Alolan Persian and Type: Null similarly operate as pivots, but they can more safely bring Rotom-F into play due to the former's stat reductions and the latter's low Speed. Alolan Persian's Z-Parting Shot can also bring Rotom-F up to full health, while Type: Null can lure in Pokemon for Rotom-F to take advantage of such as Carracosta and Oricorio-G. Although somewhat counterintuitive with Defog, entry hazard setters such as Qwilfish and Omastar are capable of wearing down bulky switch-ins to Rotom-F like Audino and Lanturn while putting Pokemon like Stoutland and Abomasnow in range of Subzero Slammer. Secondary entry hazard removers such as Hitmonchan and Kabutops appreciate Rotom-F's ability to break down Pokemon like Jellicent and Tangela while compensating for its inability to use Defog in the face of threats like Simisear and Lycanroc.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Trick is able to cripple specially defensive Pokemon such as Audino, Lanturn, and Type: Null that might switch in on Rotom-F when it doesn't require the added Speed provided by the item. Defog can let Rotom-F remove entry hazards in an emergency, though the option isn't very reliable, since Rotom-F is weak to Stealth Rock and would rather not be locked in a status move most of the time.

Set Details

Choice Scarf allows Rotom-F to outspeed Pokemon like Oricorio-E, non-Choice Scarf Dodrio, and Silvally-Fairy, granting it its ability to check a big portion of the tier and function as a reliable revenge killer. A Timid nature allows Rotom-F to outspeed +2 Modest Omastar as well as other Choice Scarf users like Skuntank and Kabutops.

Usage Tips

Choice Scarf Rotom-F should try to function as a revenge killer and check to many Pokemon such as Oricorio-G, Kabutops, and Alolan Persian thanks to its unresisted coverage and formidable Speed. If the opposing team lacks a solid counter such as Lanturn or Audino, this set can be utilized early-game to soften up foes for a late-game cleaner. Rotom-F is even able to break through some less bulky specially defensive Pokemon such as Eelektross thanks to its high Special Attack and BoltBeam coverage. Since Rotom-F is able to threaten Ground-types such as Mudsdale and Golurk, predict well on when to use Blizzard and when to use Volt Switch; once you successfully predict a Ground-type switch-in by using Blizzard or those Pokemon have been removed by other teammates, Rotom-F will be able to use its Electric-type STAB moves freely. Bluffing a non-Choice Scarf set can turn Rotom-F into an even more threatening revenge killer late-game if the opposing team doesn't have a faster Choice Scarf user like Primeape or a priority user such as Gurdurr. Utilizing Trick wh​en Rotom-F doesn't re​quire the added Speed is a valuable way of crippling expected switch-ins such as Lanturn, Assault Vest Crabominable, and Cryogonal.

Team Options

Fighting-type answers such as Oricorio-E, Victreebel, and Tangela are able to check or counter Pokemon such as Gurdurr and Choice Scarf Primeape, effectively threatening some of the most common revenge killers for Choice Scarf Rotom-F. In return, Rotom-F cripples their checks like Cryogonal and Lanturn with Trick. Other pivots such as Alolan Persian, Eelektross, and Primeape can form a VoltTurn core with Rotom-F to help maintain momentum and bring in offensive threats. Pokemon such as Stoutland, Lycanroc, and Kangaskhan are able to threaten slower special walls such as Audino and Lanturn, even being able to Pursuit trap them in the case of Stoutland. In return, Rotom-F is able to threaten physical walls such as Mudsdale and Tangela, as well as being able to bring these Pokemon in safely through Volt Switch. Entry hazard setters like Mudsdale and Qwilfish are able to support Rotom-F by effectively wearing dow​n Pokemon such as Eelektross and Crabominable with Stealth Rock, Spikes, and Toxic. They're also able to counter or threaten Choice Scarf Primeape, while Rotom-F checks Pokemon such as Victreebel and Jellicent. Due to its Stealth Rock weakness, more reliable hazard removes such as Skuntank, Alolan Sandslash, and Silvally-Fairy are valuable partners for Rotom-F. Skuntank and Alolan Sandslash appreciate Rotom-F's ability to check Ground-types, while Silvally-Fairy is also able to create a VoltTurn core with Parting Shot and check Fighting-types such as Primeape and Gurdurr.​

Rotom-Fan.overview: Rotom-S has a niche because of its good defensive Electric / Flying typing, which gives it the ability to check common threats such as Oricorio-G, Gurdurr, Scyther, and Swanna. Its movepool, which includes moves such as Will-O-Wisp and Defog, gives it some more utility as a defensive Pokemon. Although it's one of the few relevant hazard removers that are immune to both Spikes and Toxic Spikes, its weakness to Stealth Rock and lack of reliable recovery hinder its ability to switch in, which interferes with its role as a Defogger. In addition, it's pressured by common hazard setters like Regirock and Focus Sash Omastar. Weaknesses to prevalent Rock- and Ice-type moves further undermine its ability to check standard Fighting-types like Primeape and Hitmonchan. Furthermore, Oricorio-E is another notable adversary; despite Oricorio-E's slightly lower bulk, Taunt is its main selling point over Rotom-S, permitting Oricorio-E to shut down defensive hazard setters such as Mudsdale – something Rotom-S cannot do. On the offensive side, it is likewise overshadowed by Oricorio-E due to the latter's access to Hurricane, Roost, Taunt, Calm Mind, as well as Defog. As an offensive pivot, it is outclassed by Eelektross and Rotom-F, which have more coverage options that can be used to threaten counters. As a result of its numerous flaws, Rotom-S is often considered to be an unconventional Electric-type pick in general, but it finds a small place in the tier with its typing and defensive capability. It also faces competition from Lanturn, as Lanturn has an immunity to Electric-type moves and a resistance to Ice-type moves, greater special bulk, and access to Heal Bell. It should be kept in mind that having both Will-O-Wisp and Defog on the same moveset is Rotom-S's only niche over the previously mentioned Pokemon and is, for the most part, the only reason to use it.
Rotom-Fan.comments:
Other Options

An alternate EV spread of 248 HP / 192 Def / 68 SpD permits Rotom-S to avoid the 2HKO from Primeape's Stone Edge and Hitmonchan's Ice Punch after Leftovers recovery. Rest + Chesto Berry is a possible recovery option, but it can only effectively be used once, subsequently forfeiting its item slot; since Rotom-S does not have the room for Sleep Talk, it is not suggested either, since a sleeping Rotom-S cannot serve its primary role of being a Defogger. Rocky Helmet is another option for an item but it is generally inferior to Leftovers or Iapapa Berry, which supplement Rotom-S's recovery. It can get a little chip damage on physical attackers like Kangaskhan but eliminates its recovery altogether unless Pain Split is used. Specially defensive Rotom-S can be used, but is largely outshined by Lanturn in this role. Choice Scarf is a possible but unrecommended set that is overshadowed by other Electric-types such as Rotom-F, which has a better STAB combination. An offensive Defog set can be utilized, but it is outclassed by Oricorio-E, which can use a much stronger Flying-type STAB move in Hurricane, has reliable recovery in Roost, and has higher Speed. Swanna is another Fighting-type check and Defogger that overshadows Rotom-S in speed and offensive prowess. Substitute + Pain Split is yet another option Rotom-S can run. Toxic and Thunder Wave can be run too, as they enable Rotom-S to cripple its checks. However, Substitute, Toxic, and/or Thunder Wave are usually less useful and would mean that Rotom-S would have to replace a much more valuable utility move.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Lanturn is Rotom-S's greatest downfall. It not only prevents Rotom-S from pivoting, but it actually heals itself through Volt Absorb and takes advantage of Rotom-S's inability to deal significant damage to it. In general, offensive Electric-types take of advantage Rotom-S; examples include Rotom-F, Alolan Raichu, and Eelektross. The most Rotom-S can do is pivot against them as they come in.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Walls such as Clefairy and Audino can comfortably take all of Rotom-S's attacks and retaliate with Toxic or provide clerical support for their team. Clefairy can also spam Stealth Rock or set up with Calm Mind.

Ice-types: Powerful Ice-type wallbreakers such as Abomasnow, Cryogonal, and Aurorus will obliterate all Rotom-S sets. On the other hand, Rotom-S can threaten the former with STAB Air Slash.

Rock-types: Regirock can use Toxic on Rotom-S and proceed to set up Stealth Rock in spite of Rotom-S's numerous attempts to remove them, stalling Rotom-S until it succumbs to poison. Faster Rock-types like Lycanroc and Kabutops will either OHKO or easily 2HKO Rotom-S.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Moves

Volt Switch is the preferred STAB Electric-type attack, as it enables Rotom-S to generate momentum for the team. Will-O-Wisp can be used to burn common physical attackers such as Golurk and Primeape, reducing the damage of their moves and neutralizing them. It can also be used to pressure Rotom-S's checks such as Mudsdale. Defog allows Rotom-S to remove any hazards. Thus, it expands Rotom-S's role as a defensive pivot. Though unreliable, Pain Split can heal Rotom-S while damaging the foe simultaneously. Because of Rotom-S's naturally low HP stat, this move can be fairly good. It can be used offensively as well, severely denting its counters and possibly even putting them in knockout range.

Set Details

48 Speed EVs allow Rotom-S to outspeed Jolly Aggron and maximum invested neutral-natured base 60s such as Abomasnow and Pawniard. Iapapa Berry gives Rotom-S a one-time heal of 50% of its maximum health, which will activate after Rotom-S switches into Stealth Rock three times. Alternatively, Leftovers is a passive form of recovery that lets Rotom-S avoid the 2HKO from Primeape's Stone Edge and Hitmonchan's Ice Punch but is otherwise negligible.

Usage Tips

Rotom-S should be brought in early-game, as it can cripple common entry hazard setters such as Regirock with Will-O-Wisp as well as clear any entry hazards with Defog. Its tendency to be worn down easily throughout the match signifies the need to remove entry hazards as soon as possible so it is healthy enough to check Gurdurr, Primeape, and Scyther. Later in the match, Rotom-S should be brought in on slower Pokemon such as Audino or on resisted Grass-, Fighting-, or Flying-type moves to eliminate any remaining entry hazards. This may include, but is not limited to, Choice-locked Primeape's Close Combat and Swanna's Hurricane. Being immune to the Toxic Spikes, Rotom-S should be brought in directly on Qwilfish to quickly remove the aforementioned hazard before a teammate can be afflicted by poison. Although it has a great Defense stat, Rotom-S's appalling HP stat prevents it from taking more powerful physical hits such as Stoutland's Return and Zangoose's Facade. Therefore, be sure to switch it in only on weak to moderate physical attacks. Since Electric-types like Alolan Raichu tend to wall Rotom-S's attacking moves, predict this by going for a status move or pivot out, unless the foe has Lightning Rod or Volt Absorb. After it inevitably gets worn down from repeated attacks, Rotom-S should go for Pain Split, as it will recover a lot of health, especially against Pokemon with high HP stats such as Skuntank and Audino. When facing faster Taunt users such as Qwilfish or Defiant users such as Primeape, instead of going for Defog, predict and respond with a STAB move.

Team Options

In general, Fighting-types such as Hitmonchan are valuable teammates to Rotom-S because of their good type synergy with it. While Rotom-S can easily take a Supersonic Skystrike from Oricorio-G, Gurdurr and Primeape can deal with the common Ice-types that are the bane of Rotom-S's existence, with Primeape being able to form a solid VoltTurn core with Rotom-S. Other pivots like Silvally-Fairy can coincide with Rotom-S to gain momentum for the team. They also help with breaking specially defensive walls such as Lanturn. Clefairy and other specially defensive walls can take on the strong special attackers that would otherwise beat Rotom-S, like Drampa. Wish support from clerics such as Audino helps with Rotom's lackluster recovery. In return, Rotom-S can check the Fighting-types that threaten Audino, such as Hitmonchan, Primeape, and Gurdurr. Pokemon such as Aurorus, Jynx, and Omastar that can tear apart Rotom-S's checks and counters appreciate the removal of entry hazards and benefit greatly from Rotom-S's Defog. As such, Rotom-S would fit better on more balanced or offensive teams that value Defog support but can moreover harness its pivotal capabilities.

Regigigas.overview: Regigigas at first glance looks good to use because of its stats, movepool, and great utility options; however, the problem lies in its ability Slow Start, as it halves its Attack and Speed for 5 turns, which takes out any offensive use for this Pokemon. Although Slow Start reactivates every time it switches in, Regigigas can still spread status and Knock Off items. It is outclassed by other Normal-type Pokemon like Stoutland and Kangaskhan because they have a more useful ability and more use offensively.

sets.name: Slow Utility
sets.description: This set attempts to spread status, Knock Off items, and use Thunder Wave and Substitute to avoid status and stall out turns to get rid of Slow Start. However, Regigigas struggles with this because it gets outpaced by most of the metagame, as it will take a hit before it gets a chance to move and its attacks will hit weakly. Furthermore, it easily gets worn down due to its unreliable recovery from Leftovers and Drain Punch, as it does not have access to moves like Rest and Protect. Other Normal-type Pokemon like Stoutland and Kangaskhan both have a more immediate offensive presence, with their ability allowing them to hit Ghost-type Pokemon with their STAB moves, and have their own niches like Stoutland's Pursuit and Kangaskhan's access to two priority moves.

Phione.overview: Phione is practically unviable due to its subpar base 80 stats across the board. It is relegated to being a Rain Dance pivot that can keep itself healthy thanks to Heal Bell and Hydration, but even in the only role it can take it is outclassed by Volbeat and Liepard thanks to their better stats and more helpful utility options.

sets.name: Rain Dance
sets.description: Phione is a Rain Dance pivot that can semi-reliably heal itself thanks to the combination of Rain Dance and its ability Hydration, along with Heal Bell. However, this set is inferior to other rain setters such as Liepard and Volbeat thanks to their better stats, stronger support options such as Taunt, Thunder Wave, and Encore, and access to Prankster.

Servine.overview: Servine's main niche is being a bulky Defog user that can take on most Stealth Rock users due to its Grass typing. Access to Contrary and Leaf Storm also allows it to boost its Special Attack while using a strong STAB move, and access to reliable recovery in Synthesis helps Servine stay around longer. A decent Speed tier also lets Servine outspeed base 80 Speed Pokemon like Stoutland and Shiftry. Servine's bulk is decent, but a mediocre defensive typing isn't anything to write home about, and as it relies on Eviolite, it is very susceptible to Knock Off and should be wary of Pokemon that commonly use it. A low Special Attack stat means that Servine won't be doing much damage until it gets a boost, meaning that bulky Pokemon like Assault Vest Hitmonchan and Cryogonal can take it on. Servine also lacks special coverage moves, leaving offensive sets limited to a Grass-type STAB attack and Hidden Power and forcing it to choose which Pokemon it wants to beat. Leaf Storm's low PP also limits how much Servine can break through a team. Furthermore, Servine faces competition as a Defog user from Pokemon like Skuntank and Shiftry, which have either a better typing or better utility. Its main competition is Lurantis, which can hit physically with Superpower, is stronger, bulkier, and can afford to run different items, meaning Servine's only real niche over Lurantis is its Speed.
Servine.comments:
Other Options

Glare can be used as a form of Speed control, though Servine has a hard time justifying it over the utility of Defog and Synthesis, and choosing a support move over Hidden Power Ice leaves it walled or more threatened by many Pokemon. Aromatherapy can be used for team support but suffers the same problems as Glare in that it's hard to choose a move to give up. Hidden Power Fire can be used to immediately beat Ferroseed and Alolan Sandslash and pressure other Steel-types, though it leaves Servine more open to Dragon-types like Drampa. Alternatively, Hidden Power Rock can be used to hit both Flying- and Fire-types like Oricorio-E and Simisear super effectively, though doing so leaves Servine unable to hit Grass- and Dragon-types super effectively. Knock Off is an option to cripple Pokemon that may otherwise be a nuisance to Servine or its teammates such as Clefairy and Gurdurr. Taunt makes it even easier for Servine to beat most entry hazard setters, as it can prevent them from setting hazards up at all, but is again hard to fit. A SubSeed set can be used, though it is unable to touch Pokemon like Drampa that avoid Leech Seed, and is generally outclassed by Jumpluff. A specially defensive set with Mirror Coat can be used to take a hit from strong special attackers and surprise Pokemon like Haunter and Drampa but is situational at best.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types in general are a problem for Servine, as they check it and can normally beat it one-on-one. In particular, Simisear outspeeds Servine and is able to heavily damage or OHKO it with Fire Blast, and Turtonator can use it to easily set up.

Ice-types: Abomasnow, in addition to beating Servine with Blizzard, also sets up hail, which limits how much Servine can recover with Synthesis. Aurorus acts similarly but can only reliably beat Servine if it is at full HP and Servine doesn't have any boosts. Jynx is able to outspeed Servine and OHKO it with Ice Beam.

Flying-types: Flying-types like Oricorio-G and Dodrio give Servine a very tough time. Oricorio-G can safely come in almost always, and while Dodrio can't directly switch into Servine without taking a notable amount of damage, it is able to reliably OHKO Servine or use Swords Dance as Servine switches out.

Pokemon Resistant to or Immune to Grass: Skuntank and Haunter resist Leaf Storm and easily threaten Servine. Pokemon with Sap Sipper like Drampa and Bouffalant come in freely on Servine and leave it unable to damage them too much.

Strong Wallbreakers: Pokemon like Stoutland and Alolan Raticate easily threaten Servine due to its mediocre bulk, though Servine does outspeed them and can beat them if it already has Contrary boosts.

sets.name: Fast Utility
sets.description:
Moves

Leaf Storm is Servine's strongest STAB move and raises its Special Attack by two stages when used thanks to Contrary. Defog allows Servine to function as a form of entry hazard control by removing Stealth Rock and Spikes from the field. Synthesis is a reliable form of recovery that lets Servine stick around longer to use Defog more or get offensive presence with Leaf Storm. Hidden Power Ice allows Servine to hit several Pokemon that resist or are immune to Leaf Storm such as Drampa, Altaria, and most Grass- and Flying-types.

Set Details

Eviolite boosts Servine's bulk, allowing it to take hits better. Maximum HP EVs are used to increase its overall bulk to allow it to Defog throughout a game. Contrary is Servine's best ability, allowing it to spam Leaf Storm without drawbacks.

Usage Tips

Servine should be brought in on defensively oriented Pokemon like Clefairy, Ferroseed, and Gastrodon and Defog away entry hazards that the former two can set up. It also can switch into and beat other common Stealth Rock setters like Regirock and Mudsdale, with its Grass-typing allowing it to check them. Servine can switch into some offensively oriented Pokemon, though only ones it has a type advantage against, as its bulk isn't too great. Servine is generally used more in a support role and shouldn't be solely relied on for an offensive sweep, though it can do this in a pinch. Servine should try and keep its HP as high as possible with Synthesis so it has more opportunities to come in and take care of hazards. Contrary also allows Servine to be a Defog and Sticky Web deterrent, as the boosts they give to Servine's evasion and Speed can be annoying for opposing teams. However, Servine is heavily pressured by many common offensive Pokemon like Skuntank, meaning that it may have to switch out immediately after clearing hazards with Defog.

Team Options

Pokemon that take large amounts of damage from Stealth Rock like Articuno and Oricorio-G appreciate Servine's role as a hazard remover. Lanturn is able to take advantage of Servine's ability to check Pokemon like Gastrodon and opposing Lanturn while taking care of Flying- and Fire-types like Oricorio-G, Swanna, and Simisear for Servine. As Servine's Grass-typing gives it many weaknesses, it should partner with Pokemon that can safely take strong hits from these types. Regirock can take Fire-, Flying-, and Poison-type attacks fairly well and appreciates Servine's ability to beat most bulky Water-types, while Metang can take Ice-type attacks from Aurorus and is supported by Servine's Ground-type resistance. Strong wallbreakers like Stoutland can wear down a team to a point where Servine can clean up late-game if a team's faster threats are removed. On the other hand, Servine's bulk also means that it struggles with strong breakers itself, so Pokemon that can take on breakers like Drampa and Stoutland also help Servine. Clefairy and the aforementioned Regirock are examples of good options here.

Watchog.overview: Watchog is a poor choice for a Normal-type wallbreaker in the PU metagame, as it is heavily outclassed by Stoutland and Kangaskhan, which possess greater Speed tiers and much more wallbreaking potential. Stoutland and Kangaskhan also have Scrappy to hit opposing Ghost-type Pokemon with their Normal-type moves. On the other hand, Watchog is stuck with Analytic as its best ability, which makes it rely on attacking second; however, with its subpar bulk, it doesn't survive for long.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: Watchog just attempts to come in and hit as hard as it can, having coverage to hit every Pokemon in the tier for at least neutral damage. Once again, there isn't much reason to use Watchog as an offensive Normal-type Pokemon because it doesn't hit as hard as Kangaskhan and Stoutland, its main competition in the PU metagame, and they are faster and possess more bulk than Watchog.

Stoutland.overview: Stoutland stands out as an amazing wallbreaker thanks to an excellent base 110 Attack and access to Scrappy, which allows Stoutland to more easily spam Return. Its decent bulk allows it to switch in on Pokemon such as defensive Jellicent and Roselia, which also allows it to take a hit from faster foes. Although it has a decent Speed for a wallbreaker, it's still not too hard to revenge kill or be outright outsped. It also has trouble with Fighting-, Steel-, and Rock-types and gets a lot of competition from other Normal-types such as Kangaskhan and Dodrio; however, Stoutland stands out from them due to its large damage output without fear of Double-Edge recoil or being put on a timer through Toxic poison.
Stoutland.comments:
Other Options

Crunch can be run over Pursuit in order to hit certain targets that can otherwise switch in on Return or Superpower, such as Bronzor and Metang, but they aren't very common, so it's a very situational move overall. Silk Scarf can be used if you wish to not be locked into a single move, and it also lures Pokemon in if the opponent thinks Stoutland is holding a Choice Band, but the lack of damage output for a wallbreaker is not worth it. Toxic can be used on lured walls such as Regirock and Carracosta, but Stoutland prefers the offensive pressure of its standard moveset, and Toxic is highly exploitable when Choice-locked.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Faster Fighting-types like Primeape can come in and easily OHKO Stoutland with Close Combat, while slower and bulkier Pokemon like Gurdurr can take a hit and KO in return with a combination of Drain Punch and Mach Punch.

Steel-types: Pokemon like Aggron and Bronzor take little damage from Return and can cripple Stoutland with Toxic, set up hazards, or just deal damage. Aggron despises switching into Superpower, while Bronzor must stay wary of Crunch or Pursuit if it tries to switch out. Defensive Mawile is notable, as it doesn't take super effective damage from any of Stoutland's attacks and has Intimidate to make Stoutland do even less damage.

Rock-types: Omastar, Regirock, and Carracosta can all switch in on Stoutland's Return with ease and set up Stealth Rock, use Stoutland as setup fodder, or just dish out some damage. Omastar can also potentially set up on Stoutland if it locks into any move besides Superpower. However, they lack reliable recovery, so they can be somewhat easily whittled down and do not like switching in on a Superpower.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Tangela can switch in on any of Stoutland's attacks with relative ease, heal itself back up, and cripple Stoutland with Sleep Powder or Knock Off. Mudsdale can switch in while healthy and dent Stoutland with Earthquake, but lacks reliable recovery and can be worn down over time.

Faster Pokemon: Stoutland is not too difficult for Pokemon such as Dodrio and Kangaskhan to outspeed and revenge kill if it has taken a lot of damage beforehand. Furthermore, a good number of revenge killers such as Simisear and Jynx can carry super effective coverage in Focus Blast.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Moves

Superpower hits the majority of Pokemon that resist Return for super effective damage, such as Omastar, Regirock, and Aggron. Pursuit deals double damage to Pokemon that switch out, threatening Pokemon such as Musharna and Cryogonal. Facade enables Stoutland to deal massive damage even after being burned, also making the opponent think twice before using a status-inflicting move. It also allows it to better deal with Pokemon such as Jellicent and Sableye.

Set Details

Scrappy allows Stoutland to hit Ghost-types that would otherwise freely switch in on its Return or Superpower. An Adamant nature maximizes Stoutland's damage, but a Jolly nature can be run to outspeed a few key threats, in particular Timid Victreebel, Adamant Kangaskhan, and Jolly Absol.

Usage Tips

Since Stoutland is holding a Choice Band, it will be locked into using a single move unless it switches out, so be wary of that. You are mainly going to be spamming Return, as not only is it STAB-boosted, but it also neutrally hits a large amount of the tier. Stoutland does best as a wallbreaker when dealing with specially bulky walls such as Clefairy and Audino, and although physically bulky Pokemon such as Regirock and Gurdurr can give it trouble, it can usually wear them down over the match.

Team Options

Fighting-type checks like Jellicent and Silvally-Fairy can deal with Fighting-types such as Primeape and Gurdurr. Water-, Ground-, and Grass-types such as Lanturn, Mudsdale, and Victreebel can help against bulky Rock-type Pokemon like Regirock. Fire-types like Simisear can serve as answers to certain Pokemon that can switch in on Stoutland's moves, such as Tangela and defensive Mawile. Late-game sweepers such as Jynx, Nasty Plot Alolan Persian, and Alolan Raichu appreciate Stoutland's ability to break through walls that would otherwise prevent their sweep. Due to being locked into a single move, Stoutland will be switching in and out a lot, and many entry hazard setters also serve as switch-ins to Stoutland, so hazard removers such as Skuntank and Hitmonchan can be good.

Liepard.overview: Liepard is somewhat versatile and unpredictable thanks to its plethora of viable sets such as Choice Band, Nasty Plot, and weather support. As a result of these sets' offensive nature, Liepard fits mostly on offensively based teams that appreciate its good Speed tier and prowess. Liepard has access to Prankster, as well as useful offensive tools such as Pursuit, Sucker Punch, and Knock Off, allowing it to cripple teams. Despite these positives, Liepard has a notable flaw in the fact that its offensive stats are low even when boosted, so it struggles to break past bulky foes such as Mudsdale. Additionally, Liepard has mediocre bulk and is weak to common Fighting- and Fairy-type attacks. Without the proper coverage, it can struggle to retaliate against foes that use these moves. Lastly, Liepard is a prediction-reliant Pokemon, and being Choice-locked into Sucker Punch can be costly because it can give the opponent free turns to set up.
Liepard.comments:
Other Options

A Life Orb set can be used over Choice Band if Liepard doesn't want to be Choice-locked, but it appreciates the extra power behind its coverage moves. Trick cripples bulky walls that try to switch in on Liepard such as Regirock and Audino. Taunt similarly enables Liepard to cripple passive Pokemon like Audino. Fairium Z can also be used as a tool to hit Fighting-types harder and lets Liepard switch into weaker Knock Offs easier. A bulkier EV spread for Weather sets can be used to slightly increase Liepard's longevity, but Liepard has inherently mediocre bulk, so it often isn't worth it.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Hitmonchan can hit Liepard with super effective priority attacks, but have to be wary of Play Rough.

Faster and Stronger Pokemon: Due to Liepard's mediocre defensive stats, any Pokemon that is faster, stronger, and isn't weak to Sucker Punch can check it. Some examples of such threats include Lycanroc and Choice Scarf Primeape.

Weather Setters: Weather setters such as Abomasnow and Aurorus are able to disrupt Liepard's weather set by replacing the weather that Liepard sets for its teammates.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Moves

Knock Off is Liepard's strongest STAB attack and has the utility of removing the foe's item. Pursuit is used to trap Pokemon such as Haunter and Choice Specs Jellicent. Play Rough gives solid coverage versus Fighting- and Dark-types such as Gurdurr, Poliwrath, and Sableye, which would otherwise wall Liepard. U-turn allows Liepard to pivot out on checks like Silvally-Fairy, which gives its team momentum. Sucker Punch is a powerful priority attack against Pokemon that can outspeed Liepard. Lastly, Copycat allows Liepard to revenge kill faster Pokemon such as Dodrio and Choice Scarf Primeape, but only if used with Prankster.

Set Details

Maximum Attack investment with a Choice Band allows Liepard to be as powerful as possible. Maximum Speed investment with Jolly nature ensures that Liepard outspeeds base 105 Speed Pokemon such as Cryogonal. Black Glasses over Choice Band can work, since Liepard spams Knock Off most of the time. Prankster is to be used to give Copycat priority, but if running another move instead, Limber is preferred.

Usage Tips

Choice Band turns Liepard into a prediction-reliant Pokemon. Liepard should use Knock Off to remove foes' items early-game. However, be careful when using Dark-type moves against Psychic- and Ghost-types like Musharna and Jellicent because they sometimes carry Colbur Berry to weaken them; in Musharna's case, its potential Z-Crystal reduces Knock Off damage and its Z-Move can OHKO Liepard back. Bringing Liepard in on predicted Psychic-type attacks from Jynx or choice-locked Ghost-type attacks from Oricorio-G and Haunter is ideal for Pursuit trapping. Be wary when locking Liepard into Sucker Punch because setup sweepers like Carracosta can take advantage of it. Liepard should pivot out on its hard counters with U-turn.

Team Options

Hitmonchan and Kabutops can clear entry hazards with Rapid Spin, while Liepard in return can Pursuit trap Ghost-type Pokemon such as Haunter for them. Entry hazard setters such as Mudsdale, Ferroseed, and Qwilfish are also good partners, as the residual damage they provide can weaken Liepard's switch-ins into range of Knock Off and synergizes well with U-turn. Qwilfish is especially notable because it covers Liepard's weakness to Fighting-, Bug-, and Fairy-type attacks. Pokemon with access to Volt Switch, such as Eelektross and Alolan Raichu, pair well with Liepard because they form VoltTurn cores.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Moves

Dark Pulse is Liepard's strongest special STAB attack and has a chance to make the foe flinch. Encore is perfect for Liepard, since it gives Liepard a chance to set up freely once a foe is locked into a non-threatening move. Copycat allows Liepard to use Dark Pulse as a form of priority due to Prankster and beat faster foes such as Dodrio and Jynx.

Set Details

Black Glasses is used to boost the power of Liepard's Dark Pulse. Alternatively, Leftovers gives Liepard passive recovery at the cost of significant power loss on a Pokemon that's already fairly weak.

Usage Tips

Liepard should aim to lock foes into setup moves or harmless status moves using Encore. Liepard can then proceed to use Nasty Plot after locking a foe with Encore or against a Pokemon Liepard can threaten out. Copycat should be used after using Dark Pulse once, as it will allow Liepard to gain priority on its Dark Pulses. Due to this set being a mono-attacker, it should be preserved until late-game, when its checks are worn down or eliminated from the battle.

Team Options

Silvally-Fairy and Musharna make good partners because they can remove Fighting-types and Liepard appreciates Healing Wish support from the latter. Pokemon that can switch into Fighting-, Bug- and Fairy-type attacks, such as Qwilfish also pair well with Liepard. Qwilfish can also set Toxic Spikes, which will hinder Liepard's checks further. Liepard appreciates residual damage on its foes due to its lack of power, so entry hazard users such as Qwilfish and Regirock work well with it. Alolan Raichu and Jynx make good partners for Liepard since they can threaten Fighting-types and can wear down Pokemon such as Skuntank and Eelektross that can take hits from Liepard otherwise.

sets.name: Weather
sets.description:
Moves

Knock Off is Liepard's best STAB attack and is helpful for removing items from Pokemon such as Assault Vest Hitmonchan and Crabominable, which both disrupt rain. Rain Dance summons rain for 8 turns with Damp Rock, while Sunny Day summons sun for 8 turns with Heat Rock. Encore can be used by Liepard to lock its foes into non-threatening moves, then take advantage of them by bringing in weather sweepers and attackers with U-turn. Thunder Wave is another option that can be used to slow down faster foes.

Set Details

Damp Rock and Heat Rock give 8 turns of weather to a team. Prankster gives priority to Sunny Day and Rain Dance, ensuring Liepard can set the weather quickly. Maximum Speed with a Jolly nature ensures that Liepard is faster than every other Prankster user. Maximum Attack investment gives Liepard some offensive presence and power behind a Knock Off.

Usage Tips

Once Liepard sets the weather, it should exit battle as soon as possible in order to let its team take advantage of as many weather turns as possible. Liepard is less ideal as a lead for weather teams; Liepard should be preserved because it has great utility in setting up weather with priority, so your best bet is to send it in whenever the weather is needed or is about to expire. Liepard isn't bulky at all, so it will find most switch-ins once a teammate is KO'd or against certain passive Pokemon. Liepard's Dark typing allows it to be immune to Prankster moves such as Sableye's Will-O-Wisp, giving Liepard more openings to come in.

Team Options

Liepard should be paired with weather sweepers such as Kabutops and Ludicolo on rain teams or Victreebel and Leafeon on sun teams. Electric-types such as Alolan Raichu can be used on rain teams to take advantage of Thunder's perfect accuracy in the rain. Stealth Rock users, most notably Golem and Regirock, should be used for sun teams because they provide good role compression. Pokemon like Simisear should be paired with Sunny Day Liepard because they take advantage of their Fire-type attacks being boosted by the sun.
